questions.text: A patient presented with right-sided hemiparesis that completely resolved in 4-6 hours. What score will you use to determine the risk of a future stroke in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of a transient ischemic attack. The risk of stroke following TIAs is determined by the ABCD2 score.  

CHADS2-VASc score is used to determine the risk of stroke in a patient with atrial fibrillation.

CURB-65 is a scoring system used to predict mortality in patients with community-acquired pneumonia.

APACHE II is a scoring system used to predict ICU mortality.

Related Pearl: ABCD2 Score

The risk of stroke following TIAs is determined by ABCD2 score:

SBP>140 mmHg or DBP >90 mmHg 1
Clinical symptoms:
  • Unilateral weakness

  • Speech disturbances without weakness
 1
Duration:
  • >60 minutes

  • 10 - 59 minutes

Diabetes 1

ABCD2 Score Total 3-months Rate of stroke (%)

questions.text: Stewart-Treves syndrome is characterized by ______.

choices.text: Superficial venous thrombophlebitis of the anterior chest wall

questions.solution:
Stewart-Treves syndrome is characterized by lymphedema-associated angiosarcoma.

This syndrome is observed in the setting of chronic lymphedema after axillary dissection for breast cancer. It develops on an extremity ipsilateral to an axillary lymphadenectomy. It appears on the upper, medial arm as a violaceous plaque with nonpitting edema and has poor survival.

Surgical excision with wide margins is the treatment of choice but the rate of recurrence is high.

Other options:

Option A: Tietze's syndrome is characterized by a benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages.

Option B: Zuska’s disease, also called recurrent periductal mastitis, is characterized by recurrent retro areolar infections and abscesses.

Option D: Mondor’s disease is characterized by thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall.

questions.text: Which of the following gives rise to major and minor calyces in the kidneys?
questions.solution:
The division of the ureteric bud gives rise to major and minor calyces in the kidney.

The kidney develops from 3 sources as follows:

  • Metanephric blastema (Option C) gives rise to the excretory system of the kidney. It forms the Bowman's capsule, the proximal convoluted tubule, the loop of Henle, and the distal convoluted tubule. 
  • The ureteric bud, an outgrowth of the mesonephric duct, gives rise to the kidney's collecting system. It forms the collecting ducts, minor and major calyces, renal pelvis, and ureter.
  • Angiogenic mesenchyme (Option A), which migrates into the metanephric blastema, gives rise to the glomeruli and the vasa recta. 

Option D: Primitive urogenital sinus arises from the ventral portion of the cloaca and gives rise to the vesicourethral canal cranially and definitive urogenital sinus caudally. The vesicourethral canal gives rise to the urinary bladder, female urethra, and prostatic part of the urethra in males. The definitive urogenital sinus gives rise to the membranous and penile urethra except for the terminal part in males.

questions.text: A patient presents with a white lesion in his mouth which he noticed a month ago. He is a smoker. Oral examination shows a white patch that is adherent and cannot be scrapped off. Oral cavity findings are seen in the image below.  What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Considering the clinical presentation, the lesion shown in the image is suggestive of leukoplakia. The next step of management of this patient will be to do a biopsy of the lesion.

Leukoplakia is a premalignant condition of the oral cavity. It is seen anywhere in the upper aerodigestive tract. It may represent squamous hyperplasia, dysplasia, and/or carcinoma with an associated risk of malignant transformation.

A biopsy should be done to establish a diagnosis and an appropriate work-up is done if carcinoma is identified. Severe dysplasia and carcinoma in situ are premalignant lesions and are treated with complete surgical excision. Mild and moderate dysplasia may be observed or excised.

Cessation of smoking, elimination of the areca nut/pan habit, and reduction in alcohol consumption should be encouraged in all patients with premalignant lesions.

Oral thrush is most commonly caused by Candida albicans. It is a white coating covering your mouth and throat. Scraping it off with a tongue depressor shows inflamed red areas that often bleed slightly as well. Oral thrush can be treated with topical or oral antifungals.

Oral submucosal fibrosis is characterized by the formation of fibrous bands beneath the oral cavity. The disease is progressive and causes limitation of mouth opening and restricted tongue movements. Intralesional steroids and surgical excision of fibrous bands are recommended.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presented with complaints of swelling and pain in the left ankle and knee and fever for 3 days. He had a history of sore throat 3 weeks ago. Echocardiography showed the presence of mitral regurgitation. Histopathological findings are given below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition?

choices.text: Small or medium-sized vegetations on either or both sides of the valve leaflets are seen
Condition can occur after group A streptococcal pharyngitis
Subendocardial irregular thickenings are called MacCallum plaques
Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in the lesion in the heart

questions.solution:
The lesion shown in the histopathological slide is Aschoff's body and the most probable diagnosis is acute rheumatic fever. The rheumatic fever phase of rheumatic heart disease is marked by small, warty vegetations along the lines of closure of the valve leaflets.

Rheumatic fever is an acute, immunologically mediated, multisystem inflammatory disease that classically occurs a few weeks after group A streptococcal pharyngitis. (Option B) Acute rheumatic carditis is a common manifestation of active rheumatic fever. It may progress over time to chronic rheumatic heart disease.

Aschoff's bodies are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells, and occasional plasma cells. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon.

Inflammation of the endocardium and the left-sided valves typically results in fibrinoid necrosis within the cusps or tendinous cord. (Option D) Over these necrotic areas, small vegetations called verrucae develop along the lines of closure. Irregular thickenings present in the subendocardium are called MacCallum plaques. (Option C)

Some major manifestations of rheumatic fever are:

  • Migratory polyarthritis of the large joints 
  • Pancarditis (myocarditis, pericarditis, or endocarditis)
  • Subcutaneous nodules (typically on extensor surfaces of extremities)
  • Erythema marginatum, an irregular circinate skin rash 
  • Sydenham chorea, a neurologic disorder with involuntary rapid movements

In chronic RHD, the mitral valve leaflet is thickened, with commissural fusion and shortening. There is thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords. This can lead to narrowing the mitral orifice, leading to a fish-mouth appearance (buttonhole).

Image showing button hole appearance is seen in mitral stenosis in case of rheumatic heart disease.

Image showing Aschoff bodies seen in RHD.

Note: Small or medium-sized vegetations on either or both sides of the valve leaflets are seen in Libman-Sacks endocarditis. (option A)

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic male patient was found to have a bilateral loss of peripheral visual fields. On tonometry, intraocular pressure was raised. Fundoscopy showed cupping and pallor of the optic disc. Iridocorneal angle was normal on gonioscopy. He is started on a topical drug that reduces the intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral flow. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
The topical drug started that reduces intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral flow is latanoprost, a prostaglandin analog. It is used in the treatment of open-angle glaucoma. 

This patient's findings of peripheral vision loss, increased intraocular pressure (IOP) with optic disc cupping, and a normal iridocorneal angle is suggestive of open-angle glaucoma.

Topical prostaglandins like latanoprost, travoprost, bimatoprost, and tafluprost are now used as first-line agents to lower IOP. The major mechanism of action is by enhancing the uveoscleral outflow though they also increase trabecular outflow.

The most common ocular side effects are conjunctival hyperemia, eyelash thickening, iris hyperpigmentation, and loss of periorbital fat. These drugs are administered once every day at bedtime and are used with caution in inflamed eyes.

The systemic side effects are uncommon and include occasional headaches, malaise, myalgia, skin rash, and mild upper respiratory infections. Latanoprost is preferred as the first-line due to fewer ocular side effects.

Other options:

Option A: Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It reduces IOP by decreasing aqueous production. 

Option C: Mannitol is an osmotic agent, which lowers IOP by creating an osmotic gradient so that water is pulled from the vitreous into the blood vessels. It is used as a short-term treatment to reduce IOP in acute angle-closure glaucoma or prior to intraocular surgery.

Option D: Pilocarpine is a miotic that acts as a cholinergic agonist. In angle-closure glaucoma, cholinergic agents open the angle by contraction of the sphincter pupillae, pulling the iris away from the trabecula.

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: Corneal transparency is maintained by all of the following factors, except _______.
questions.solution:
Corneal transparency is maintained by all of the given factors except irregularity of stromal collagen fibrils. The regularity of stromal collagen fibrils, which are arranged as a lattice, contributes to the transparency of the cornea. 

Other factors contributing to the transparency of the cornea are:

  • Peculiar refractive index of corneal lamellae (Goldmann theory)
  • Avascularity of the cornea
  • Endothelial pumps such as Na+/K+ ATPase pump, bicarbonate-dependent ATPase, Na+/H+ pump.
  • Evaporation from the corneal surface.
  • Normal intraocular pressure.
  • Swelling pressure of the stroma.
  • Corneal crystallins: water-soluble proteins of keratocytes
  • Barrier function of epithelium and endothelium

questions.text: A surgeon performs a hysterectomy for uterine fibroids after obtaining relevant informed consent from the patient.  Despite adequate precaution, the ureter was injured intraoperatively. Under which of the following principles will the doctor not be held responsible for this act?
questions.solution:
The doctor will not be responsible for the above act under medical maloccurrence.

Medical Maloccurrence/Inevitable Accident: Every human being responds differently to different drugs as well as to different treatment modalities. On certain occasions, despite all proper care given by the doctor during treatment, the patient fails to respond properly or may suffer some adverse reactions to the drug which may lead to severe injuries or permanent deformities. This is known as a medical maloccurrence/inevitable accident. 

If the doctor can prove this before the court, it will be an absolute defence against malpractice.

'Res ipsa loquitur' means 'the thing or fact speaks for itself'. It is obvious evidence of the negligent act committed. For example, swabs left in the abdominal cavity post laparotomy.

'Novus actus interveniens': This essentially means that the negligence at the core of the lawsuit stems from the actions of a third party and that this negligence was unforeseeable. The viability of this defence heavily relies on the specific details of each case. For instance, if a doctor writes a prescription that is allegedly illegible, and the pharmacist misreads it, fails to verify it with the doctor, and then dispenses the wrong medication to the patient, resulting in an injury, the doctor might use this defence in such a scenario.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented with pain and swelling in the knee joint. The physician advised for the examination of synovial fluid from the knee joint on polarized light microscopy, which showed needle-shaped crystals. What is the composition and birefringence pattern shown by these crystals?

choices.text: Monosodium urate crystals with negative birefringence
Calcium pyrophosphate crystals with negative birefringence
Calcium oxalate crystals with positive birefringence

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the presence of needle-shaped crystals in synovial fluid point towards the diagnosis of gouty arthritis. It is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals (MSU), which are needle-shaped and show negative birefringence on polarized light microscopy.

The below image shows negative birefringent needle-shaped crystals seen in gout.

Other options:

Option A- Calcium apatite crystals can occur in areas of tissue damage (dystrophic calcification) and in hypercalcemic or hyperparathyroid states (metastatic calcification). Clumps of these crystals may appear as intra- or extracellular nonbirefringent globules or aggregates that stain purplish with Wright’s stain and bright red with alizarin red S.

Option C- Calcium pyrophosphate crystals (rhomboid-shaped) deposition is seen in pseudogout. These crystals are rod-shaped or rhomboid-shaped and are weakly positive or nonbirefringent crystals.

Option D- Calcium oxalate crystals (CaOx) are seen in chronic renal failure. These crystals can be deposited in visceral organs, blood vessels, bones, and joints. The synovial fluid analysis will show the presence of variable-shaped crystals (commonly bipyramidal crystals are seen) with variable birefringence to polarized light.

NOTE:

Though pseudogout is the condition in which the knee joint is most commonly involved, gout can also involve the knee joint.

Below image shows the crystals seen in pseudogout.

Related Pearl: Difference between Gout and Pseudo-gout

Finding

Gout

Pseudogout

Crystal composition

Monosodium urate

Calcium pyrophosphate

Shape

Needle like

Rhomboid

Birefringence pattern

Negative

Weak positive

Most commonly affected joint

1st MTP

Knee

questions.text: As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act, 2021, induction of MTP in a mentally ill or a rape victim is allowed until what age of gestation?
questions.solution:
As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Act, 2021, the induction of MTP in a mentally ill woman or a rape victim is allowed until 24 weeks. 

Features of the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Act 2021:

  • Enhancing the upper gestation limit from 20 to 24 weeks for special categories of women, which includes survivors of rape, victims of incest, and other vulnerable women (like differently-abled women, minors).
  • Opinion of only one provider will be required up to 20 weeks of gestation and of two providers for termination of pregnancy of 20-24 weeks of gestation.
  • Upper gestation limit does not to apply in cases of substantial fetal abnormalities.
  • Name and other particulars of a woman whose pregnancy has been terminated shall not be revealed except to a person authorized in any law for the time being in force.
  • The ground of failure of contraceptives has been extended to women and their partners.

Note: The bill was passed by Rajya Sabha on 17th March 2021.

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: van den Bergh's test in the case of Dubin-Johnson syndrome is interpreted as _____.
questions.solution:
van den Bergh's test in the case of Dubin-Johnson syndrome is interpreted as a direct positive.

van den Bergh's reaction is used to determine the serum bilirubin level. Here, the bilirubin reacts with the diazo reagent to form the azo pigment. 

Interpretation:

  • Conjugated bilirubin is water soluble, hence reacts rapidly with the reagent and gives color and is called a direct reaction.
  • Unconjugated bilirubin is not water soluble hence has to be extracted using alcohol as an agent following which it would react with reagent and give color. Hence it is called an indirect reaction.
  • If both are present, a color is produced immediately, and it intensifies on adding alcohol. This is called as a biphasic reaction.

Dubin-Johnson syndrome is an autosomal recessive trait in which the conjugated bilirubin in the blood is increased. It is due to a mutation in the MRP-2 protein which is responsible for the transport of conjugated bilirubin into bile.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented with complaints of dysphagia and chest pain. A barium swallow study was done and the findings are given below. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The barium swallow image shows a bird beak appearance which is characteristic of achalasia cardia. Secondary achalasia is associated with Chagas disease which is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi infection and not Trypanosoma brucei.

Achalasia is characterized by the triad of incomplete lower esophageal sphincter relaxation, increased lower esophageal sphincter tone, and aperistalsis of the esophagus.

Primary achalasia is rare. It results from the degeneration of nitric oxide–producing neurons that normally induce lower esophageal sphincter relaxation.

Secondary achalasia is associated with the following conditions:

  • Chagas disease
  • Diabetic autonomic neuropathy
  • Infiltrative disorders such as malignancy, amyloidosis, and sarcoidosis
  • Systemic sclerosis
  • Lesions of dorsal motor nuclei (e.g., following polio)
  • Down syndrome
  • Allgrove (triple A) syndrome

Manometry is the gold standard test for diagnosis and it also distinguishes achalasia from other potential esophageal motility disorders.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: Which of the following structures passes through the opening of the diaphragm marked as '?' in the image below?
questions.solution:
The opening of the diaphragm marked in the given image is the esophageal opening. Among the given options, the structure that passes through this opening is the left vagus nerve. 

The esophageal opening passes through a major opening in the muscular part of the diaphragm at the level of the T10 vertebra, a little to the left of the aortic hiatus. The structures passing through the esophageal opening are:

  • Esophagus
  • Right and left vagal trunks
  • Esophageal branches of the left gastric vessels

Option A: The thoracic duct passes through the opening in the crus of the diaphragm at the level of T12 along with the aorta.

Option B: The superior epigastric artery passes through a minor opening called the Space of Larry (Costo-Xiphoid gap) between the sternal and costal parts of the diaphragm.

Option D: The right phrenic nerve passes through the opening in the central tendon at the level of T8 along with the inferior vena cava.

Related Pearl: Diaphragmatic openings

Level of opening

  • Space of Larry (Costo-Xiphoid gap) - Superior epigastric artery

Note:

Splanchnic nerves pass through the right and left crus of the diaphragm.

The azygous vein may sometimes pass through the right crus of the diaphragm.

The hemizygous vein may sometimes pass through the left crus of the diaphragm.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of dull aching pain in the lower abdomen for the past 8 months. There is no clinical evidence of any pelvic pathology. She says the pain decreases on lying down and increases on walking, bending, and standing. You diagnose her with having chronic pelvic pain syndrome. Which of the following is false regarding this syndrome?

choices.text: Conscious pain mapping is not useful in diagnosis

questions.solution:
Conscious pain mapping is a useful investigation in the diagnosis of chronic pelvic pain syndrome.

Chronic pelvic pain (CPP) refers to acyclical pelvic pain of more than 6 months duration. 

Chronic pelvic pain syndrome is a condition characterized by CPP not associated with any clinical evidence of pelvic pathology. It possibly occurs because of dilated pelvic veins. And, hence, shifting the location of pain with body movement is characteristic of this syndrome. It is associated with congestive dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, postcoital ache, and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Doppler ultrasound and venography help in the diagnosis. Conscious pain mapping at laparoscopy under local anesthesia is useful in deciding the cause and location of chronic pain. This improves diagnostic accuracy.

Treatment comprises progestogen therapy. Progestogens, by their anti-estrogenic effect, constrict the veins, reduce blood flow, and suppress ovulation.

questions.text: A preterm neonate delivered one hour back in a PHC is rushed to the district hospital. There is an evisceration of bowel loops from a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the evisceration of bowel loops, coming out of a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus is gastroschisis. It occurs when there is a failure in the closure of the body wall in the abdominal region.

The defects seen in the ventral body wall include:

  • Gastroschisis- The intestinal loops herniate through the defect in the abdominal wall. The defect usually lies to one side of the umbilicus (right side commonly). The loops of the bowel are not covered by amnion as they herniate through the abdominal wall directly into the amniotic cavity. The affected bowel loops can be damaged by exposure to amniotic fluid.
  • Omphalocele- The bowel loops fail to return from the physiologic umbilical hernia. Since the umbilicus is covered by a reflection of the amnion, the omphalocele is also covered by amnion.
  • Congenital umbilical hernia- This is due to a failure of the umbilical ring to close after physiologic herniation of the intestines.

Ectopia Vesicae/ Bladder exstrophy is a congenital abnormality that occurs when the lower abdominal wall does not form properly and the bladder is open and exposed.

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

Characteristic Gastroschisis Omphalocele
Defect size (diameter) 2-3 cm 2-15 cm
Sac Never Always, may be ruptured
Gestational age Prematurity Term
Umbilical cord Adjacent to the defect (defect is seen usually on its right side)  Attached to sac
Herniated viscera Small bowel, stomach, colon Small bowel, stomach, colon, liver
Malrotation Yes Yes
Bowel character Inflammatory, edematous Normal
Enternal nutrition Delayed Normal
Associated abnormalities Uncommon (10% atresia) Common (50%)

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient presented with nausea, vomiting, fatigue, and polyuria. On examination, he has an altered mental state. His past medical history is significant for lung cancer, which is now in remission.  The abnormalities in his blood reports are elevated serum calcium levels and low serum parathyroid hormone levels. What is the most likely type of underlying lung cancer in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts the symptoms of hypercalcemia secondary to humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy (HHM)—a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with underlying squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.

Hypercalcemia results from the ectopic production of parathyroid hormone (PTH) or PTH-related peptides.
Clinical manifestation of hypercalcemia:
  • Renal - polyuria, polydipsia, nephrolithiasis
  • Central nervous system - lethargy, altered mental status, stupor, coma
  • Gastrointestinal - Nausea, vomiting, anorexia, abdominal pain, constipation, peptic ulcer disease, pancreatitis
  • Cardiac - bradycardia, AV block, short QT interval
  • Skeletal - bone pain, pathological fractures

Treatment:

  1. Volume expansion by intravenous normal saline (200-500 mL/h)
  2. Forced diuresis using loop diuretics after sufficient rehydration
  3. Intravenous bisphosphonates (zoledronic acid, pamidronate)
  4. Others - Denosumab, gallium nitrate, steroids

Paraneoplastic syndromes may be the presenting finding or the first sign of recurrence of malignancy.

Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with lung cancer:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)
  • Hypercalcemia of malignancy
  • SIADH

  • Syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) 
  • Cushing's syndrome
  • Eaton-Lambert syndrome
  • Retinal blindness

  • Hypertrophic primary osteoarthropathy

  •  Clubbing

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is associated with the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). Although SIADH presents with fatigue, nausea, and confusion, it also presents with hyponatremia, which is detected on laboratory investigations (not seen in this patient).

questions.text: What is the most common mutation seen in cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
The most common mutation in cystic fibrosis is Phe508del. 

Cystic fibrosis or mucoviscidosis is an autosomal recessive disorder with a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) gene on chromosome 7q. The most common CFTR mutation is F508 deletion.

CFTR gene encodes for ATP-gated chloride channels in the apical membranes of epithelial cells. It regulates the flow of ions across epithelial membranes of sweat glands, respiratory airways, pancreatic ducts, etc. The defect leads to high salt concentrations in sweat and viscous luminal secretions in the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts.

Clinical manifestations/ complications of cystic fibrosis include:
  • Sinusitis and nasal polyps
  • Respiratory - copious hyper-viscous and adherent pulmonary secretions with abnormal mucociliary clearance obstruct small and medium-sized airways leading to respiratory compromise. The disease can be further complicated by bronchiectasis and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).
  • Gastrointestinal - 
    • Thick and adherent exocrine secretions obstruct pancreatic ducts and impair the production and flow of digestive enzymes
    • Tissue destruction of the exocrine pancreas, with fibrotic scarring, cyst proliferation, and loss of acinar tissue - fat malabsorption, steatorrhea, fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies
    • Obstruction of intrahepatic bile ducts and parenchymal fibrosis leading to hepatic insufficiency and focal biliary cirrhosis
    • Distal intestinal obstructive syndrome in adults and meconium ileus in neonates
  • Reproductive - males have infertility due to the congenital absence of bilateral vas deferens and defective sperm transport, resulting in obstructive azoospermia. Females have infertility due to abnormalities of the reproductive tract secretions.

 The diagnosis is confirmed if both of the following criteria are met:

  • Presence of
    • Clinical symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary) or
    • Positive newborn screening or
    • A sibling with cystic fibrosis
  • Evidence of dysfunction of the CFTR gene by
    • Two positive sweat chloride test results were obtained on separate days or
    • Identification of two CFTR mutations by genetic testing or
    • An abnormal measurement of nasal potential difference

Cystic fibrosis requires a multidisciplinary approach to management. The correction of the defect can be via:

  • Lumacaftor, an FDA-approved drug that corrects the misfolding and reverts the Phe508del mutation defect
  • Ivacaftor potentiates CFTR channel opening and stimulates ion transport

End-stage pulmonary failure requires lung transplantation.

questions.text: A male patient presents with complaints of a sudden loss of taste and hearing loss. He also says he is unable to close one eye and tears do not stop flowing. On examination, there are lesions In the ear as shown in the image given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of loss of taste, sudden hearing loss, inability to close one eye, and epiphora along with vesicular eruptions in the external auditory canal and tympanic membrane is suggestive of Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus).

Ramsay Hunt syndrome is caused by the reactivation of Herpes zoster in the geniculate ganglion. In most patients, there is an involvement of the trunk of the facial nerve, which results in severe facial palsy.

Clinically, the patients present with all symptoms of facial palsy along with vesicular rash in the external auditory canal and pinna. The involvement of chorda tympani results in a loss of taste. 

The illustration given below shows the clinical features seen in Ramsay Hunt syndrome.

It may also be associated with hearing loss and vertigo due to the involvement of the 8th cranial nerve. There may also be anesthesia of the face due to the involvement of the 5th cranial nerve.

The treatment of Ramsay Hunt syndrome involves antiviral medications like acyclovir or famciclovir, as well as corticosteroids like prednisone.

Other options:

Option A: Bell's palsy is an idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset due to a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve.

The image given below shows the clinical features seen in Bell's palsy.

 

Option C: Moebius syndrome is a congenital unilateral/ bilateral lower motor neuron facial nerve paralysis with abducens palsy causing abnormal ocular abduction.

Option D: Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome is an idiopathic disorder consisting of a triad of:

  1. Facial paralysis
  2. Swelling of lips
  3. Fissured tongue

The image given below shows the clinical features seen in Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome.

questions.text: What is the most common site of vulval cancer?
questions.solution:
The most common site of vulval cancer is the labia majora. 

Vulval cancer is an uncommon malignancy found in elderly women, usually in their 6th and 7th decades of life. It can also be seen in younger women who have been diagnosed with sexually transmitted infections such as HIV and HPV infections.

Risk factors include

  • Chronic vulval irritation
  • Immunosuppression such as in pregnancy
  • HIV infection, condyloma acuminata
  • Smoking, local dystrophies
  • Poor hygiene.

The most common type of vulval cancer is squamous cell cancer. The other types include melanoma, adenocarcinoma, and basal cell cancer. The labia majora is most commonly involved, but the clitoris and perineal area may be involved too. The anterior two-thirds of the vulva is usually involved. 

Clinical features include bleeding and foul-smelling discharge from the ulcerated lesion. Difficulty in micturition in case of urethral involvement, rectal bleeding, and painful defecation in case of rectal involvement.

Vulval cancer mainly proliferates by direct spread to adjacent regions, and by lymphatic spread. Hematogenous spread of vulval cancer is rare. 

Investigations include punch biopsy, cystoscopy in case of urethral involvement, anoscopy or proctoscopy in case of perineal involvement, CT and MRI scans, and lymphography. Lymphatic mapping and sentinel node biopsy should be done to provide adequate surgical management.

The image given below shows a 4*5cm warty lesion on the left labium majus of the vulva, most likely vulvar cancer.

Related Pearl: Staging of Vulval Cancer (FIGO)

Stage Features
I Tumor confined to vulva
IA Lesions ≤2 cm in size, confined to the vulva or perineum and with stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm, no nodal metastasis
IB Lesions >2cm in size or with stromal invasion >1mm , confined to the vulva or perineum, with negative nodes
II Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with negative nodes
III Tumor of any size with/without extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with positive inguinofemoral lymph nodes
IIIA i) With 1 lymph node macrometastases (≥5mm) or,
  ii)1-2 lymph node micrometastases(<5mm)
IIIB i) With 2 or more lymph node macrometastases (≥5mm), or
  ii) 3 or more lymph node micrometastases (<5 mm)
IIIC With positive nodes with extracapsular spread
IV Tumor invades other regional structures (upper 2/3rd urethra, upper 2/3rd vagina) or distant structures
IVA Tumour invades any of the following:
  i) Upper urethral and/or vaginal mucosa, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to the pelvic bone, or
  ii) Fixed or ulcerated inguinofemoral lymph nodes
IVB Any distant metastasis including pelvic lymph nodes

Related Pearl: Treatment Modality in Vulval Cancer

Stage Treatment
1A
  •  Radical wide local excision
     
1B
  • Partial vulvectomy + ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection
II
  • Tumor 2-4cm – total vulvectomy + B/L groin lymph node dissection
  • Tumor >4cm or poorly differentiated – radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
 
III
  • Megavoltage radiotherapy
  • Local surgical excision - Radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
  • Local recurrence – chemotherapy
 
IV
  • Chemotherapy or radiotherapy
  • Local excision on residual tumor
  • ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node + ve – contralateral node removed
  • Femoral lymph node +ve – pelvic lymph node removed

questions.text: Which among the following features is least likely to be seen in a patient presenting with the condition shown in the image below?

choices.text: Gangrene and ischemic ulcers over the digits
Numbness over the outer aspect of arm and forearm
Wasting of thenar and hypothenar muscles
Pain over the affected limb aggravated by exercise

questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows the extension of the anterior part of the transverse process of C7 vertebrae and is suggestive of the cervical rib. It causes thoracic outlet syndrome. Numbness over the outer aspect of the arm and forearm is least likely to occur in this patient.    

The cervical rib narrows the scalene triangle (bounded by scalenus anterior, scalenus medius, and first thoracic rib below), leading to compression of the subclavian artery at C8 and T1 nerve roots. 

Clinical features: Most of the cases are asymptomatic. 

Vascular manifestations Neurological features Features in the neck
Upper limb claudication usually is observed in the forearm and arm more obvious after usage of the limb. Pain, on the medial side, weakness on the medial side of the arm, forearm, hand Hard, fixed, bony mass in the supraclavicular region
Vasomotor changes with cyanosis, cold fingers, and excessive sweating may be observed. Card test for interossei muscle weakness, Froment’s sign/test for weakness in adductor pollicis may be positive Palpable thrill above the clavicle in the subclavian artery
Wasting of thenar, hypothenar, and forearm muscles.    Bruit on auscultation
Often digital gangrene, ischemic ulcers in digits, edema of fingers and hand are observed     


A radiograph of the neck is useful in detecting a cervical rib. CT scan of the neck and CT angiogram of the subclavian artery are the ideal investigations. MRI of the neck is also useful.

Several treatment options are available like physical therapy, muscle relaxants, NSAIDs, and transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation. Surgery is done in cases of vascular compression and failure of non-operative therapy.

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: A child was brought to the pediatrician. On examination, the child's skull feels soft and appears as shown below. He is also noted to have delayed dentition and bow legs. What could be the cause?
questions.solution:
The given findings such as craniotabes (soft skull), frontal bossing, bow legs, and delayed dentition in a child are suggestive of rickets.

Clinical Features of Rickets:

General:

  • Failure to thrive
  • Listlessness
  • Protruding abdomen
  • Muscle weakness (especially proximal)
  • Fractures

Head:

  • Craniotabes: softening of the cranial bones detected by applying pressure at the occiput or over the parietal bones
  • Frontal bossing
  • Delayed fontanelle closure
  • Delayed dentition
  • Craniosynostosis

Chest:

  • Rachitic rosary: widening of the costochondral junctions which feels like the beads of a rosary
  • Harrison groove: horizontal depression along the lower anterior chest due to pulling of the softened ribs by the diaphragm during inspiration
  • Predisposition to respiratory infections and atelectasis as softening of the ribs impairs air movement

Back:

  • Scoliosis, kyphosis, lordosis

Extremities:

  • Enlargement of wrists and ankles due to growth plate widening
  • Valgus or varus deformities
  • Windswept deformity: occurs when one leg is in extreme valgus and the other is in extreme varus
  • Anterior bowing of the tibia
  • Coxa vara

questions.text: You have been invited to a child's birthday party. On reaching his home, you notice him ride a tricycle to the stairs and then get off, climb the stairs with alternate feet to reach his room. He has built a tower of 9 blocks in his room and is able to copy a circle using the glitter pens you gifted him. What is the likely age that these milestones correspond to?
questions.solution:
These milestones correspond to an age of 3 years.

The milestones attained by a child at age 3 are:

  • Gross motor development: Can ride a tricycle and walk up the stairs with alternate feet
  • Fine motor development: Can build a tower of 9 blocks and can copy a circle
  • Social and adaptive: Shares toys, begins to count, can identify 1-2 colors 
  • Language: Continually asks questions, knows full name

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was brought with concerns of having ingested a foreign body. X-ray confirms the presence of a coin in the esophagus. The child is asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable. Which of the following is the appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Observe for 24 hours; if the foreign body is not passed in feces, then perform endoscopy.
Perform urgent endoscopy and removal of the foreign body.
Make the child eat bananas, and wait for passage of foreign body in stool.
Provide plenty of fluids orally for safe passage of the foreign body.

questions.solution:
Asymptomatic blunt objects and coins lodged in the esophagus can be observed for up to 24 hours in anticipation of passage into the stomach.

Urgent endoscopic removal is preferred for sharp objects, button batteries in the esophagus, and foreign bodies associated with respiratory symptoms.

Button batteries are very dangerous foreign bodies and must be expediently removed because they can cause

  • Mucosal injury in 1-hour contact time
  • Involve all layers of the esophagus in 4 hours

After suspecting a foreign body in either the trachea or esophagus, plain x-rays of the chest, neck, and abdomen are obtained. Anteroposterior and lateral views are helpful in localizing the objects.

A swallowed coin stuck in the esophagus will appear flat on the anteroposterior view, while the edge will be visible in the lateral view. In the case of coins in the trachea, the findings will be opposite- flat in the lateral view and edge in anteroposterior view. This is because of the difference in dimensions of the trachea and esophagus. 

A button can be differentiated from a coin based on the double-halo and step-off that can be seen in anteroposterior and lateral views.

questions.text: The plain x-ray shows a particular change in ribs. This is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The x-ray depicts the inferior rib notching, which is a finding associated with coarctation of the aorta.

Coarctation of the aorta is the narrowing/constriction of the aorta most commonly occurring at origin of ductus arteriosis. It can also be seen preductal or post ductal and is associated with Turner syndrome.

Preductal or infantile type has severe coarctation become symptomatic as soon as the duct begins to close. Differential cyanosis and radial-femoral delay are classic signs.

Adult or juxta ductal is usually mild and goes unnoticed until adolescence. They present as weakness, pain or claudication in legs after exercise, hypertension in the upper extremities with weak pulses and hypotension in the lower extremities.

Roesler sign-Notching of the inferior margin of the ribs(4th-8th) from pressure erosion by enlarged collateral vessels is common by late childhood. 

A figure of 3 sign (Reverse 3) is a contour abnormality of the aorta as shown below.

Rib notching refers to the deformation of the superior or inferior surface of the rib. Osteogenesis imperfecta, rheumatoid arthritis and hyperparathyroidism are associated with superior rib notching.

questions.text: In a young boy who presented with molluscum contagiosum, it was noted that new lesions appeared at the site of scratching. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon where new lesions appeared at the site of scratching in a young boy presenting with molluscum contagiosum is pseudo-Koebner response.

Koebner/isomorphic response (Option B) refers to the appearance of new skin lesions in previously normal skin subjected to trauma. They are typically linear, as they follow the route of the injury.  It is more likely to occur when the disease is active.

Pseudo-Koebnerization refers to the appearance of similar skin lesions at the site of injury, resulting from the spread of an infective agent. It is seen in plane warts and molluscum contagiosum, 

Koebner phenomenon is seen in conditions like

  • Psoriasis
  • Vitiligo
  • Erythema multiforme
  • Lichen planus
  • Necrobiosis lipodica
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Hailey-Hailey disease
  • Darier disease
  • Vasculitis
  • Pityriasis rubra pilaris

Other options: 

Option-C: Reverse Koebner phenomenon refers to the disappearance of skin lesions after trauma to the area, which is seen in psoriasis.

Option-D: Isotopic response is the emergence of a new lesion at the site of a previous unrelated dermatosis such as granuloma annulare developing at the site of herpes zoster and psoriasis developing at the site of contact dermatitis.

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

questions.text: Identify the image shown below.
questions.solution:
The image shown is Charleston bending brace used for scoliosis.

Charleston bending brace is a commonly prescribed nighttime brace. It is custom-fitted based and is intended to be worn while lying down. It applies lateral force to the spine, pushing the curve closer to the midline and holds it in an overcorrected position. 

Milwaukee brace is used in scoliosis. It is also known as a cervico-thoraco-lumbo-sacral orthosis or CTLSO. It is a back brace used in the treatment of spinal curvatures (such as scoliosis or kyphosis) in children. 

The image shown below is the Milwaukee brace:

 

Reisser's cast is also used in the management of scoliosis. The given image shows Risser's cast.

 

Wilmington Brace is another common TLSO brace custom-fitted based on a cast taken of the patient in the supine position. The brace fits onto the body like a tight jacket, known as a full-contact TLSO. The Boston brace is a snug-fitting underarm brace that provides lumbar or low thoracolumbar support. The difference between the two is that the Wilmington brace is custom-made for each wearer.

The following image shows Wilmington/ Boston brace based on whether it was custom-made for the patient:

Boston brace is the most effective among these all.

questions.text: A young primi at 34 weeks of gestation was admitted as her BP was 150/90 mmHg and urine dipstick was 2+ on antenatal checkup. All of the following symptoms indicate progression to severe pre-eclampsia, except _______.
questions.solution:
All of the given symptoms would indicate progression to severe pre-eclampsia except thrombocytosis. Severe pre-eclampsia is associated with thrombocytopenia.

Preeclampsia occurs due to the failure of the invasion of extravillous trophoblasts into the spiral artery. It is characterized by the development of gestational hypertension along with increased urinary protein excretion (≥300 mg/day) after 20 weeks of gestation. Other symptoms suggestive of severe pre-eclampsia are as follows:

  • Headaches - usually over the occipital or frontal region
  • Visual disturbances - These could include scotomas. These are due to spasms of retinal vessels following retinal infarction, occipital lobe damage secondary to vasogenic edema, or retinal detachment. 
  • Epigastric or right upper quadrant pain - This is due to hepatocellular necrosis, ischemia, and edema that stretches the Glisson capsule. This is usually seen along with elevated serum hepatic transaminase levels.
  • Sudden and generalized or persistent edema - Visible edema over the ankles despite rest, especially on rising from the bed in the morning hours, is pathological. 
  • Diminished urinary output
  • Fetal-growth restriction
  • Pulmonary edema

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old man presented with complaints of abdominal pain and fever for the past 2 days. Examination shows palmar erythema, testicular atrophy, and distended abdomen with diffuse tenderness. Shifting dullness is present. His vital signs and laboratory findings are given below. He has a history of alcohol consumption for the past 30 years. Which of the following is the next best step in the management?

Vitals and laboratory findings:

  • BP: 138/90 mmHg
  • Pulse: 93 bpm
  • Temp: 101.8 F
  • WBC: 12,500/mm3
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards liver cirrhosis with ascites. The raised temperature and the increased WBC count are most likely due to spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Paracentesis and ascitic fluid analysis is the next best step in the management of this patient.

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is the spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intraabdominal source. Abdominal paracentesis within 12 hours of admission is the investigation of choice. The diagnosis of SBP is made when the ascitic fluid has an absolute neutrophil count >250/μL.

Infection with E.coli and other gut bacteria is most commonly seen. However, gram-positive bacteria like Streptococcus viridans, Staphylococcus aureus, and Enterococcus sp., can also be found.

Management: The first line of empirical treatment is with a third-generation cephalosporin or a combination of beta-lactam/beta-lactamase agents. In patients who have had an episode of SBP and recovered, prophylactic antibiotics are given to prevent a recurrence.

Other options:

Option A- Liver biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of liver cirrhosis. It determines the grading of inflammation and staging of fibrosis of the liver. Ultrasonography, CT, and MRI are not sensitive to detect liver cirrhosis. It is not the next best step for this patient.

Option B- The administration of fluids is not the best next step for this patient.

Option D- Administration of furosemide and spironolactone is done for the treatment of ascites along with dietary restrictions. However, the patient has a fever and abdominal pain which is a concern for SBP, for which diuresis is not indicated.

questions.text: Which of the following proteins connects the lines marked as A and B (indicated by red arrows) in the following image?
questions.solution:
The above image is the electron microscope view of the muscle. Line A corresponds to the M line, and Line B corresponds to the Z line. The protein that connects the M line with the Z line is titin. 

Here is an image highlighting the various zones of a sarcomere.

The area between two Z-lines is called a sarcomere. 

Apart from proteins like actin, myosin, troponin, and tropomyosin, there are some additional structural proteins that are important for the function of the skeletal muscle:

  • Actinin - It binds actin to the Z lines.
  • Titin - It is the largest protein and connects the Z lines to the M lines.
  • Desmin - It connects Z lines to the plasma membrane.

Dystrophin connects actin filaments to the transmembrane protein β-dystroglycan in the sarcolemma by the smaller proteins syntrophins in the cytoplasm.

The troponin molecules are attached intermittently along the sides of the tropomyosin molecules. They have three loosely bound protein subunits:

  • Troponin I - It inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
  • Troponin T - It binds troponin components to tropomyosin.
  • Troponin C - It binds the calcium ions and initiates contraction.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

Related Pearl: Sarcomere

questions.text: A 72-year-old male patient presented with dysphagia and regurgitation. Barium swallow showed the following picture. Weakness of which of the following muscles predisposes to the given condition​?

choices.text: Transverse fibers of the cricopharyngeus and oblique fibers of the palatopharyngeus.
Transverse fibers of the cricopharyngeus and oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus.
Oblique fibers of the cricopharyngeus and transverse fibers of the thyropharyngeus.
Oblique fibers of the cricopharyngeus and transverse fibers of the palatopharyngeus.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a pulsion diverticulum on the barium swallow is suggestive of Zenker's diverticulum. Weakness of transverse fibers of the cricopharyngeus and oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus predispose to this condition.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

Related Pearl: Pharyngo-esophageal diverticula

 

Diverticula Weak space Site
Zenker diverticulum Killian triangle/ Killian dehiscence

Above the upper esophageal sphincter

Between the oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus muscle and the horizontal fibers of the cricopharyngeus muscle
Laimer's diverticulum Laimer’s triangle/ Laimer–Hackermann’s area

Posteriorly below cricopharyngeus and above longitudinal muscle layer of the esophagus
Killian– Jamieson Diverticulum Killian–Jamieson area
 
Laterally between the oblique and transverse fibers of the cricopharyngeus
at its attachment to the cricoid cartilage

questions.text: A 40-year-old female came with a history of jerky movements involving limbs and trunk. She also complains that she is more irritable nowadays. Her MRI from a previous doctor's visit shows marked atrophy of the caudate nucleus. The pedigree chart is given below and investigations show trinucleotide repeat (CAG) sequences. Which of the following drugs can be used to manage the movement disorder in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with trinucleotide repeat (CAG) sequences and the family pedigree showing the autosomal dominant mode of inheritance point towards a diagnosis of Huntington’s disease. VMAT2 (Vesicular monoamine transporter 2) inhibitor approved for the treatment of Huntington's chorea is deutetrabenazine.

Huntington's disease (HD) is a degenerative disease of the caudate and putamen (“striate neurons”) caused by an autosomal dominant inheritance of a trinucleotide repeat (CAG) in the Huntington gene (chromosome 4), which results in motor, behavioral, oculomotor, and cognitive dysfunction. HD is characterized by rapid, nonpatterned, semi-purposeful, involuntary choreiform movements of limb, face, or trunk. A phenomenon referred to as anticipation is seen particularly in males, with subsequent generations having larger numbers of repeats and earlier ages of disease onset.

Tetrabenazine and deutetrabenazine are inhibitors of VMAT2 and cause presynaptic depletion of catecholamines. Deutetrabenazine is a newer form of tetrabenazine approved for the treatment of chorea associated with Huntington's disease. Deutetrabenazine takes advantage of the stronger bonds that deuterium forms with carbon (deuterated tetrabenazine). They have a longer half-life than the corresponding products of tetrabenazine metabolism.

Tetrabenazine is extensively metabolized by CYP2D6. It may cause hypotension and depression with suicidal tendencies. It can also cause parkinsonism. Deutetrabenazine has adverse effects similar to those of tetrabenazine.

Other options:

Sodium valproate is used for moderate-severe Sydenham's chorea. It is characterized by involuntary, purposeless, jerky movements which mainly affect the head and upper limbs. In the tongue, it is visible as the characteristic darting movements.

Deflazacort: Corticosteroid approved for the treatment of Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy.

Edaravone: It is a free radical scavenger approved for the treatment of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

Disease Repeats Clinical features
Fragile X- syndrome   CGG Mental retardation, large ears and jaws, macroorchidism in males

Myotonic Dystrophy

(chromosome 19)

   CTG Muscle loss, cardiac arrhythmia,
cataracts, frontal balding
Huntington’s disease   CAG Affective disorder
Spinocerebellar ataxia type 1   CAG Progressive ataxia, dysarthria,
dysmetria.
Friedreich's ataxia   GAA Progressive ataxia,
dysarthria, hypertrophic
cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: As the medical officer of the primary health center (PHC), you are tasked with setting up a camp to promote the vaccination of children. The nurse from the PHC transports the vaccines in ice. The test shown in the image is performed for which of the given vaccines?
questions.solution:
The image shown is shake test that is used for the pentavalent vaccine, which is a freeze-sensitive vaccine.

The "Shake Test" is used to check whether freeze-sensitive vaccines have been damaged by exposure to temperatures below 0°C.  Once it has been thawed, the vial of freeze-damage vaccine no longer has the appearance of a cloudy liquid but tends to form flakes that settle down at the bottom of the vial.

  • A frozen vaccine is used as a control vial and the vial suspected to be damaged by freezing is taken as the test vial.
  • Both are shaken after thawing and the rate of sedimentation is compared.
  • If the rate of sedimentation in the test vial is slower than the control vial, then it is usable and has not been damaged.

Freeze-sensitive vaccines:

  • Hepatitis B
  • Pentavalent
  • IPV (Inactivated poliovirus)
  • DPT
  • TT
  • PCV

 Measles, Oral poliovirus vaccine, and Bacille Calmette-Guerin vaccine are not damaged by freezing.

Related Pearl: Temperature Sensitivity of Vaccines

  • Measles, mumps, rubella

  • Rabies

  • Varicella zoster

questions.text: An individual takes a deep breath of 100% oxygen from mid-inspiration and then expires through a rapidly recording nitrogen meter. This produces the recording shown in the image below. What does this test measure?
questions.solution:
The test described is the single-breath N2 test which is used to measure the dead space volume, and the image shown is the single-breath N2 curve.

From mid-inspiration, the patient inhales 100% oxygen as deeply as possible, then exhales steadily while the N2 content of the expired gas is continuously measured using a nitrogen meter. The recording obtained is the single-breath N2 curve.

  • Phase I of the curve: Initial gas exhaled that was present in the dead space. It does not contain any N2.
  • Phase II: A mixture of dead space and alveolar gas
  • Phase III: Alveolar gas. It terminates at the closing volume (the lung volume above residual volume at which lower airways begin to close due to lesser transmural pressure)
  • Phase IV: The N2 content of the expired gas is increased.

The volume of the dead space is the volume of the gas that is expired from peak inspiration to the midportion of phase II. The total dead space can be calculated using Bohr's equation. 

The anatomic dead space refers to the respiratory system volume exclusive of alveoli, and the total (physiological) dead space is the volume of gas not equilibrating with blood i.,e. wasted ventilation. In healthy individuals, the two dead spaces are almost equal and can be estimated by body weight. The normal dead space air in a young adult man is around 150 mL.

Other options - 

Option B: Forced vital capacity, a dynamic lung measurement from spirometry is the largest amount of air that can be expired after a maximal inspiratory effort. Forced expiratory volume in the first second, FEV1, is the fraction of the vital capacity that is expired during the first second.

 

Option C: Tidal volume (TV) is measured with the help of a diagnostic spirometer. It is the amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration or the amount of air that moves out with each expiration during quiet breathing. The normal values are 500-750 mL.

Option D: Diffusion capacity of the lungs across the alveolocapillary membrane as an index is measured using carbon monoxide (CO) gas. The normal value of DLCO at rest is about 25 mL/min/mmHg. It is calculated by:

questions.text: All of the following are used in the management of patients with spontaneous subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), except _____.
questions.solution:
All of the following are used in the management of all patients with SAH except fluid restriction. Hyponatremia is a common complication in SAH and fluid restriction will worsen perfusion.

SAH is caused by bleeding from a ruptured aneurysm (80% of cases) or arterio-venous malformations.

Clinical features:

  1. Transient loss of consciousness.
  2. Acute-onset severe headache (described as the worst headache of a patient's life)
  3. Neck rigidity
  4. Focal neurological deficits
  5. Painful oculomotor nerve palsy due to posterior communicating artery aneurysm 
  6. Abducens nerve palsy as a result of cavernous sinus aneurysm

Non-contrast CT will show the presence of blood in the subarachnoid space and basal cisterns. A lumbar puncture will reveal the presence of xanthochromia. 

Hess and Hunt's scale is the most widely used scale to grade the severity of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Surgically, SAH can be managed by aneurysm clipping and endovascular coiling within 24 hours of the bleed, if tolerated. 

Medical management of SAH focuses on protecting the airway, managing blood pressure, preventing rebleeding, managing vasospasm, and treating hydrocephalus.

Oral nimodipine causes vasodilation of cerebral blood vessels and improves the outcome by preventing ischemic injury. Systolic blood pressure is maintained below 160 mmHg using nicardipine, labetalol, or esmolol. Osmotically active agents, such as mannitol are given to combat raised intracranial pressure. Analgesics, anti-emetics, and gastric protective agents are also used. 

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is admitted to the ICU with fever and hypotension. She has rigors, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Her BP is 70/50 mmHg, with a pulse of 140 bpm, and a temperature of 39.5°C. She is minimally responsive. Skin examination reveals generalized erythroderma but no signs of skin infection. Pulmonary examination shows diffuse crackles bilaterally. Examination per vagina reveals a retained tampon that is immediately removed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above presentation of fever, hypotension, erythroderma, conjunctival hyperemia, vomiting, and the finding of a retained vaginal tampon, point towards a likely diagnosis of staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome.

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a toxin-mediated disease that is most commonly associated with staphylococcal and group A streptococcal infections. Staphylococcal TSS on the other hand is associated with the toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1), which binds directly to the MHC II complex and T-cell receptors. This results in a massive increase in cytokines interleukin-2 (IL-2), interferon γ, and tumor necrosis factor (TNF), leading to a cytokine storm. 

Staphylococcal TSS is associated with the use of a highly absorbent tampon. Nonmenstrual cases are seen in patients with surgical or postpartum wound infections, especially when packing of the wound occurs.

The clinical criteria required to diagnose TSS include fever >102 °F diffuse macular erythroderma with desquamation after 1-2 weeks, hypotension, and the involvement of >3 organ systems(liver, kidneys, gastrointestinal tract, and/or CNS). The laboratory diagnosis of staphylococcal TSS can be made when negative results are obtained in the following tests:

  • Blood or cerebrospinal fluid cultures for another pathogen

  • Serologic tests for leptospirosis, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, or measles

The T-cell activation which produces the cytokine storm in TSS can be seen in the image below:

Other options:

Option A: Rocky Mountain spotted fever is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii. In this condition, the rash begins on wrists and ankles and spread centripetally. The appearance of rash on palms and soles happens later in the disease. Lesion evolves from blanchable macules to petechiae. Headache, myalgias, and abdominal pain can accompany the infection.

Option B: Invasive meningococcal disease presents with meningitis, sepsis (ie, meningococcemia), or a combination of both. Meningitis is the most common complication of meningococcal bacteremia. It usually begins suddenly with an intense headache, vomiting, photophobia, confusion, and a stiff neck. The condition may progress to coma within a few hours.

Option D: Streptococcal TSS is associated with pyrogenic exotoxin and other toxins that act as superantigens and mediate the release of proinflammatory cytokines. In contrast to patients with staphylococcal TSS, the majority with streptococcal TSS are bacteremic. The most common associated infection is a soft tissue infection—necrotizing fasciitis, myositis, or cellulitis. It can also be seen in pneumonia, peritonitis, osteomyelitis, and myometritis. The general features of the illness include fever, hypotension, renal impairment, and respiratory distress syndrome. Rash usually does not develop. In the given situation, the source of infection is the retained vaginal tampon, streptococcal TSS is not the correct the answer.

Related Pearl: Cutaneous Infections/Diseases caused by Staphylococcus aureus

Cutaneous Infections/Diseases caused by Staphylococcus aureus

A. Direct infection of skin and adjacent tissues

  • Carbuncle
  • Ecthyma
  • Folliculitis
  • Furunculosis
  • Impetigo
  • Sycosis

B. Secondary infection

  • Eczema, infestations, ulcers, etc.

C. Cutaneous disease due to effect of bacterial toxin

  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS)
  • Toxic shock syndrome
  • Staphylococcal scarlatina
  • Recurrent toxin‐mediated perineal erythema

questions.text: A female child is being evaluated for primary amenorrhea and short stature. An ultrasound was done, and it showed a small uterus and streak ovaries. Which of the following cardiac anomaly is most likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of primary amenorrhea and short stature along with streak ovaries in the ultrasound is suggestive of Turner syndrome. It is frequently associated with left-sided cardiovascular anomalies like bicuspid aortic valves.

Turner syndrome occurs due to complete or partial monosomy of X-chromosomes. It produces hypogonadism in phenotypic females.

Clinical findings include webbing of the neck, protruding ears, and lymphedema of the hands and feet, short stature. The gonads are streaks of fibrous tissue, known as gonadal dysgenesis. There is primary amenorrhea and a lack of secondary sex characteristics. Congenital heart anomalies and structural renal anomalies are common.

Cardiac anomalies in Turner syndrome: Common defects are bicuspid aortic valves, coarctation of the aorta, aortic stenosis, and mitral valve prolapse. Cardiovascular abnormalities are the most important cause of mortality.

Related Pearl: Disorders of Sexual Development

Mullerian agenesis

Turner syndrome

Complete XY dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome)

Cause

X-linked mutation of androgen receptor

Also called Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome

SRY gene mutation on the Y chromosome

Reproductive organs

Absent or rudimentary uterus and upper vagina, normal ovaries
