Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

  • 45 XO which is seen in 40-50% patients 
  • 45 X mosaicism (eg, 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/47,XXX, or 45,X mosaics with the X chromosome anomalies)

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis was started on methotrexate therapy. What is the mechanism of action of methotrexate?
questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of methotrexate is the inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase.

It has well-known immunosuppressant and anti-inflammatory properties. Beneficial effects in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are due to the inhibition of cytokine production, chemotaxis, and cell-mediated immune reaction.

Methotrexate is now the disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drug (DMARD) of choice and the standard treatment for most patients. Also used in cases of juvenile RA.

Adverse effects of methotrexate include hepatotoxicity, myelosuppression, and interstitial pneumonitis. Other side effects include nausea, loose stools, punctate cutaneous eruptions, and alopecia. Probenecid and aspirin can increase the levels of the drug and its toxicity. It is contraindicated in pregnancy, breastfeeding, leucopenia, liver disease, and peptic ulcer.

Other Options:

Option A: Some of the cell wall synthesis inhibitors are penicillins, cephalosporins, carbapenems, and monobactams.

Option B: Tetracyclines, chloramphenicol, macrolides, clindamycin, and linezolid inhibit protein synthesis. 

Option C: Azathioprine is a purine synthase inhibitor and is a potent suppressant of cell-mediated immunity.

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with excessive bleeding during menstruation, accompanied by a feeling of heaviness in her lower abdomen. Her periods last for 8-10 days and are associated with the passage of clots. An ultrasound of her pelvis reveals a well-defined, heterogeneous hypoechoic mass. Which among the following drugs are not helpful in the shrinkage of this tumour before surgery?
questions.solution:
The clinical case and ultrasound findings point to a diagnosis of uterine fibroid (leiomyoma), and misoprostol does not help shrink the size or reduce the vascularity of the tumor. 

Drugs to reduce the size of the fibroid:

  • Antiprogesterone – Mifepristone/RU-486.
  • Danazol (usually not used due to androgenic side effects).
  • GnRH 
    • Agonists – goserelin, leuprolide, triptorelin, nafarelin.
    • Antagonists – cetrorelix, ganirelix.
  • Selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRMs) – Ulipristal, Asoprisnil.

Other medical methods used in the treatment of fibroids:

  • Levonorgestrel intrauterine device - controls bleeding effectively.
  • Combined oral contraceptives
  • Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA).
  • Tranexamic acid.
  • Iron therapy for anemia.
  • Selective estrogen-receptor modulators (SERMs) like tibolone and raloxifene are used as add-back therapy along with GnRH treatment. They reduce associated vasomotor symptoms and bone loss without interfering with the size of the fibroid. 

Radiological interventions for fibroids:

  • Uterine artery embolization - Angiographic procedure where polyvinyl alcohol microspheres are introduced into both uterine arteries, producing ischemia and necrosis of the fibroid.
  • Magnetic resonance-guided focused ultrasound - Ultrasound energy is focused to cause coagulative necrosis in selected fibroids.

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

Related Pearl: Contraindications to uterine artery embolization

Absolute contraindications:

  • GnRH agonist use
  • Asymptomatic fibroids
  • Pregnancy
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Uterine malignancy
  • Calcified fibroid

Relative contraindications:

  • Patient desirous of future pregnancy: UAE causes poor uterine perfusion and pelvic adhesions, decreasing fertility. 
  • Postmenopausal women: Fibroids regress naturally, after menopause. Fibroid enlargement post-menopause raises the suspicion of malignancy.
  • Subserosal or submucosal fibroids: Pedunculated subtypes may detach intraperitoneally or within the uterine cavity. This may lead to sterile peritonitis or intrauterine infection.
  • Size or number of fibroids: Large fibroids or a greater number of fibroids can cause large amounts of necrosis following UAE. This may lead to post-op pain or infection. 
  • Contraindications to radiologic contrast agents.

Related Pearl: Uses of Misoprostol

INDICATIONS PRIMARY DOSE OF MISOPROSTOL REMARKS

MEDICAL TERMINATION OF PREGNANCY

 

Combined Regimen(recommended):
Upto 12 weeks of gestation-800mcg vaginally, buccally or sublingually.

Beyond 12 weeks of gestation-400mcg vaginally, buccally or sublingually every 3 hours


Misoprostol only regimen:
Upto 12 weeks-800mcg vaginally, buccally or sublingually

Beyond 12 weeks-400mcg vaginally, bucally or sublingually every 3 hours

Ideally used 1-2 days after 200mg of Mifepristone in the combined regimen.


The mucosal route of administration is preferred over the oral route of administration.


These doses also apply for incomplete and missed abortion.

SURGICAL ABORTION

12-14weeks- both medical and surgical methods can be done

>14weeks-surgical method 

 Cervical preparation: 400mcg vaginally/ sublingually

Another method: Oral Mifepristone 200mg 24-48 hours before the procedure

 
PPH Prophylaxis

800mcg sublingual single dose OR 600mcg orally/ sublingually/rectally

single dose for PPH secondary prevention (approx >350ml blood loss)

  Where oxytocin is not available or storage conditions are inadequate
PPH treatment 800 mcg sublingually single dose

questions.text: Which of the following hypothalamic nucleus/nuclei is/are responsible for maintaining the normal body temperature at extreme climatic conditions?
questions.solution:
Anterior and posterior hypothalamic nuclei are responsible for regulating the body temperature in response to heat or cold, respectively. 

The anterior hypothalamic-preoptic area contains large numbers of temperature-sensitive neurons, that are believed to function as temperature sensors for controlling body temperature.

Bilaterally in the posterior hypothalamus, approximately at the level of the mammillary bodies, signals from the anterior hypothalamic preoptic area and signals from elsewhere in the body are integrated to control the heat-producing and heat-conserving reactions of the body.

Other options:

Option A: The ventromedial nuclei of the hypothalamus serve as a major satiety center that gives a sense of nutritional satisfaction and inhibits the feeding center.

Option C: The lateral nuclei of the hypothalamus serve as a feeding center and operates by exciting the motor drives to search for food.

Option D: Suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus controls the circadian rhythms and synchronizes various physiological changes of the body with night and day. It is critical for organizing sleep into a recurring 24-hour circadian pattern of sleeping and waking.

Related Pearl: Functions of Main Hypothalamic Nuclei

 

Hypothalamic Nucleus Function
Supraoptic  Synthesizes vasopressin (ADH)
Paraventricular Synthesizes oxytocin
Preoptic & anterior Nuclei Control parasymphathetic system
Posterior & Lateral Control symphathetic system
Anterior Regulate temperature(response to heat)
Posterior Regulate temperature(response to cold)
Lateral

Initiate eating and increase food intake (Hunger center)
Increase water intake (Thirst center)
Medial

Inhibit eating and reduce food intake (satiety center)

Suprachiasmatic

 Controls circadian rhythm

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of drug abuse and multiple unstable relationships. You notice scars on the patient’s forearm that look self-inflicted. The patient also mentions a long-lasting feeling of emptiness and anger issues in relationships. Which of the following personality disorders is the patient likely to have?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is indicative of borderline personality disorder.

Borderline personality disorder belongs to cluster B of personality disorders. Diagnostic features of this disorder include at least five of the following:

  • Frantic efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment.
  • Unstable or intense interpersonal relationships, alternating between idealization and devaluation.
  • Markedly and persistently unstable self-image or sense of self.
  • Impulsivity in at least two potentially self-damaging areas (spending, sex, reckless driving, substance abuse, binge eating)
  • Recurrent suicidal behavior, gestures, threats, or self-mutilating behaviors.
  • Instability of affect due to marked reactivity of mood
  • Chronic feelings of emptiness
  • Inappropriately intense anger or difficulty controlling anger
  • Stress-related, transient paranoid ideation or dissociative symptoms.

Associated features can include tendency to undermine self when close to reaching a goal and intense attachment to non-human objects like pets and material things than to other humans.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the treatment of alcohol abuse causes reduced craving by blocking the opioid receptor?
questions.solution:
Naltrexone causes reduced reward response to drinking and reduced craving by blocking the opioid receptor.

Before prescribing: Evaluate for possible current opioid use; consider a urine toxicology screen for opioids, including synthetic opioids. Obtain liver function tests and follow up periodically.

Acamprosate, naltrexone, and disulfiram are used in the treatment of alcohol dependence.

Other options:

Option A: Chlordiazepoxide is a benzodiazepine used in the treatment of alcohol withdrawal.

Option B: Acamprosate affects glutamate and GABA neurotransmitter systems, but its alcohol-related action is unclear.

Option D: Disulfiram inhibits the intermediate metabolism of alcohol which causes a build-up of acetaldehyde and a reaction of flushing, sweating, nausea, and tachycardia if a patient drinks alcohol.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl complains that she has a feeling of obstruction in the nose while breathing. She has a history of frequent colds on exposure to dust. On examination, Cottle’s test is negative, and the given finding is seen. The mass does not disappear on blowing the nose. On probe testing, the mass feels soft, can be moved up and down, and does not bleed easily on probing. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of nasal obstruction in a young person with a history of allergic rhinitis along with the image showing a pink fleshy unilateral swelling in the nasal cavity is suggestive of antrochoanal polyp.

Antrochoanal polyp arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum near its accessory ostium, comes out of it, and grows in the choana and nasal cavities. 

It is usually single and unilateral which is more commonly seen in children and young adults. It has 3 parts namely:

  • Thin antral stalk,
  • Round and globular choanal part, and
  • Flat nasal part.

The clinical features include unilateral nasal obstruction, mucoid nasal discharge, and a hyponasal voice. It is soft and can be moved up and down with a probe.

Diagnosis is made by radiograph of the paranasal sinuses reveals opacity of the involved antrum. Non-contrast CT scan reveals the extent of the polyp.

Endoscopic sinus surgery is the treatment of choice. Recurrence is uncommon after the complete removal of the polyp.

Other options:

Option A: Angiofibroma leads to severe and recurrent epistaxis and bleeds easily on probing. 

Option B: Hypertrophied turbinate feels firm on probe testing and cannot be moved up and down on probing.

Option C: Ethmoidal polyps are usually bilateral. They occur in adults.

Related Pearl: Antrochoanal Polyp

  • Main etiological factors: Infection and allergy
  • Usually affects children
  • Site of origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum
  • Clinical features:
    • Usually single and unilateral
    • Unilateral nasal obstruction which becomes bilateral when it grows posteriorly and obstructs opposite choana
    • Mucoid nasal discharge
    • Hyponasal voice
  • Findings:
    • Grows posteriorly and usually missed on anterior rhinoscopy
    • Posterior rhinoscopy: Globular mass filling the choana or nasopharynx
  • Investigation: Nasal endoscopy: Shows nasal polyps that are pale, gelatinous and pedunculated. NonContrast CT scan: Gives exquisite bony detail of the paranasal sinus anatomy. It is the primary diagnostic imaging modality.
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

Related Pearl: Ethmoidal polyps

  • Main etiological factor is allergy
  • Usually affects the middle-aged
  • Site of origin: Lateral wall of the nose
  • Clinical features: Nasal stuffiness, headache (due to sinusitis), sneezing, watery nasal discharge, anosmia/ hyposmia, mass protruding from the nasal cavity
  • Findings:
    • Anterior rhinoscopy: Multiple, bilateral polypi that are smooth, glistening, grape-like masses often pale in color
    • They may be sessile or pedunculated, insensitive to probing and do not bleed on touch
  • Investigation of choice: NCCT
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text:
After an earthquake, several casualties are received at the emergency department. One of these patients presents with multiple rib fractures. On examination, her neck veins are distended, and her heart sounds are muffled. An eFAST revealed fluid in the pericardial sac. Which color is assigned to the patient according to the triage color coding?

(eFAST - Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma)
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with rib fractures, neck vein distension, muffled heart sounds, and eFAST showing fluid in the pericardial cavity is indicative of cardiac tamponade. It is classified as red according to the triage color coding.

Triage is used to classify the priority of treatment. It is carried out at the site of the disaster to determine the priority for immediate medical attention, transportation, and admission to the hospital.

The internationally accepted four-color coded system is used commonly.

 

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: An 18-year-old male patient presents with the findings shown below, which he says occur recurrently. He also has similar lesions on his scrotum and complains of redness and pain in his eyes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this young man with recurrent oral and genital ulcers, as well as eye involvement, is Behcet's syndrome.

Behcet's syndrome is a vasculitic disorder that presents with recurrent oral and genital ulcerations and ocular involvement. It is a multisystem inflammatory disorder with a known association with HLA B*51. 

This syndrome commonly presents in young people, with males having more severe disease. These patients present with recurrent oral aphthous ulcers that are usually small and painful, painful genital ulcers, skin lesions (folliculitis, erythema nodosum, positive pathergy test, etc.), uveitis, arthritis/arthralgia, deep vein thromboses, etc.

To diagnose a patient with this condition, they must present with recurrent oral ulceration in addition to 2 of the following - genital ulcers/ocular involvement/skin lesions/positive pathergy test.

Topical glucocorticoids can be used to manage oral and skin lesions, but ocular involvement can often only be managed with intravenous steroids, azathioprine, and cyclosporine. 

Other options-

Option (A): Cogan's syndrome characteristically presents with interstitial keratitis and hearing loss. Hence, eye involvement is common, but oral and genital ulceration are not usually seen.

Option (B): Sjögren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that occurs due to the infiltration of lymphocytes into exocrine glands. This results in dry eyes and a dry gritty sensation in the mouth. However, recurrent oral and genital ulceration is not a common feature of this disease. 

Option (D): SAPHO syndrome is characterized by synovitis, acne, pustulosis, hyperostosis, and osteitis (SAPHO) and can present with various skin and musculoskeletal manifestations. Oral and genital ulceration is uncommon.

Related Pearl: HLA association with diseases

Autoimmune Gut and Skin Diseases and HLA associations
Gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease) DQ2 , DQ8
Chronic active hepatitis DR3
Dermatitis herpetiformis DR3
SLE(white) DR3
Sjogren’s syndrome DR3
Psoriasis vulgaris Cw6
Pemphigus vulgaris DR4, DQ1
Bullous pemphigoid variant DQ7
Autoimmune Endocrine Diseases and HLA associations  
Type 1 diabetes mellitus DQ8, DR4, DR3, DR2
Hyperthyroidism (Graves’) B8, DR3
Hyperthyroidism (Japanese) B35
Adrenal insufficiency DR3
Autoimmune Neurologic Diseases and HLA associations  
Myasthenia gravis B8
Multiple sclerosis B16, DR2
 Other Important Diseases and their HLA Associations  

Ankylosing Spondylitis

Reactive Arthritis

Psoriatic Arthritis

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia B47

Abacavir hypersensitivity B57 (B*57:01)

Related Pearl: Primary Forms of Vasculitis with Sites of Involvement

  Giant cell arteritis

Small-sized arteries - + + + + + +

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient came for a routine check-up. An electrocardiogram was done, which is given below. What is the most probable finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
First-degree heart block is the most probable finding in the given electrocardiogram (ECG).

The ECG image shows a prolongation of the PR interval by >0.20 seconds, which is indicative of first-degree heart block.

First-degree heart block is the abnormal slowing of the conduction through the atrioventricular node. It is characterized by a prolonged PR interval >0.20 seconds without disrupting the atrial and ventricular conduction. The normal PR interval is from 0.12 seconds to 0.20 seconds. 

Some of the common causes of first-degree heart blocks are coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, infections, electrolyte abnormalities, drugs, and collagen vascular diseases. Most of the patients are usually asymptomatic and are diagnosed incidentally. In high-grade first-degree heart block (PR interval >0.30 seconds), patients develop symptoms like dyspnea, chest pain, or syncope.

For the majority of patients with first-degree AV block, there is no need for treatment. In patients with a PR interval greater than 0.30 seconds, who are experiencing symptoms believed to be due to the AV block, pacemaker placement may be required. In patients with AV block related to myocardial infarction (MI), pacemaker placement may be indicated.

Other options:

Option B- Type I Mobitz (Wenckebach) block is a subtype of second-degree heart block. It is characterized by progressive prolongation of the PR interval, shortening of the RR interval, and a pause (dropped beat) that is less than 2 times the immediately preceding RR interval. The shortest PR interval occurs after the pause and the longest PR interval occurs before the pause.

The below image shows the type I Mobitz heart block.

Option C- Type II Mobitz block is also a subtype of second-degree heart block. It is characterized by an intermittent failure of P wave conduction without any change in the preceding impulses. There is no progressive prolongation of PR interval like in type I Mobitz block. 

The below image shows the type II Mobitz block.

Option D- Complete heart block/third-degree heart block is the complete failure of conduction from the atrium to the ventricles. It is characterized by no relationship between the P wave and QRS complex, P waves more than QRS complexes, and equal RR and PR intervals. A junctional or ventricular escape rhythm maintains the ventricular conduction.

The below image shows the complete heart block.

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of blood in her urine. She informs you that this happens every month for 1 week and stops on its own. She underwent a C-section 1 year ago and has no history of incontinence. During clinical examination, a catheter is inserted into the bladder, and the following finding is seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the catheter emerging from the cervical os. This, along with the history of cyclical hematuria, is suggestive of Youssef syndrome seen in a case of vesicouterine fistula.

Vesicouterine fistulas can develop after cesarean section, uterine rupture, and placenta accreta. Most cases present weeks to years later.

Vesicouterine fistulas can present with cyclical hematuria, urinary incontinence or complete continence, menstrual abnormalities, and urinary tract infections. Youssef syndrome is seen in cases of vesicouterine fistulas, and it is associated with a classic triad:

  • Amenorrhea
  • Cyclical hematuria - also called menouria: Menstrual blood trickles into the bladder through the fistula, causing hematuria
  • Urinary continence (there is no vaginal leakage of urine)

Hysteroscopy and cystoscopy are gold-standard investigations. 

Vesicouterine fistulas are treated as follows: 

  • Prolonged bladder catheterization - leads to spontaneous closure
  • Surgical repair via abdominal route

questions.text: The image below shows X-rays of a patient with chronic osteomyelitis. The structure marked as ‘3’ in the given image denotes _______.
questions.solution:
The structure marked as '3' in the given image denotes sequestrum. Sequestrum is a piece of devitalized bone that has been separated from its surrounding bone during the process of necrosis.

In the given image, the marked structures are as follows:

  1. Involucrum is the thick sheath of periosteal new bone that surrounds the sequestrum. 
  2. Cloacae are openings in the involucrum that allow drainage of purulent and necrotic material out of the dead bone.
  3. Sequestrum is a piece of devitalized bone that has been separated from its surrounding bone during the process of necrosis.

questions.text: An intern, during his medicine postings, was asked to calculate the cardiac index of a patient whose heart rate is 80 beats/min and respiratory rate is 20/min. The patient's heart was able to pump 75 mL of blood from each ventricle per heartbeat and the body surface area was determined to be 1.5 sq. meters. What would be the value of the calculated cardiac index?
questions.solution:
The cardiac index is the cardiac output per minute per square meter of the body surface. It would be 4 L/min/m2. 

Cardiac index = Cardiac output/body surface area

Cardiac output is given as follows:

Cardiac output = heart rate X stroke volume.

The stroke volume is the amount of blood pumped out of each ventricle per beat (i.e. 75 mL in the given question) and heart rate is given as 80 beats/min.

Cardiac Output = heart rate X stroke volume = 80 X 75 mL = 6 L/min

Therefore, cardiac index = 6 L/min/1.5 m2 = 4 L/min/m2 

It has been observed that cardiac output increases proportionally with an increase in body surface area. Hence, cardiac output is frequently expressed in terms of cardiac index.

Related Pearl: Cardiac pressure - volume loop

The volume-pressure curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure(Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

Phase I: Period of filling (between A and B)

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction (between B and C)

Phase III: Period of ejection (between C and D)

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation (between D and A)

where,

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

questions.text: The Sengstaken-Blakemore tube used in the management of bleeding esophageal varices consists of all of the following, except ______.
questions.solution:
The Sengstaken-Blakemore tube consists of 3 channels the esophageal balloon channel, a gastric balloon channel, and a gastric aspiration channel.

The gastric balloon is inflated and tension is applied to the gastroesophageal junction. If this does not control the hemorrhage, the esophageal balloon is inflated as well, compressing the lower oesophageal venous plexus between them. Only gastric contents can be aspirated.

Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is thus used to provide mechanical tamponade for temporary stoppage of bleeding in acute variceal bleed setting.

Linton-Nachlas tube has only two ports and a single gastric balloon. 

The Minnesota tube has 4 openings:

  • Two suction tubes:
    • Gastric aspiration port
    • Esophageal aspiration port
  • Two inflation tubes:
    • Gastric balloon port
    • Esophageal balloon port

This tube allows the aspiration of both gastric and oesophageal contents.

Below is the image of the Minnesota tube.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman delivered a healthy baby at 38 weeks of gestation. Twenty minutes later, the mother developed severe shortness of breath and appeared cyanotic. Her ECG and chest x-ray showed no abnormality. Despite resuscitation, she died after a few hours. Her laboratory reports revealed the following findings. What is the most probable diagnosis?
Platelets Low
Fibrinogen Low
Thrombin time Increased
Prothrombin time Increased
Partial thromboplastin time Increased
Fibrin degradation products Increased
questions.solution:
The laboratory test results point to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The most probable diagnosis with the given clinical scenario and laboratory values is amniotic fluid embolism. It presents during the late stages of labor or immediate postpartum (peripartum period).

Currently, amniotic fluid embolism is widely believed to be caused by the entry of fetal material into the maternal circulation. The tissue factor present in fetal material activates factor VII, resulting in DIC. The fetal material leads to the activation of proinflammatory mediator systems.

Risk factors include rapid labor, meconium-stained liquor, cesarean delivery, placenta previa, eclampsia, placental abruption, polyhydramnios, uterine tears, post-term pregnancy, and advanced maternal age.

Amniotic fluid embolism is a clinical diagnosis and the diagnostic criteria include the following:

  • Sudden-onset cardiorespiratory arrest, or both hypotension and respiratory compromise
  • Overt DIC
  • Onset during labor or within 30 minutes of delivery of the placenta.
  • No fever (≥38°C)

Differential diagnoses including myocardial infarction, pulmonary embolism, and anaphylactic shock need to be ruled out. 

The condition can be fatal and management includes cardiopulmonary resuscitation and advanced cardiac life support. Intubation may be required. Inotropes and vasopressors may be used to maintain cardiac output and blood pressure.

Autopsy findings will show the presence of squamous cells shed from the fetal skin, lanugo hair, fat from vernix caseosa, and mucin derived from the fetal respiratory or gastrointestinal tract in the maternal pulmonary microvasculature.

Other options-

Option A: Preeclampsia is characterized by the development of hypertension to the extent of 140/90 mmHg or more with proteinuria, after the 20th week of gestation, in a previously normotensive and non-proteinuric woman. Pre-eclampsia causes endothelial injury which in turn leads to DIC.

Option B: Tension pneumothorax can be a possible diagnosis with the patient's clinical symptoms. But a normal chest x-ray would make this diagnosis unlikely. 

Option C: Bacterial sepsis leads to endothelial injury and release of phospholipids, which in turn leads to DIC. The tissue factor that is released in response to cytokines (IL-1), tumor necrosis factor, and endotoxin. The tissue factor activates the extrinsic pathway, leading to coagulopathy. Given the patient's history, an amniotic fluid embolism is more likely. 

Related Pearl: Causes of Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acute, subacute, or chronic thrombohemorrhagic disorder occurring as a secondary complication in a variety of diseases. It is characterized by the activation of the coagulation sequence that leads to the formation of microthrombi throughout the microcirculation of the body. As a consequence of the thrombotic diathesis, there is a consumption of platelets, fibrin, and coagulation factors and, secondarily, activation of fibrinolytic mechanisms.

Causes of DIC:

Obstetric complications
  • Abruptio placenta
  • Retained dead fetus
  • Septic abortion
  • Amniotic fluid embolism
  • Toxemia
Infections
  • Sepsis
  • Meningococcemia
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Aspergillosis
  • Malaria
  • Toxemia 
Neoplasms
  • Ca. pancreas
  • Ca. prostate
  • Ca. lung
  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia
Massive Tissue Injury
  • Traumatic injury
  • Burns
  • Extensive surgery
Miscellaneous
  • Acute intravascular hemolysis
  • Snake bite
  • Shock
  • Stroke
  • Vasculitis
  • Aortic aneurysm
  • Liver disease

Related Pearl: Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

 Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

Parameter Uses
Prothrombin Time (PT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the extrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal PT is 11–13 seconds.
Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the intrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal aPTT is 25–35 seconds. A relatively rare cause of prolonged aPTT is the presence of antibodies against coagulation plasma proteins called inhibitors. It can be seen due to the following reasons: Hemophilia A and B patients receiving clotting factors to control their bleeding episodes, Pregnancy, Autoimmune diseases, Malignancies (lymphoma, prostate cancer), and Dermatologic conditions.
Thrombin time (TT) It is used for testing the conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin and depends on adequate fibrinogen levels. 
Bleeding time (BT) It is the time taken for a standardized skin puncture to stop bleeding. It tests the ability of blood vessels to constrict and platelets to form a hemostatic plug. 
Fibrin degradation products (FDPs) They are used to assess the fibrinolytic activity, and they are increased in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

questions.text: A multiparous woman presents at 36 weeks of gestation. On examination, fundal height is less than the period of amenorrhea. In the fundal grip, the fetal pole is not palpable and in the pelvic grip, the lower pole of the uterus is empty. On the lateral grip, a soft, irregular breech is felt on one side of the midline. Identify the most common fetal position in the given presentation?
questions.solution:
The given examination findings are suggestive of a transverse lie. The most common fetal position in a transverse lie is dorso-anterior.

Transverse lie occurs when the long axis of the fetus lies perpendicularly to the maternal spine or centralized uterine axis.

The position of the fetus in a transverse lie is determined by the direction of the back, which is the denominator. The position may be:

  • Dorsoanterior, which is the most common. (60%)
  • Dorsoposterior, where the chance of fetal extension is common with increased risk of arm prolapse
  • Dorsosuperior 
  • Dorsoinferior

According to the position of the head, the fetal position is termed right or left, the left one being more common.

Abdominal examination findings:

On inspection, the uterus looks broader and is often asymmetrical. It does not maintain the pyriform shape.

Palpation:

  • Fundal height is less than the period of amenorrhea.
  • Fundal grip: Fetal pole (breech or head) is not palpable.
  • Lateral grip: A smooth, hard, and globular head is felt on one side. A soft, broad, and irregular breech is felt on the other side.
    • In dorso-anterior: The back is felt anteriorly across the long axis 
    • In dorso-posterior: Irregular small parts are felt anteriorly
  • Pelvic grip: The lower pole of the uterus is empty.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman presents with a sudden onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath for 1 day. A chest radiograph reveals a moderate pleural effusion. Thoracocentesis is performed and results are given below. What is the most likely cause of pleural effusion in this patient?
  • Pleural fluid protein/serum protein ratio: 0.6
  • Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH ratio: 0.6
  • Pleural fluid glucose: 65 mg/dL
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the pleural effusion in the setting of acute breathlessness and chest pain that meets the criteria for exudative pleural effusion, along with pleural fluid glucose levels above 60 mg/dL. is likely to be due to pulmonary embolism.

The effusion in pulmonary embolism is a result of increased pulmonary capillary permeability leading to interstitial fluid moving from the lung to the pleural space by crossing the visceral pleura. The increased permeability is caused by the release of inflammatory mediators from clots that are rich in platelets. 

Transudative and exudative pleural effusions are distinguished by measuring the lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and protein levels in the pleural fluid. Exudative pleural effusions meet at least one of the following criteria, whereas transudative pleural effusions meet none:

  • Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5
  • Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6
  • Pleural fluid LDH more than two-thirds of the normal upper limit for serum

Also if the difference between the protein levels in the serum and the pleural fluid is >3.1 g/dL, it is likely to be transudative pleural effusion.

If the fluid appears to be exudate, then pleural fluid glucose levels can help in identifying the etiology. If the glucose levels are less than 60 mg/dL, then the effusion is likely due to malignancy, parapneumonic effusion (bacterial infection), and rheumatoid pleuritis.

Examples of transudative pleural effusions are effusions due to congestive heart failure, cirrhosis, and nephrosis. Exudative pleural effusions are caused by malignancies, bacterial infections, rheumatoid pleuritis, and pulmonary embolism.

If the pleural fluid cytology, culture, glucose, and staining do not yield any result, perform spiral CT to rule out pulmonary embolism and assess the markers of tuberculosis.

Other options:

Option A and C : Congestive heart failure and cirrhosis are examples of transudative pleural effusion.

Option B: Although this patient's exudative effusion may be parapneumonic, the absence of fever, sudden onset of symptoms, chest x-ray without consolidation, and normal pleural fluid glucose make bacterial infection a less likely cause.

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure (most common)
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Myxedema 
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Urinothorax
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Infections: Tuberculosis, pneumonia, intraabdominal abscess (like- liver abscess)
  • Malignancy: Pleural mesothelioma, metastasis, lymphoma
  • Connective tissue diseases: SLE, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Drugs: Amiodarone, bromocriptine, dantrolene, dasatinib, methysergide, nitrofurantoin
  • Others:
    • Pancreatitis
    • Asbestosis
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Hemothorax
    • Chylothorax
    • Meigs' syndrome 
    • Dressler syndrome (post-myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery)
    • Yellow nail syndrome

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, diagnosed with bipolar disorder is under treatment with lithium for the past 2 months. She now presents with excessive thirst and frequent urination and a diagnosis of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus was made. The administration of desmopressin did not increase the specific gravity of urine. Which is the most appropriate treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate treatment for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI) is amiloride.

Lithium is a mood stabilizer with a very narrow therapeutic index hence regular determination of serum concentrations is important. Its use is approved by FDA in acute mania and the prevention of recurrences of bipolar illness in adults or adolescents.

Important side effects of lithium are-

  • Fine tremors in therapeutic dose
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Hypothyroidism
  • T wave flattening
  • CNS toxicity manifests as coarse tremors, giddiness, ataxia, motor incoordination, nystagmus, mental confusion, slurred speech, and hyperreflexia.

The development of NDI is related to the accumulation of Li+ in distal tubular cells and subsequent inhibition of GSK-3β, leading to vasopressin insensitivity and downregulation of aquaporin-2 channels. Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that blocks entry of Li+ into collecting duct cells and thus can be used to treat lithium-induced NDI.

Other options:

Option A: Thiazide diuretics may also lead to lithium toxicity. Lithium competes with sodium for reabsorption. Diuresis leads to Na+ loss and compensatory sodium as well as lithium reabsorption from the proximal tubule, leading to toxicity.

Option C: Furosemide is a loop diuretic. It acts by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle resulting in increased excretion of sodium, potassium, and chloride. Thiazide diuretics also lead to lithium toxicity.

Option D: Chlorpropamide is a long-acting oral sulfonylurea preferred for central diabetes insipidus owing to its enhancing action on circulating vasopressin.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient with a history of chronic ear pain and ear discharge presents with fever, headache, vomiting, irritability, and confusion. His CT brain is shown in the image below. Which of the following drugs is not useful in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with the given CT image points to a diagnosis of a temporal lobe abscess that is most likely to have developed as an intracranial complication of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM).  Intravenous antibiotic metronidazole is administered. Raised ICP is treated with dexamethasone or mannitol.

Brain abscess has 4 stages:

  • Stage of invasion (initial encephalitis): This stage usually passes unnoticed. Headache, malaise, low-grade fever, and drowsiness are seen.
  • Stage of localization (latent abscess): This is an asymptomatic stage, usually lasting for several weeks. A capsule is formed to localize the pus. 
  • Stage of enlargement (manifest abscess). Enlargement of the abscess (leading to raised intracranial pressure) and the formation of a zone of edema around the abscess lead to an aggravation of symptoms.
  • Stage of termination (rupture of abscess). The abscess expands and ruptures into the ventricle or subarachnoid space resulting in fatal meningitis.

Signs of raised intracranial pressure are headache, nausea, vomiting, lethargy, drowsiness, confusion, papilledema, and coma. 

Characteristic findings of temporal lobe abscess are nominal aphasia, homonymous hemianopia, epileptic fits, contralateral motor paralysis, pupillary changes, and oculomotor palsy. 

CT brain is the investigation of choice. Brain abscess is seen as a ring-enhancing lesion in imaging studies.  

Management:

  • Medical:  Intravenous antibiotics (usually metronidazole) are started. Raised intracranial pressure is treated with dexamethasone or mannitol.
  • Surgical: Abscess drainage of the temporal lobe abscess followed by radical mastoidectomy for CSOM is the definitive management in such cases.

questions.text: A  primigravida was brought to the emergency department with the sudden onset of fever, altered mental status, confusion, and petechiae over both lower limbs. She has no history of similar episodes. Laboratory reports revealed thrombocytopenia, anaemia, features of acute kidney injury, and antibodies to ADAMTS13. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a primigravida who presents with sudden onset of fever, neurologic abnormalities(altered mental status, confusion), thrombocytopenia (petechiae over lower limbs), hemolytic anaemia, acute kidney injury and antibodies to  ADAMTS13 suggests the diagnosis of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).  

TTP is a thrombotic microangiopathy that can be inherited or spontaneously acquired. It results from a deficiency of, or antibodies to, the metalloprotease ADAMTS13, which normally cleaves multimers of vWF. Failure to cleave these multimers results in abnormally large vWF multimers which activate platelets and lead to excessive platelet adhesion and aggregation. This causes platelet thrombi to form, and fibrin deposits to take place at various sites. These thrombi result in the classic pentad of clinical features: 

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Renal failure
  • Neurologic findings
  • Fever

The platelet thrombi narrow the vessel lumen, causing shearing stress on the red blood cells that are passing through. This results in microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia. The same platelet thrombi cause microvascular occlusion and result in features like renal failure and neurological manifestations.

On peripheral smear, these fragmented red cells appear as schistocytes or helmet cells, as shown in the image below:

 

Timely diagnosis is important to prevent devastating outcomes like profuse bleeding and renal failure. The best method to treat these patients is using plasma exchange therapy. It should be continued until the platelet counts are back to normal and there are no signs of hemolysis for at least 2 days. Glucocorticoids can also be used along with this therapy. In refractory cases, rituximab, and caplacizumab an antiVWF nanobody decreases mortality when used in patients with ADAMTS13 <10%.

Other causes of microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia include:

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) (Most common)
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)
  • Malignant hypertension
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Disseminated cancer 

Other options-

Option (A): Immune thrombocytopenic purpura occurs as a chronic disease in adults with several episodes over time, usually following infections. It presents as mucocutaneous bleeding and very low platelet counts. These patients have otherwise normal peripheral blood pictures.

Option (B): Disseminated intravascular coagulation refers to the widespread intravascular clot formation, commonly due to sepsis, trauma, and obstetric complications. These patients present with petechiae, ecchymoses, oozing from venipuncture sites, etc. They do not display the classic pentad seen in TTP. Schistocytes may be present on peripheral smear. Deranged clotting parameters are seen only in DIC and not in TTP.

Option (C): Hemolytic uremic syndrome is a disorder seen predominantly in children, following an episode of bloody diarrhea. Escherichia coli O157:H7 is most commonly the cause of this diarrhea. It can also present with acute renal failure, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia, but neurological manifestations are less common. ADAMTS13 levels are normal in a majority of patients. It can be low in some rare cases.

Related Pearl: Differences between TTP and HUS

questions.text: A woman presents with anxiety and nightmares. These symptoms started when she and her family were shifted to a rehabilitation camp when their city was hit by an earthquake 4 months ago. She did not accompany her family when they went back to look for their lost belongings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts a stress reaction (nightmares, avoidance) to a traumatic event for a period of 4 months. This indicates a diagnosis of post-traumatic stress disorder.

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a psychiatric disorder characterized by increased stress and anxiety occurring after a stressful or traumatic event (e.g., witnessing or being involved in violent accidents, crime, war, assault, kidnapping, natural disaster, life-threatening illness, physical or sexual abuse). 

The predisposing factors for this condition include:

  • Presence of childhood trauma
  • Borderline, paranoid, dependent, or antisocial personality disorder traits
  • Inadequate family or peer support system
  • Female gender
  • Genetic susceptibility to psychiatric illness
  • Recent stressful life changes
  • Recent excessive intake of alcohol

Symptoms of PTSD can be divided into four types:

  • Intrusion symptoms
    • Flashbacks- The individual may act and feel as if the traumatic event is reoccurring 
    • Nightmares of the event
  • Hyperarousal 
    • Increased startle response
    • Insomnia
    • Hypervigilance
    • Difficulty concentrating
    • Reckless and self-destructive behavior
    • Irritability and anxiety
  • Avoidance symptoms:  
    • avoiding memories, thoughts, and feelings of the event
    • avoiding external reminders of the traumatic event
  • Negative cognitions and mood associated with the traumatic event
    • Inability to remember an important aspect of the traumatic event
    • Feelings of depersonalization and derealization
    • Anhedonia
    • Negative emotional state- fear, horror, anger, guilt, or shame

The duration of these symptoms should be >1 month to label it as PTSD.

Based on the duration between the event and the presentation of symptoms, stress disorder is classified as follows.

Duration Condition
3 days to 1 month Acute stress reaction
More than 1 month Post-traumatic stress disorder
Symptoms occur after 6 months Delayed Post-traumatic stress disorder

Psychotherapies that are effective for PTSD include exposure therapy, trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy, eye movement desensitization, and abreaction. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) may be prescribed as first-line treatment.

Other option:

Adjustment disorder is an emotional response to a stressful event such as the loss of a job, divorce, moving to a new environment, financial problems, medical illnesses, or the death of a loved one. Most patients are able to return to their previous level of functioning within 3 months. 

Diagnostic criteria for adjustment disorder include:

  • Development of emotional or behavioral response within 3 months of the onset of the stressor
  • The symptoms or behavior are clinically significant, where, any one of the following are met - 
    • The response is out of proportion to the severity or intensity of the stressor
    • Significant impairment in social, occupational, or other areas of functioning
  • Stress-related disturbance does not meet the criteria for another mental disorder or exacerbation of pre-existing mental disorder
  • The symptoms do not represent normal bereavement
  • Once the stressor is terminated, the symptoms do not persist for more than 6 additional months.

The mainstay of treatment is psychotherapy. 

 

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of Trauma and Stress related disorder

 
PTSD
Adjustment disorder
Bereavement

Financial/ Illness/ Relationship issues

Symptoms

questions.text: A child presented with swelling of the wrist joint. She also had perifollicular hemorrhages and ecchymosis around hair follicles. Bleeding gums were seen on examination. An x-ray of her wrist is shown below. Identify the marked sign.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of scurvy and the sign marked by the arrow is Wimberger's sign. It is a ring-shaped outline of the epiphysis.

Dietary deficiency of vitamin C leads to scurvy. It is common between 6 and 9 months of age. Defective osteoid production by osteoblasts with reduced endochondral bone ossification is likely to be the cause of the condition.

Clinical features include bleeding into the skin which includes petechiae, ecchymosis, perifollicular hemorrhages, bleeding into joints, and bleeding gums which are mainly due to the impaired formation of connective tissue.

Radiological features:

  • Trummerfeld zone

  • Frankel's line - an increased density at the metaphyseal ends (Option D)

  • Pelcan's spur - seen in the metaphysis and is prone to fracture (Option B), and

  • Wimberger's sign - a pencil-shaped outline seen in the epiphysis. (Option A).

Treatment includes supplementation of vitamin C (200 mg/day).

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

Related Pearl: Important differences between vitamin D and vitamin C deficiencies

 
Vitamin D     deficiency  
Vitamin C     deficiency
Pathology Poor mineralization of bone Poor osteoid          formation
Clinical features

No/less irritability

Rachitic rosary (nodularity at the costochondral junction)

Irritability is predominant

Scorbutic rosary (angular & sharp costochondral junction)
Radiological features

Cupping 

Fraying

Splaying

White line of Frankel

Pelkan spur

Wimberger ring sign

Subperiosteal hemorrhage

Note: Irritability in scurvy is due to hampered neurotransmitter production (conversion of dopamine to norepinephrine and tryptophan to serotonin requires vitamin C).

questions.text: Mid-upper arm circumference measurement was done to assess the nutritional status among young children. Based on a cut-off value of 11.5 cm, they are categorized into those with or without severe acute malnutrition. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate test of significance in this case is the chi-square test.

In this scenario, the cut-off of 11.5 cm is used to categorize children into those with severe malnourishment and those without (nominal data). Hence, the chi-square test is appropriate in this case.

The chi-square test (χ2) is a non-parametric (non-numeric) test used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

Other options:

Option B: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. If a study were to compare the blood pressure in a group of patients before and after treatment, then paired t-test would be used.

Option C: The independent t-test, or the unpaired t-test, is a statistical test that determines whether there is a statistically significant difference between the means in two unrelated (independent) groups. A comparison of BMI between males and females in a population is an example of an unpaired t-test.

Option D: Analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to compare the mean/average of three or more groups.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: With respect to congenital heart diseases and chest x-rays, which of the following pairs is correct?

choices.text: Transposition of great arteries - egg on side appearance
Tetralogy of Fallot - box shaped heart
Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation - gooseneck sign

questions.solution:
The correct pair is TGA - Egg on side or egg on string appearance.

In the transposition of great arteries, the heart appears globular (like an egg) due to an abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement. The superior mediastinum appears narrow which gives the appearance of an egg-on-a-string. 

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with thyroid swelling. Blood tests show elevated TSH levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies. The histopathological image is given below. Identify the correct statement regarding this condition.

choices.text: Associated with extranodal marginal zone B-cell lymphoma in the thyroid gland
Characteristic Orphan Annie Eye nuclei seen
Neutrophilic infiltration seen in the thyroid

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario with the presence of Hurthle cells is suggestive of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. The correct statement regarding this condition is option A.

It is an autoimmune disease, characterized by the gradual destruction of the thyroid gland leading to thyroid failure. It is commonly seen in women between 45 to 65 years of age. It is caused by the presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase.

Morphologically, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. It is well-demarcated from the adjacent structures.

Microscopic features include:

  • Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well-developed germinal centers (option D)
  • Atrophied thyroid follicles 
  • The epithelial cells lining the follicles contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm. These cells are called Hurthle cells. They represent the metaplastic response of the normally low cuboidal follicular epithelium to chronic injury.
 

Clinical features include painless enlargement of the thyroid which is generally symmetric and diffuse. Typically, hypothyroidism develops gradually. In some patients, however, it may be preceded by transient thyrotoxicosis caused by disruption of thyroid follicles and release of thyroid hormones.

Individuals with Hashimoto's thyroiditis are at increased risk for the development of extranodal marginal zone B-cell lymphoma within the thyroid gland. They are also at increased risk for developing other autoimmune diseases, both endocrine (type 1 diabetes, autoimmune adrenalitis) and non-endocrine (systemic lupus erythematosus, myasthenia gravis, and Sjögren syndrome).

Characteristic Orphan Annie Eye nuclei (Option B) and Psammoma bodies (Option C) are seen in Papillary carcinoma. Some molecular studies suggest that Hashimoto's thyroiditis predisposes to papillary carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Antibodies seen in some autoimmune thyroid disorders

Antibody Disorder
TSH receptor-stimulating Immunoglobulins (TSI) Graves disease
Anti TPO & Anti Tg antibodies Chronic lymphocytic(Hashimoto) thyroiditis

TRBAb

(maternal transmission)

 Transient congenital hypothyroidism (maternal autoimmune thyroid disease)
  • Anti TPO – Anti thyroperoxidase antibody
  • Anti Tg – Antithyroglobulin antibody
  • TRBAb – TSH receptor blocking antibodies

questions.text: A 3-hour-old neonate with apnea has been on bag and mask ventilation for the last 30 seconds. She has now started taking spontaneous breaths. The heart rate is still at 100–110/min. What is your next step?
questions.solution:
As per the NRP algorithm, at any time during resuscitation, if the HR > 100 and spontaneous breathing resumes then discontinue ventilation.

The components of NRP resuscitation include the following: (TABCD)

  • Temperature- maintain between 36.5 and 37.5oC
  • Airway- "sniffing" position, clear secretions if needed
  • Breathing- tactile stimulation, PPV (40–60 breaths/min), ETT
  • Circulation- chest compressions:ventilation ratio (3:1 = 90:30; lower 1/3rd sternum; two thumb technique preferred)
  • Drugs- Epinephrine, volume expanders 

Algorithm states:

  • HR <100/min + no respirations →  Positive pressure ventilation (PPV)
  • No response with PPV → Endotracheal intubation (ET)
  • HR <60/min → Chest compressions
  • No response to chest compressions → Epinephrine

questions.text: A child presents with palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, and pain in the knee joint resulting from arthritis. Urine examination showed hematuria and proteinuria. Which of the following finding is most likely present in the patient?

choices.text: IgA deposition in the mesangial region

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the investigations are suggestive of Henoch-Schönlein purpura. IgA deposition in the mesangial region is most likely finding to be present in this patient.

Henoch-Schönlein purpura is a subtype of acute leukocytoclastic vasculitis that is seen more commonly in children and adolescents following an upper respiratory infection. The patient may present with the following clinical features:

  • Skin lesions- characteristically involve the extensor surfaces of arms and legs, and also the buttocks
  • Abdominal manifestations- include pain, vomiting, and intestinal bleeding
  • Arthralgias- primarily of the knees and ankles
  • Renal manifestations- include gross or microscopic hematuria, nephritic syndrome, or nephrotic syndrome. Renal manifestations are more severe in adults. A rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis is seen in some cases.

Microscopic findings:

  • IgA deposition in the mesangial region is the pathognomic feature. Sometimes there is the deposition of IgG and C3 along with IgA.
  • Renal lesions show focal or diffuse mesangial proliferation, and/or endocapillary proliferation to crescentic glomerulonephritis.
  • Skin lesions show subepidermal hemorrhages and necrotizing vasculitis of small vessels. Direct immunofluorescence examination shows deposits of IgA within dermal blood vessel walls.

Other options:

Option A: Alport syndrome is caused by mutations that affect type IV collagen that results in hematuria with progression to chronic renal failure. It is accompanied by nerve deafness and various eye disorders, including lens dislocation, posterior cataracts and corneal dystrophy.

Option B: Microscopic polyangiitis is a necrotizing vasculitis that affects capillaries, small arterioles, and venules. Most cases are associated with MPO-ANCA. The features include hemoptysis, hematuria and proteinuria, bowel pain or bleeding, muscle pain or weakness, and palpable cutaneous purpura.

Option C: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) occurs due to antibody-mediated destruction of platelets. Autoantibodies, most often directed against platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb–IIIa or Ib–IX are found. The patient can present with petechiae, ecchymoses, easy bruising, nosebleeds, and gingival bleeding. The disease manifests first with melena, hematuria, or excessive menstrual flow.

questions.text: The transmission cycle of an arbovirus is given below. Which of the following vaccine can prevent infection with this virus?
questions.solution:
The transmission cycle of the Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus is shown in the image. SA 14-14-2 vaccine is approved for use in India to prevent infection.

JE follows bird-arthropod-human transmission. Humans are the dead-end hosts, pigs are the amplifier hosts, and herons act as reservoir hosts. The disease is transmitted by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India).

Clinical features include high fever, headache, and vomiting. Signs of encephalitis such as convulsions, neck rigidity, and altered sensorium appear after 1-6 days. Measures like mosquito control, and locating piggeries away from houses can be done.

Vaccine:

  • Inactivated Vero cell culture-derived SA-14-14-2 vaccine is approved for use in India. JE vaccine is given in two doses- at 9-12 months of age and at 16-24 months of age in areas that are endemic to the disease, according to the National Immunization Schedule.
  • A formalin-inactivated mouse brain vaccine using the Nakayama strain has been used successfully for immunization. Two doses at two weeks intervals followed by a booster 6-12 months later constitute a full course. The immunity produced by the vaccine is short-lived.

Other options:

Option A: Weigl's vaccine is the earliest used vaccine against epidemic typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. Pediculus humanus corporis (human body louse) is the vector. Symptoms include fever and chills. A characteristic rash on the trunk and limbs, sparing the face, palms, and soles, may also be seen. 

Option B: 17D vaccine is a live-attenuated vaccine administered to prevent yellow fever. It is administered through the subcutaneous route. Vaccination is mandatory for travel to or from endemic areas.

Option D: Jeryl Lynn strain of the mumps virus is used against the disease as a live-attenuated vaccine. It is contraindicated in pregnancy and individuals allergic to eggs.

questions.text: A 30-year-old apparently healthy man developed abdominal pain at the airport. An x-ray was obtained, which is shown below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows multiple cylindrical capsules in the stomach and intestine, which are consistent with a diagnosis of body packer syndrome.

Body packers are individuals who swallow illegal drugs like heroin and cocaine with the purpose of smuggling. Usually, the drugs are carefully wrapped in latex or plastic and swallowed, to be excreted later with the help of laxatives.

Drugs are usually of similar radio-opacity as fecal material and may be difficult to detect on x-rays. CT scan may be done to aid in diagnosis.

The image below shows multiple cylindrical capsules in the stomach and intestine. 

A similar term is body stuffer syndrome, which refers to consumption or stuffing drugs in the rectum or vagina just when the person is apprehensive of being caught. Drug toxicity may be seen due to systemic absorption.

Other options:

Option A-  Bezoar formation is an indigestible mass due to the consumption of a variety of materials that were intentionally or accidentally ingested indigestible substances.

The image below shows a colonic bezoar due to the ingestion of box myrtle seeds.

Option B- Pica is eating non-nutritive, non-food substances like chalk, paper, ash, and mud over a period of at least one month in patients with iron-deficiency anemia.

Option D- Appendicolith is the accumulation of firm feces with mineral deposits. These deposits are seen incidentally in abdominal computed tomography without any signs of appendicitis. It may obstruct the appendix lumen, causing appendicitis, and is rarely found in patients with appendix inflammation.

The image below shows a CT of an appendicolith.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient has a right breast lump of size 4 cm and bilateral fixed axillary lymph nodes. What is the TNM staging of this breast lump?
questions.solution:
The TNM staging of the breast lump is T2N2M1.

  • A right breast lump of size 4 cm is categorized as T2
  • Presence of ipsilateral fixed axillary lymph node is categorized as N2a
  • Spread to the contralateral side, indicated by bilateral fixed axillary lymph nodes, is metastasis, which is M1.

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered a benign condition and not included under Tis.

Prefixes for TNM staging:

  • c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)
  • p: pathological (histological) staging
  • y: stage following systemic or radiation therapy (either prior to surgery or as a primary treatment)
  • r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

Suffix for TNM staging:

  • m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours

questions.text:
All of the following are virulence factors of Candida albicans, except ________.

ALS - agglutinin-like sequence
questions.solution:
All of the above are virulence factors of Candida albicans except glucuronoxylomannan (GXM).

GXM is the capsular polysaccharide of Cryptococcus. During infection, GXM is solubilized in spinal fluid, serum, or urine and can be detected by an enzyme immunoassay or by the agglutination of latex particles coated with antibodies to the polysaccharide. This test is diagnostic of cryptococcosis if done with proper control.

 The virulence factors of Candida albicans:

  • Agglutinin-like sequence (ALS) surface glycoproteins, that bind to the host cell membrane receptors and mediate attachment to the epithelial and endothelial cells.
  • Secreted aspartyl proteinases (SAPs), that degrade host cell membranes and destroy immunoglobulins.
  • Phospholipase (PLB1) is secreted by the yeasts and pseudohyphae.
  • Fungal biofilm, which is protected by the extracellular matrix material prevents the penetration of the host’s immune response and antifungal drugs.

Clinically, infection with candida can present as cutaneous and mucosal candidiasis, systemic candidiasis, and rarely, chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis. Cutaneous and mucosal infections manifest as thrush affecting the tongue, lips, gums, and palate. It is seen as a patchy to confluent, whitish pseudomembranous lesion and is commonly associated with AIDS. Candida may also invade the vaginal mucosa leading to vulvovaginitis, and the nails, and around the nail plate (onychomycosis).

Serum beta 1,3 glucan assay can be used in the diagnosis of systemic candidiasis. 

Given below is an image of oral thrush.
