questions.text: A 45-year-old patient complained of pain in one side of the neck. She is afraid of eating food as it worsens the pain. Ultrasound imaging of the salivary glands is done and shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of pain on one side of the neck that worsens with food and the ultrasound image showing a stone within Wharton's duct is suggestive of sialolithiasis (salivary gland stone).

The submandibular gland has highly viscous secretions and hence forms the most common site for salivary gland stone formation. The two most common sites of stone impaction are near the punctum and the hilum of the gland where the duct bends over the mylohyoid muscle. 

The patient usually presents with acute painful swelling in the submandibular region, which is aggravated with food intake. Symptoms resolve 1-2 hours after the meal is completed. On examination, a tender and enlarged submandibular gland can be noted on bimanual examination. Pus may be seen draining from the sublingual papilla or can be expressed on bimanual palpation of the gland. 

Most submandibular stones are radio-opaque and visible in radiographs. Stones of size <4 mm are removed via a dormia basket using endoscopic or ultrasound-guided methods under local anesthesia. Stones of size >4 mm are broken first using intracorporeal or extracorporeal lithotripsy and then removed using a dormia basket. 

Submandibular gland excision is done only when minimally invasive techniques have failed or there is evidence of a salivary gland tumor. 

Nerves at risk during the removal of the submandibular gland: 

  • the marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve 
  • the lingual nerve
  • the hypoglossal nerve

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with generalized body aches, fatigue, and anxiety for the past 4 months, but her sleep is not affected due to pain. On examination, increased pain sensitivity and tender bony prominences are noted. Laboratory and radiological investigations were normal. You suspect fibromyalgia in her. Which of the following drugs is preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
Duloxetine is preferred in fibromyalgia patients having pain along with fatigue and anxiety, as it has antidepressant action as well.

The examination findings of tender bony prominences (earlier considered as a part of the diagnostic evaluation) and increased pain sensitivity with associated low mood favor the diagnosis of fibromyalgia.

Fibromyalgia is characterized by chronic musculoskeletal pain and tenderness. Other symptoms include fatigue, depression, sleep disturbances, cognitive dysfunction, and anxiety. It is predominantly seen in females. 

Patients with fibromyalgia have an increased prevalence of other syndromes associated with pain and fatigue. This includes chronic fatigue syndrome, chronic headaches, irritable bowel syndrome, interstitial cystitis/painful bladder syndrome, and other pelvic pain syndromes. It is a diagnosis of exclusion.

Treatment strategies include physical conditioning, strength training, exercise programs, cognitive-behavioral strategies, and transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation (TENS) for movement-evoked pain and fatigue.

Pharmacotherapy with single agents to treat multiple symptom domains is recommended. Cyclobenzaprine, pregabalin, and sedating antidepressants like amitriptyline are used in fibromyalgia pain associated with sleep disturbances (Option A, B). However, in patients having pain associated with fatigue, anxiety, or depression, drugs that have both analgesic and antidepressant/anxiolytic effects, such as duloxetine or milnacipran, are used.

Option C: Glucocorticoids are not effective against fibromyalgia-related symptoms.

questions.text: A person is brought dead to the casualty and you notice certain eye changes, which are marked in the image below. The person has not been dead for more than 4 hours.  What is the shown postmortem change known as?
questions.solution:
The postmortem change shown in the given image is suggestive of tache noir, a black-colored deposit of cell debris and mucous on the sclera that occurs within 3-4 hours of death.  

Initially, yellow-colored triangles appear on either side of the cornea with the apex pointing towards the canthus. The color then progressively changes to brown and black, followed by wrinkling of the surface.

Other postmortem changes occurring in the eye:

  • Loss of corneal reflex
  • Flaccidity of eyeballs occurs due to a reduction in intraocular pressure (IOP). IOP reaches zero at the end of 2 hours after death.
  • Dilatation of the pupil due to relaxation of muscles of the iris
  • Increased potassium concentration in the vitreous up to 100 hours following death
  • Kevorkian sign (Option A) occurs due to fragmentation of blood column in the retinal vessels, which lasts for about 1 hour. It occurs due to the loss of blood pressure and can be seen only through an ophthalmoscope as shown below:

Other options

Option C- During the distribution of postmortem hypostasis, the pressure by collar bands, waistbands, belts, wrinkles in the clothes prevents the capillaries from filling due to gravity. Such areas remain free from stain and are seen as strips or bands called vibices. 

Option D- Tardieu spots are round, dark, and well-defined pinpoint petechial hemorrhages. They are seen in asphyxial deaths. This occurs due to the increased intravenous pressure, leading to the rupture of thin-walled capillaries and venules.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical findings would typically be seen in a patient with an injury to the bulbar urethra?
questions.solution:
Butterfly perineal hematoma is the typical finding seen in the bulbar urethral injury. 

Marked bruising of the penis, scrotum, and pubic area is commonly associated. Urethrogram with water-soluble contrast is used for confirmation of the diagnosis. 

  Rupture of the membranous urethra Rupture of the bulbar urethra
Cause Fracture of the pelvis Blow to the perineum (fall-astride injury-straddle injury)
Clinical features
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • High-riding prostate on digital rectal examination (Vermooten sign).
  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • Urinary retention
  • Perineal bruising and hematoma (Butterfly hematoma)
Investigation Retrograde urethrogram Retrograde urethrogram

 

Other options:

Option A: Membranous urethra rupture is most commonly caused by a pelvic fracture, and this fracture is usually seen in road traffic accidents. Clinical features include urinary retention, blood at the urethral meatus, and a high-riding prostate felt on digital rectal examination.  

Option C: Cobb's collar refers to the congenital narrowing of the bulbar urethra seen in patients with posterior urethral valves.

Option D: Deep pelvic extravasation of urine (in the deep perineal pouch) is typically seen in patients with injury to the membranous urethra only. 
In contrast, bulbar urethral injury leads to extravasation of urine in the superficial perineal space, scrotum and the lower anterior abdominal wall.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child was brought to the outpatient clinic with features of hypotonia, irritability, and exaggerated startle response. Development milestones were delayed. Fundoscopic examination revealed the finding as shown in the image below. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an infant presenting with hypotonia, irritability, exaggerated startle response, delayed milestones, and the image showing the cherry-red spot point to the diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease. The enzyme deficient in this condition is β-hexosaminidase A.

Tay-Sachs disease is a lipid storage disorder due to the deficiency of hexosaminidase A leading to the accumulation of GM2 gangliosides. It is classified into infantile, juvenile, and adult-onset forms based on the age at onset and clinical features.

Affected infants usually develop normally until 4-5 months of age. Clinical features of Tay-Sachs disease include:

  • Muscle weakness (hypotonia)
  • Seizures
  • Exaggerated startle response
  • Macrocephaly
  • Mental retardation
  • Macular cherry-red spots
  • Blindness
  • Developmental delay

The deficiency of β-hexosaminidase A and B causes Sandhoff's disease. The clinical manifestations of Sandhoff disease are similar to those of Tay-Sachs disease. Infants with Sandhoff disease have hepatosplenomegaly, cardiac involvement, and mild bony abnormalities.

Other options:

Option A: Fabry disease is an X-linked lysosomal storage disorder caused due to deficiency of α-Galactosidase. This leads to the accumulation of globotriaosylceramide. Clinical features include angiokeratomas, hypohidrosis, corneal and lenticular opacities, and painful acroparesthesias. Angiokeratomas are dark red to blue-black, flat or slightly raised, punctate lesions, usually seen between the umbilicus and the knees (called the bathing suit area) and the trunk.

Option B: Metachromatic leukodystrophy is a lysosomal storage disease caused due to deficiency of the enzyme arylsulfatase A. It leads to demyelination and the patient has a neurodegenerative course.

Option D: Gaucher disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder with a deficiency of acid-β-glucosidase. It leads to the accumulation of glucosylceramide. The features of this disease include growth retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the distal femur. Histology shows the presence of Gaucher cells with a characteristic wrinkled-paper appearance. Mental retardation is seen in infants. 

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

questions.text: A patient with Graves' disease presents with the following finding. Which statement regarding this condition is false?

choices.text: Acropachy is strongly associated with this condition.
It occurs in more than 50% of patients with Graves' disease.
It occurs almost always in the presence of moderate or severe form of ophthalmopathy.
Skin changes can occur after trauma.

questions.solution:
The given scenario along with the image is suggestive of thyroid dermopathy. It occurs in <5% of patients with Graves’ disease. Thyroid dermopathy is almost always associated with ophthalmopathy.

Thyroid dermopathy is most frequently observed over the anterolateral parts of the lower leg. Hence, it is termed pretibial myxedema. Skin changes can occur at other sites, particularly after trauma. The typical lesion is a noninflamed, indurated plaque with a deep pink or purple color and orange peel-textured papules.

Thyroid acropachy refers to a form of clubbing rarely observed in Graves’ disease. It is strongly associated with thyroid dermopathy.

Thyroid dermopathy usually does not need any active treatment, but if necessary, treatment includes topical, high-potency glucocorticoid ointment under an occlusive dressing or octreotide can be useful in some cases.

The following image shows thyroid dermopathy and acropachy:

questions.text: A mother of five, brings her youngest child, an 18-month-old girl, for evaluation. The child appears very thin with minimal fat distribution. There is severe wasting of the shoulders, arms, buttocks, and thighs as shown in the below image. The middle-upper arm circumference is less than 11.5 cm. The child is alert and irritable. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The alert and irritable child with severe fat wasting in the areas of the shoulders, arms, buttocks, and thighs is likely to have marasmus. 

Marasmus is a type of severe protein-energy malnutrition which occurs due to insufficient calorie intake. It is characterized by severe wasting of fat and muscles. The child appears to be very thin, having a 'skin and bones' appearance with no fat. 

The loss of buccal fat leads to the 'monkey facies' or 'old man face' due to its aged and wrinkled appearance. 'Baggy pants appearance' is due to the presence of loose skin in the buttocks that hangs low. 

Other features that may be present are hypotension, hypothermia, and bradycardia as well as micronutrient deficiencies. 

Diagnosis of severe acute malnutrition is made with the help of anthropometry.

  • Weight for height is below -3 standard deviations for the mean on the World Health Organization (WHO) chart or,
  • Presence of bipedal edema or,
  • Middle-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is less than 115 mm (in the red zone of the tape as shown below). 

 

The children should be assessed for the following: 

  • Severe edema 
  • Low appetite (failed appetite test) 
  • Medical complications 
  • One or more danger sign

If any of the above are present, the child should be treated as a case of complicated severe acute malnutrition and should have inpatient management. Uncomplicated cases can have supervised home management. 

The WHO recommends testing hemoglobin, total blood count, peripheral blood smear, blood glucose, serum albumin, electrolytes, stool microscopy with culture, parasitic evaluation, retroviral testing, and urine microscopy with culture. 

Other options: 

Option A - Kwashiorkor is another type of protein-energy malnutrition that is characterized mainly by pitting edema starting in the legs and feet that spread to the hands and face. They also show skin changes characterized by increased pigmentation and desquamation. They do not show signs of hunger and are difficult to feed. The weight for height may be normal. The following image shows the edema and the skin changes seen in Kwashiorkor.

 

Option C - Chronic pancreatitis can mimic protein-energy malnutrition. It can occur due to cystic fibrosis and obstruction of the pancreatic ducts due to roundworms. This would present with prolonged abdominal pain, weight loss, and steatorrhea. 

Option D - Marasmic kwashiorkor is a mixed form of malnutrition that presents with features of both marasmus and kwashiorkor. There will be edema, and growth stunting with less severe hair and skin changes of kwashiorkor.

The image below shows Flag sign characterised by alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal pigmented areas on the hair strand.

questions.text: A patient presented with a painless, well-circumscribed swelling near the wrist joint. There are no skin changes or neurological involvement. Histopathological examination of the swelling revealed spindle cells with palisading of the nuclei as shown in the image below. Which of the following is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a painless, well-circumscribed swelling near the wrist joint along with the nuclear-free zones between nuclear palisading observed in the given image is suggestive of schwannoma. Verocay bodies are seen in this condition.

Schwannomas are benign tumors that may arise directly from peripheral nerves and exhibit Schwann cell differentiation. They are commonly associated with mutations in the NF2 gene on chromosome 22. This results in the loss of expression of Merlin, the NF2 gene product. 

Schwannomas are simple to excise surgically as they are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that are loosely attached to the associated nerve but do not invade it. Grossly, they appear as firm gray masses. 

Microscopically, it consists of dense areas called Antoni A area, and loose areas called Antoni B area.

  • The dense eosinophilic Antoni A areas contain spindle cells that are arranged into cellular intersecting fascicles. Palisading of nuclei is seen, with the nuclear-free zones between them, called Verocay bodies.
  • The Antoni B areas contain spindle-shaped cells that are loosely arranged and separated by a prominent myxoid extracellular matrix.

The symptoms associated with schwannoma arise due to local compression of the involved nerve or adjacent structures. Surgical removal is curative. If incompletely excised, the schwannomas can recur locally, but a malignant transformation is extremely rare. 

Other options:

Option B: Ferruginous bodies are seen in asbestosis. These are other inorganic particles that are covered by iron-containing substances. This iron is thought to be derived from ferritin within macrophages.

Option C: Miyagawa bodies are elementary, intracytoplasmic microcolonies of Chlamydia trachomatis found in lymphogranuloma venereum.

Option D: Councilman bodies are seen in liver cell damage which consists of hepatic cell degeneration and necrosis, ballooning of cells, and acidophilic degeneration of hepatocytes.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought with complaints of nasal obstruction. After a detailed examination, he was diagnosed to have adenoid hypertrophy and was planned for adenoidectomy. Which of the following options is not an indication for the surgical management of this patient?
questions.solution:
All the options mentioned above are indications of adenoidectomy, except the submucous cleft palate. It is instead, a contraindication for adenoidectomy.

Indications of adenoidectomy:

  • Adenoid hypertrophy causing snoring, mouth breathing, sleep apnea syndrome, or speech abnormalities, i.e. (rhinolalia clausa - hyponasal voice)
  • Recurrent rhinosinusitis
  • Chronic otitis media with effusion associated with adenoid hyperplasia
  • Chronic suppurative otitis media with recurrent ear discharge associated with adenoiditis/ adenoid hyperplasia
  • Dental malocclusion.

Contraindications of adenoidectomy include: 

  1. Cleft palate or submucous palate
  2. Hemorrhagic diathesis
  3. Acute infection of the upper respiratory tract

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida delivered a baby at term with a birth weight of 2.5 kg via normal vaginal delivery. The placenta delivered appears as shown in the image below. Which of the following complications is less likely to be associated with this placental variant?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a bilobed placenta, also known as placenta bilobate or bipartite placenta or placenta duplex. Fetal growth restriction is not a complication likely to be associated with this placental variant.

A bilobed placenta is described as the presence of two, almost equally sized placental lobes separated by a membrane, without significant vasculature present in between them. The umbilical cord may be inserted between the two placental lobes into the chorionic bridge, or into the intervening membranes, or in a velamentous fashion. The presence of more than two lobes is termed as multilobate placenta and is rare.

The complications associated with this placental variant:

  • First-trimester bleeding
  • Polyhydramnios
  • Abruption
  • Retained placenta

The types of placental variants:

  • Placenta succenturiata: One or more unequally sized smaller placental lobes at distant sites from the bulk of the placenta. Vessels are present in the intervening membranes that connect the two lobes. It is associated with complications like vasa previa, postpartum uterine atony, postpartum hemorrhage, and endometritis. An image of this variant is given below where L1,2,3 depicts smaller lobes, UC is the umbilical cord, and M is the intervening membrane. 
  • Placenta membranacea: Unduly large and thin placenta that develops from both the chorionic frondosum and the chorion leave. It is associated with an increased risk of placenta previa or accreta and retained placenta and its complications.
  • Ring-shaped placenta: This is a variant of placenta membranacea where a partial or complete ring of the placenta is present. This variant is associated with an increased risk of antepartum and postpartum bleeding and fetal-growth restric­tion.
  • Placenta fenestrata: In this, the central portion of a placental disc is missing.
  • Battledore placenta: In this, the umbilical cord is inserted at or near the placental margin rather than at the center. When inserted 2 cm away it is known as velamentous cord insertion. A specimen of battledore placenta is given below:
  • Extrachorial placentation: the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate. There are two types of extrachorial placentation:
    • Circummarginate placenta - In this type, the space between the fetal membranes and the basal plate is filled up by fibrin and old hemorrhage with a smooth margin.
    • Circumvallate placenta - In this type, the peripheral chorion is thickened into a ridge composed of a double fold of chorion and amnion. Complications associated with circumvallate placenta are preterm delivery, abortions, growth retardation, antepartum hemorrhage, retained placenta, and hydrorrhea gravidarum. A specimen of circumvallate placenta is shown below:

questions.text: An 8-month-old infant who has recently been weaned off breast milk presents with sudden loud crying. The baby was advised for USG abdomen and the image of the ultrasonography is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An 8-month-old infant who has recently been weaned off breast milk along with the presence of a target sign on ultrasound most likely has intussusception. Intussusception is most likely seen in infants during the weaning period due to the hypertrophy of Peyer's patches.

Intussusception is the telescoping of a segment of the bowel called the intussusceptum into a more distal segment known as the intussuscipiens and is a surgical emergency.

Ultrasound signs of intussusception are:

  • Target sign, also known as the doughnut sign or bull's eye sign. The appearance is generated by concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands. The echogenic bands are formed by mucosa and muscularis whereas the submucosa is responsible for the hypoechoic bands.
  • Pseudokidney sign: this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel. The edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and the mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles renal hilum.
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

Other options:

Option B: Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis on USG shows cervix sign.

Option C: Midgut volvulus shows a pathognomonic sign of corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

Option D: Caecal volvulus shows characteristic radiological findings like caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

questions.text: A 28-year-old was on antitubercular therapy (ATT). Which of the following drugs used in ATT causes anterior uveitis when used in high doses along with clarithromycin?
questions.solution:
Rifabutin causes anterior uveitis when used along with clarithromycin.

Rifamycins are macrocyclic antibiotics used in the treatment of mycobacterial diseases. Three rifamycins described are:

  1. Rifampicin
  2. Rifabutin
  3. Rifapentine

The side effects of rifabutin are:

  • Rash, GI intolerance, neutropenia
  • Uveitis and arthralgias with doses greater than 450 mg daily in combination with clarithromycin or fluconazole.
  • Orange-tan discoloration of skin, urine, feces, saliva, tears, and contact lenses.
  • Unique side effects include polymyalgia, pseudojaundice, and anterior uveitis.

Other Options:

Option A - Ethambutol causes side effects like optic neuritis with loss of red-green vision.

Option C - Rifampicin causes side effects like flu-like symptoms, orange color to urine, sweat, and tears, light chain proteinuria, hepatitis, teratogenicity, rashes, thrombocytopenia, and interstitial nephritis.

Option D - Isoniazid causes side effects like fever, skin rashes, drug-induced lupus, isoniazid-induced hepatitis, and peripheral neuropathy that occurs in slow acetylators.

questions.text: Which of the following IPC sections deals with causing feticide in a pregnant woman with an intent to prevent a developed child from being born alive?
questions.solution:
BNS Sec 91 (IPC 315) deals with the intent to prevent a child from being born alive or to cause its death after birth. The pre-requisite associated with this IPC is that the fetus must be in an advanced stage of development that would make it sufficiently capable of leading an extra-uterine existence. The offender is liable to imprisonment for up to 10 years, with a fine, or both.

Other options:

Option 1 - BNS Sec 89 (IPC 313) deals with the causation of miscarriage of a woman with child (and/or quick with child) without her consent. Only the person causing the abortion is liable to punishment. 

Option 3 - BNS Sec 88 (IPC 312) deals with the causation of criminal abortion (no therapeutic indication to do so) with the consent of the pregnant woman. Both the pregnant woman and the abortionist are liable to punishment. 

Option 4 - BNS Sec 90 (IPC 314) deals with the death of a pregnant woman from an act intended to cause miscarriage. In such a case, the abortionist/offender is liable to punishment including imprisonment of at least 10 years and a fine. If the act of miscarriage was undertaken after conducting a prenatal sex determination (female fetus confirmation), the offender is liable to life imprisonment and a fine of up to 2 lakh rupees.

questions.text: A 25-year-old postgraduate student comes to you with an intention to quit smoking. He has tried quitting multiple times in the past but could not control the craving. He recently read about nicotine chewing gums and seeks your advice on quitting smoking and the usage of nicotex. Which of the following is the right advice to give?

choices.text: Chew it just like any regular chewing gum and throw it within 15 minutes
Chew it slowly and keep it pressed on side of mouth till taste fades, then repeat
Nicotine replacement is as good as a placebo and should not be used
Switch to e-cigarette or vaping as it is harmless and free of smoke

questions.solution:
Nicotine gum has to be chewed slowly until there is a taste of nicotine and then kept pressed between the cheek and the teeth. This helps in the absorption of nicotine. This has to be repeated until it releases no more nicotine.

Nicotine withdrawal is characterized by mood changes, insomnia, poor concentration, restlessness, bradycardia, and weight gain. Withdrawal usually peaks at 1-3 days and lasts up to 3-4 weeks. This makes it difficult to maintain abstinence from cigarette smoking. 

Nicotine replacement therapy strategies have been developed to reduce nicotine withdrawal. Therapies include giving nicotine in the form of gums or patches for a period of 1 month to manage the withdrawal symptoms. It can then be gradually tapered.

Nicotine gum is useful in several ways. Firstly, it provides nicotine in low doses to avoid precipitation of withdrawal, which is usually the reason why patients use tobacco again. Secondly, it is free of smoke and other harmful additives. Thirdly, it provides an indirect measure of craving and how heavy tobacco usage was, in the first place.

Other options-

Option A: Chewing it like regular gum releases all of the nicotine at once, causing nausea.

Option C: Nicotine gum acts as a nicotine supplement and is better than a placebo. Any de-addiction requires motivation, and nicotine replacement might serve as a useful adjunct in motivated individuals.

Option D: Vaping or e-cigarettes have adverse effects on the cardiopulmonary system despite no smoke like conventional cigarettes. It consists of a battery-powered device, that converts a nicotine-containing liquid into vapor which the user inhales through the mouth, and exhales, just like a cigarette. It uses vapor instead of smoke, which is why it is referred to as vaping.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a known case of diverticulosis presents to the emergency department with pain abdomen. On per abdominal examination, there is guarding and rigidity. During laparotomy, a diverticular perforation is seen with purulent peritonitis.  What is Hinchey's stage in this case?
questions.solution:
Purulent peritonitis belongs to stage 3 in the Hinchey staging system.

Hinchey classification is used to describe the severity and complication of acute diverticulitis. It is used additionally to guide the overall management of acute diverticulitis. Hinchey classification of complicated diverticulitis:

Stage 1

 Mesenteric or pericolic abscess

Stage 2

 Pelvic abscess

Stage 3

 Purulent peritonitis

Stage 4

 Fecal peritonitis

The modified Hinchey classification is the most commonly used tool to describe the severity of diverticulitis. The ability of a CT scan to distinguish between grade 3 and grade 4 is limited. An accurate diagnosis is made in the operating room. The Modified Hinchey classification system is as follows:

Stage 0

 Mild clinical diverticulitis

Stage 1a 

 Confined pericolic inflammation—phlegmon

Stage 1b

 Confined pericolic abscess (within sigmoid mesocolon)

Stage 2

 Pelvic, distant intraabdominal, or intraperitoneal abscess

Stage 3 

 Generalized purulent peritonitis

Stage 4

 Fecal peritonitis

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy has non-blanching rashes on the legs and buttocks, as seen in the image. He also complains of joint pains, abdominal pain, vomiting, and blood in stool. Urine examination reveals hematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Which of the following statements is false about the condition?

choices.text: It is a large vessel vasculitis
It is often accompanied by abdominal pain
There is mesangial IgA deposition in kidneys

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario describes Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP) which is a common small vessel vasculitis in childhood.

It is characterized by a purpuric rash mostly found on the lower extremities and buttocks and is commonly accompanied by arthritis and abdominal pain. (Option C)

They may develop renal manifestations, which vary from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis: The pathogenesis of HSP nephritis appears to be mediated by the mesangial deposition of polymeric IgA. (Option D)

Laboratory studies generally show mild leukocytosis, a normal platelet count (Option A), and occasionally eosinophilia. Serum complement components are normal with a non-specific increase in total serum IgA levels.

Most clinical features of IgA vasculitis are self-limiting and resolve in a few days. Supportive management with the maintenance of hydration and pain relief is done. Patients developing nephritis due to IgA vasculitis may need aggressive management with immunosuppressants.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old lady with a history of recurrent renal stones, fatigue, and abdominal pains presents with poor blood pressure control. Current medications are lisinopril, amlodipine, and furosemide. Her blood pressure is 166/98 mmHg. Laboratory values are given below. Further evaluation is likely to show which one of the following?
Serum Values
Sodium 136 mEq/L
Potassium 4.1 mEq/L
Calcium 13.2 mg/dL
BUN 18 mg/dL
Creatinine  0.8 mg/dL

choices.text: Reduced blood flow in renal arteries

questions.solution:
The patient presents with a history of recurrent renal stones (stones), abdominal pains (groans), fatigue, and elevated serum calcium are suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Primary hyperparathyroidism has increased serum parathyroid levels and can be associated with MEN1 and MEN2A syndromes.

Patients may also present with polyuria, polydipsia, vomiting, and pathological fractures. ECG may show increased PR interval and shortened QT interval.  

Elevated blood pressure despite using three antihypertensive medications including one diuretic suggests resistant hypertension in this patient. Pheochromocytoma as a part of MEN2A syndrome may be the cause for this.

Other options:

Option A: Elevated aldosterone to renin ratio is seen in Conn's syndrome or primary hyperaldosteronism. It causes secondary hypertension and hypokalemia due to hyperaldosteronism. However, it would not explain this patient's hypercalcemia, normal potassium levels, and history of renal stones.

Option B: Reduced blood flow in renal arteries can be seen in renal artery stenosis or fibromuscular dysplasia. It may be the cause of this patient's resistant hypertension and fatigue. However, hypercalcemia or recurrent nephrolithiasis will not be present.

Option D: Elevated 24-hour urine cortisol level is seen in Cushing's syndrome. The condition presents with weight gain, moon facies, easy bruising, buffalo hump, and insulin resistance.

Related Pearl: Parathyroid Diseases

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypercalcemia

  • Parathyroid-Related
    • Primary hyperparathyroidism
      • Adenoma(s)
      • Multiple endocrine neoplasia
      • Carcinoma
    • Lithium therapy
    • Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia
  • Malignancy-Related
    • Solid tumour with metastases (breast)
    • Solid tumour with humoral mediation of hypercalcemia (lung, kidney)
    • Hematologic malignancies (multiple myeloma, lymphoma, leukemia)
  • Vitamin D–Related
    • Vitamin D intoxication
    • ↑ 1,25(OH)2D :
      • Sarcoidosis and other granulomatous diseases
      • Impaired 1,25(OH)2D metabolism due to 24-hydroxylase deficiency
    • Associated with high bone turnover
      • Hyperthyroidism
      • Immobilization
      • Thiazides
      • Vitamin A intoxication
      • Fat necrosis
    • Associated with renal failure
      • Severe secondary hyperparathyroidism
      • Aluminium intoxication
      • Milk-alkali syndrome

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with a swelling in her vagina. It is usually not painful but is troublesome during intercourse. On examination, a tender shiny swelling with well-defined margins is observed on the lateral vaginal wall. It is non-reducible and does not have any rugosities. Cough impulse is absent. The image of the swelling is given below. What causes this swelling?

choices.text: Prolapse of urinary bladder into vagina

questions.solution:
The given scenario is typical of Gartner's cyst. It arises from Gartner's duct, which is a remnant of the Wolffian duct in adults.

It is typically an asymptomatic cyst that is found on the lateral wall of the vagina. Symptoms, if present include dyspareunia, vaginal pain, and difficulty inserting tampons. Examination findings include a tense swelling that is palpable or seen to bulge from beneath the vaginal wall.

Management involves excision or marsupialization of cyst in symptomatic cases

Other options

Option A - Epidermoid cysts (or epidermal inclusions) are skin-colored round-oval cysts commonly found on the vulva. It is caused due to traumatic implantation of epidermal cells into deep tissues or due to plugged pilosebaceous units.

Option B - Cystocele is the prolapse of the urinary bladder into the vagina. It appears as a reducible swelling with ill-defined margins, rugosities, and a cough impulse. It is often associated with urinary symptoms.

Option C - Bartholin glands produce mucus for the lubrication of the vulva and vagina. Obstruction of this gland leads to Bartholin cyst. It is identified by its anatomic location, i.e. lower medial labia majora or lower vestibular area. It is usually asymptomatic but becomes painful when infected.

questions.text: A primigravida at 39 weeks of gestation presents with watery discharge per vagina and regular contractions. Physical examination reveals an adequately dilated and effaced cervix with rupture of membranes. Presentation is vertex, but labor stops progressing after the head has appeared in the vulva.  Which of the following maneuvers can be used to assist in the delivery of the head?
questions.solution:
Ritgen maneuver can be used to assist with the delivery of the head in normal labor.

When the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm, a gloved hand may be used for supporting the perineum in order to avoid expulsive delivery and to avoid perineal lacerations.

If the expulsive efforts are inadequate, the Ritgen maneuver is employed for assisted delivery of the head. This is accomplished by pushing the chin upward with the fingers of the right hand (positioned over the anococcygeal region), while the left hand exerts pressure on the occiput. Hence, the head is delivered by extension. 

The image below demonstrates the Ritgen maneuver:

 

Other options-

Option (A): Pinard maneuver is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of frank breech delivery.

Frank breech delivery (Pinard’s maneuver)—is done by intrauterine manipulation to convert a frank breech to a footing breech. Pinard maneuver is usually performed when the membranes have ruptured recently.

Technique:

  • The middle and index fingers are carried up to the popliteal fossa.
  • Then press and abduct the popliteal fossa so as to flex the fetal leg
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction and breech extraction is accomplished.

 

Option (B): Lovset maneuver used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn infant 90 degrees to bring shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder.

This technique is demonstrated in the images below-

 

Option (C): Modified Prague’s maneuver(shown below) is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: A cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification is seen on the MRI. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification is suggestive of craniopharyngioma. It is derived from Rathke’s pouch and arises near the pituitary stalk, commonly extending into the suprasellar cistern.

Other options: 

Option B: Pituitary adenomas are seen in the sellar region. Microadenomas are best shown on contrast-enhanced images. Macroadenomas are seen as snowman or figure of eight appearance. 

Option C: Meningioma is a supratentorial tumor, mainly in the parasagittal region. A classical dural tail may be seen in intracranial meningiomas but is not pathognomic. The MRI image below shows a well-defined, hyper-intense, and homogeneously enhanced mass close to the midline suggestive of meningioma.

Option D: Oligodendroglioma is exclusively found in the cerebral hemispheres, most commonly in the frontal lobes. Upto 90% of oligodendrogliomas contain visible calcification on CT. The CT image below shows a calcified cortical mass that suggests oligodendroglioma.

questions.text: A middle-aged man from West Africa developed sudden onset of fever, malaise with headache, and myalgia. This was followed by diarrhea and vomiting. The electron microscopy image of the likely causative agent is given below. Which bioterrorism category does it belong to?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and the electron microscopy image suggest the Ebola virus infection. It belongs to category A bioterrorism.

Ebola viruses are long, thread-like viruses. They belong to the genus Filovirus. Three strains of the Ebola virus have been recognized: the Zaire strain (EBO-Z), the Sudan strain (EBO-S), and the mild Reston strain (EBO-R).

Patients present with sudden fever and malaise with headache, myalgia, vomiting, and diarrhea. They may also experience hemorrhagic symptoms. Patients with severe disease develop thrombocytopenia, bleeding, and multi-organ failure leading to shock and death.  

It spreads from person to person through direct contact with body fluids such as blood, urine, sweat, semen, and breast milk. 

Diagnosis is made through the detection of Ebola virus antigen, RNA, or antibodies in the blood. Treatment includes supportive care with aggressive fluid and electrolyte replacement.

Bioterrorism is the deliberate release of an agent by attackers that causes one or more of a variety of different diseases. Category A (High risk) poses a threat to national security and can cause social disruption. Examples include Ebola, anthrax, botulism, plague, smallpox, and tularemia.

Category B bioterrorism agents are moderately easy to disseminate and associated with low mortality rates. Examples include Coxiella burnetti and Brucella. (Option B)

Category C bioterrorism agents are emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination. Examples include Nipah virus. (Option A) 

Related Pearl: Bioterrorism Agents

Description Characteristics Examples
Category A

Requires specialised public health resources

 

Bacillus anthracis

Lassa fever and other arenaviruses

Coxiella burnetti

questions.text: Tribal and hilly areas should have one health sub-center for a population size of how much?
questions.solution:
According to the present norms, tribal and hilly areas should have one health sub-center per 3000 population, one primary health center per 20,000 population, and one community health center per 80,000 population.

questions.text: Which of the following is a prescriptive screening?

choices.text: Screening of sex workers for HIV

questions.solution:
Screening for cervical cancer is an example of prescriptive screening.

Screening is defined as the search for an unrecognized illness in apparently healthy individuals by means of rapidly applied tests, examinations or procedures. In general, screening may be classified into two types:

  • Prescriptive screening
  • Prospective screening

The differences between them are highlighted in the table below:

  Prescriptive screening Prospective screening
Definition It is the screening test done in an individual for his/her own benefit It is the screening test done in an individual for the benefit of others
Purpose To detect cases and start the appropriate treatment To control disease spread by isolating the individual and providing treatment
Request for screening There is no specific request by the patient/individual. The physician responsible for the patient's care decides to perform the test. Specific requests come from to screen certain individuals.
Examples

Screening for:
- Bacteriuria in pregnancy
- Breast/cervical cancer
- Urine for sugar
- Deafness in children
- Iron deficiency anemia
- Pulmonary tuberculosis
- Newborn screening

 Screening of immigrants for infectious diseases to protect the population in the home country like screening of travellers coming from China, under request from the government to prevent the transmission of coronavirus to the Indian population.
-Screening of sex workers for HIV to prevent transmission of HIV to others
- Screening of blood donors to prevent transmission of infection to the recipient.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with complaints of difficulty in initiating and maintaining the stream of urination. Ultrasonography reveals an increase in prostate size. You start him on tamsulosin. Which of the following is true regarding this drug?

choices.text: Retrograde ejaculation is a  significant side effect.
It causes significant changes in blood pressure.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests benign prostatic hyperplasia. The true statement regarding tamsulosin is retrograde ejaculation is a significant side effect.

Tamsulosin is an α1 receptor antagonist with receptor selectivity at α1A and α1D receptors. This selectivity causes the blockade of the α1A receptor in the prostate. It is used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. It has very little effect on blood pressure due to its selective effect on α1A and α1D and hence is not used in the treatment of hypertension.

Major side effects are dizziness and retrograde ejaculation. In patients taking tamsulosin, floppy iris has been encountered during cataract surgery. Postural hypotension is a rare side-effect of this drug. It does not promote prostatic apoptosis like terazosin and doxazosin.

Related Pearl: Drugs acting on the receptors of autonomic nervous system

questions.text: A 57-year-old lady presented with complaints of dyspareunia and vaginal spotting, despite attaining menopause 3 years back. She has no other complaints, is not on any medications, and has no family history of carcinomas. On examination, the vagina appeared pale with small petechiae. Transvaginal ultrasound revealed a 3 mm thick endometrium with no abnormality. Which among the following would be an appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a case of atrophic vaginitis, which should be managed with topical estrogen, the estradiol-releasing vaginal ring being the best answer among the given options.

Atrophic vaginitis is a common cause of post-menopausal bleeding due to low estradiol levels resulting in friability. Patients may present with dry vagina; dyspareunia; and a purulent, often slightly blood-tinged, discharge. The vagina appears pale, dry, and may contain petechiae. These symptoms are part of a constellation of signs and symptoms described under genitourinary syndrome of menopause (GSM).

Treatment of atrophic vaginitis involves topical estrogens in the form of creams, tablets, or rings. Estrogen replacement restores vaginal mucosal elasticity, vaginal fluid secretion levels, blood flow, and sensorimotor responses.

Options include

  • Conjugated estrogen cream intravaginally 
  • A continuous low-dose estradiol-releasing vaginal ring containing 2 mg estradiol 
  • A 10 μg 17β-estradiol tablet intravaginally
  • An oral estrogen may be considered for maintenance therapy
  • Vaginal lubricants and moisturizers may also provide symptomatic relief.

The image below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, as per the FOGSI guidelines.

Other options:

Option A: Pipelle biopsy is done if the endometrial thickness is >4 mm on the transvaginal sonogram.

Option C: Mirena intrauterine device (IUD) or levonorgestrel IUD is effective if there is endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. It is also used to control abnormal uterine bleeding in the reproductive age group and is an effective method of contraception. 

Option D: Hysteroscopy is generally performed if pipelle biopsy does not yield an adequate result or cannot be passed.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman has the following flow pattern of umbilical arteries on a doppler. What does this pattern indicate?
questions.solution:
The given flow pattern of umbilical arteries represents an absence of end-diastolic flow (AEDF) in the umbilical arteries.

In case of absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF), the waves just touch the baseline, but do not appear below it. This is associated with intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). 

Pregnant women having intrauterine growth restriction with AEDF in the umbilical artery are managed expectantly until delivery at 34 weeks. 

Umbilical artery vessels usually have forward flow throughout the cardiac cycle.  As gestation increases, there is a gradual fall in all the placental resistance indices, so the amount of the forward diastolic flow increases and the S/D ratio (systole to diastole ratio) decreases as the period of gestation increases.

Note: Reverse end-diastolic flow has seen an insignificant increase in resistance to blood flow within the placenta. They are managed expectantly until delivery at 32 weeks.

The below image shows various patterns of end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery on Doppler.

questions.text: A patient comes with a dirty and lacerated wound. He had received a full course of tetanus vaccination previously and his last dose was about 4 years ago. Which of the following does he require?

choices.text: Single shot of tetanus toxoid vaccine

questions.solution:
A patient with a dirty and lacerated wound who completed a full course of tetanus vaccination 4 years back comes under category A.

As the patient has completed his full course of tetanus vaccination and the previous shot was within 5 years, no additional action is needed. Only wound care has to be done.

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

A. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.

B. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.

C. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.

D. Unknown or never taken immunization

Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrectly matched with respect to the porphyria and the enzyme involved?

choices.text: Acute intermittent porphyria - Uroporphyrinogen I synthase

questions.solution:
The incorrect match is variegate porphyria - ferrochelatase. The enzyme deficiency in variegate porphyria is protoporphyrinogen oxidase.

Porphyrias are a group of metabolic disorders caused due to defects in heme biosynthesis. 

The classification of porphyrias based on their enzyme deficiencies is as shown below:

Enzyme deficiency

 Name of the condition
1. ALA dehydratase ALA dehydratase deficiency
2. Uroporphyrinogen I synthase Acute intermittent porphyria
3. Uroporphyrinogen III synthase Congenital erythropoietic porphyria
4. Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase Porphyria cutanea tarda
5. Coproporphyrinogen oxidase Hereditary coproporphyria
6. Protoporphyrinogen oxidase Variegate porphyria
7. Ferrochetalase Erythropoietic Protoporphyria


Based on the involvement, porphyrias are classified as:

  • Cutaneous disease only:
    • Porphyria cutanea tarda 
    • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria 
    • Erythropoietic protoporphyria 
  • Cutaneous disease and acute attacks:
    • Hereditary coproporphyria 
    • Variegate porphyria
  • Acute attacks only:
    • Acute intermittent porphyria

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:
  • ALAD enzyme deficiency porphyria
