questions.text:
A 54-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with fatigue, tiredness, and cervical lymphadenopathy. The TLC and DLC were normal, with no immature cells. A lymph node biopsy is done and the findings are shown in the image below. CD10 and BCL2 are positive. What is the likely diagnosis?

TLC- Total leucocyte count

DLC- Differential leucocyte count
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing fatigue, tiredness, and cervical lymphadenopathy with CD10 and BCL2 positive cells with image showing abnormal lymphoid follicles with centrocytes and centroblasts is highly suggestive of follicular lymphoma.

Follicular lymphoma presents in middle age with no sex predilection. The most common presenting symptom is painless generalized lymphadenopathy. A lymph node biopsy is adequate for the diagnosis of follicular lymphoma. Immunophenotyping of the cells showing CD19, CD20, CD10, BCL2 positive, and CD5 negative is suggestive that the cells originate from the germinal center. 

The majority of follicular lymphomas have characteristic (14:18) translocation. This juxtaposes the IGH locus on chromosome 14 and the BCL2 locus on chromosome 18. This chromosomal rearrangement results in the overexpression of the BCL2 protein, which is an inhibitor of apoptosis that contributes to lymphoma cell survival.

Histopathology:

Lymph nodes exhibit a nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern. Two cell types are predominantly present in varying proportions: 

  • Centrocytes (small cleaved cells) - Small cells with a cleaved nucleus and scant cytoplasm
  • Centroblasts - Large cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm

In most cases, there is a majority of centrocytes.

The peripheral blood smear shows lymphocytosis and the bone marrow tap reveals paratrabecular lymphoid aggregates.

The following image shows a lymph node biopsy in follicular lymphoma:

Other options - 

Option B - Burkitt's lymphoma is an aggressive type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) that mainly occurs in children and young adults. It is characterized by the translocation and deregulation of the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8 to chromosome 14 or 22 - t(8:14) or t(8:22). Histopathology of the tumor reveals a starry sky appearance. It usually presents with a mass involving the mandible and abdominal viscera. Immunophenotyping of the cells shows IgM, CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL6 positive and BCL2 negative.

Option C - Mycosis fungoides is the most common type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. The histological hallmark of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (mycosis fungoides type) is the presence of Pautrier microabscess. Lesions include scaly, red-brown patches; raised, scaling plaques that may be confused with psoriasis; and fungating nodules. The presence of B-cell markers in the question rules out the differential of mycosis fungoides.

Option D - Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by the presence of chimeric BCR-ABL gene which is a result of a reciprocal (9;22) (q34;q11) translocation (Philadelphia chromosome). The presence of lymphadenopathy in the given scenario rules out the possibility of CML as it is a myeloid disorder.

questions.text:
An elderly male, who is a chronic smoker, is diagnosed with carcinoma of the bladder. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?

NMIBC- Non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer

choices.text: Cystourethroscopy is used in the diagnosis
NMIBC can extend to the lamina propria
Painful gross hematuria is the most common symptom

questions.solution:
Option C is the incorrect statement. Painful gross hematuria is not the most common symptom of carcinoma of the bladder.   

Painless, gross hematuria is the most common symptom that is indicative of a bladder carcinoma until proven otherwise. Subsequent clots and urinary retention can occur. Increased frequency and discomfort during urination may be seen. It can lead to pelvic pain due to extravesical spread, loin pain due to hydronephrosis, and suprapubic pain if the nerve is involved.

Depending upon the depth of invasion, bladder carcinoma is divided into 3 groups:

  • Flat, non-invasive carcinoma in situ (CIS)
  • Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer - does not invade detrusor muscle but can invade lamina propria. It accounts for 70% of cases
  • Muscle-invasive bladder cancer - invades the detrusor muscle.
Cystourethroscopy is the mainstay of diagnosis. It is performed on patients with hematuria. The most common radiological sign is a filling defect seen in intravenous urography(IVU). Non-contrast CT and MRI and ultrasonography are used for the immediate management of patients with gross painless haematuria. A bimanual examination should be performed both before and after endoscopic surgical treatment of these tumors.

Related Pearl: Etiological Factors for Bladder Carcinoma

Histological subtype Risk factors
Transitional cell carcinoma (urothelial) Smoking
Exposure to aniline dyes
Cyclophosphamide
Pelvic irradiation
Squamous cell carcinoma Schistosomiasis (S. haematobium)
Chronic irritation caused by stone disease
Bladder diverticula
Chronic UTI
Smoking
Adenocarcinoma

Persistent urachus or trigone of the bladder
Congenital bladder exstrophy

Inherited cancer syndromes:

  • Lynch syndrome
  • Hereditary retinoblastoma
  • Costello syndrome

Acquired genetic mutations:

  • Gain of function mutation in FGFR3
  • Activating mutations in RAS and PI-3 kinase
  • Disruption of p53 and RB genes in muscle-invasive cancers

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient with features of toxic multinodular goiter is planned for total thyroidectomy. Which among the following statements is false regarding the perioperative management of this patient?

choices.text: Last dose of carbimazole can be given on the evening before surgery
Beta blockers should be continued for 7 days after surgery
Iodine can be given along  carbimazole for 10 days before surgery
Thyroid replacement should be started 3 days after surgery

questions.solution:
For patients undergoing total thyroidectomy, thyroxine replacement should be started on postoperative day 1.

Preoperative preparation:

Traditional preparation aims to make the patient biochemically euthyroid at operation. 

  • Carbimazole 30–40 mg daily is the drug of choice for preoperative preparation. The last dose of carbimazole may be given on the evening before surgery.
  • Iodine is given 10 days before the operation. Iodide produces transient remission and may reduce vascularity, thus marginally improving safety.
  • β-adrenergic blocking drugs are used to block the clinical manifestations of a hyperthyroid state, they act peripherally on the end-organs. Propranolol also inhibits the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. The appropriate dosages are propranolol 40 mg TDS or the longer-acting nadolol 160 mg OD. Since these drugs do not interfere with the synthesis of thyroid hormones and hormone levels remain high during treatment and after surgery, it is essential to continue treatment for 7 days postoperatively.

Postoperative care:

  • Following surgery, wound care should include looking out for signs of a hematoma.
  • Following total thyroidectomy, calcium levels should be checked postoperatively. Serial calcium monitoring is recommended for high-risk patients.
  • Patients who underwent total thyroidectomy require thyroxine replacement, and it should be started on day 1 postoperatively.
  • A biochemical assessment of thyroid function and calcium should be done if necessary.

Related Pearl: Classification of Anti-Thyroid Drugs

 Drugs inhibiting iodide trapping:

  • Thiocyanates
  • Perchlorates
  • Nitrates

Drugs inhibiting hormone synthesis:

  • Propylthiouracil
  • Methimazole
  • Carbimazole

Drugs inhibiting hormone release:

  • Iodine
  • Sodium iodide
  • Potassium iodide
  • Organic iodide

Drugs inhibiting peripheral conversion:

  • Propylthiouracil
  • Amiodarone
  • Iodinated contrast dyes (Iopanoic acid)
  • Propranolol
  • Glucocorticoids

Drugs that destroy thyroid tissue:

  • Radioactive iodine

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

Treatment of thyroid storm:

Treatment modality Effect
IV Fluids, ice packs Rehydration and external cooling
Propylthiouracil
(DOC)

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Propranolol

Block adrenergic effects

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Corticosteroids

Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Lugol’s iodine/ sodium ipodate Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland
Digoxin Controls the associated atrial fibrillation
Diuretics and administration of oxygen

To manage cardiac failure

questions.text: After hitting your elbow against the wall, rubbing the affected area seems to relieve the pain. The stimulation of which of the following fibers is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The pain relief experienced after rubbing the affected area is due to the stimulation of Aβ sensory fibers.

The stimulation of large-type Aβ sensory fibers from peripheral tactile receptors depresses pain signal transmission from the same body area. This occurs due to local lateral inhibition in the spinal cord.

The activity of these cutaneous mechanosensitive afferents may reduce the responsiveness of dorsal horn neurons to the nociceptive input from afferent terminals. It explains why rubbing the skin near painful areas offers pain relief, and also explains why the local application of liniments relieves pain.

This is called the gate-control mechanism of pain modulation. It is the principle behind the use of transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) for pain relief. TENS uses electrodes to activate Aα and Aβ fibers near the injury.

Note:
Pain stimulus is transmitted by Aδ (fast pain) and C fibers (slow pain).

questions.text:
The HHH syndrome is caused due to the deficiency of _______.

HHH- Hyperornithinemia, Hyperammonemia and Homocitrullinuria.
questions.solution:
The HHH syndrome is caused due to the deficiency of the ornithine transporter.

HHH syndrome is caused by a defect in the transport system of ornithine from the cytosol into the mitochondria (ORNT1 gene) resulting in the accumulation of ornithine in the cytosol and a deficiency of this amino acid in mitochondria. The accumulation of cytosolic ornithine leads to hyperammonemia and hyperornithinemia. Homocitrulline is formed from the reaction of mitochondrial carbamyl phosphate with lysine. When ornithine is deficient, it leads to homocitrullinuria.

Components of HHH syndrome:

  • Hyperammonemia
  • Hyperornithinemia
  • homocitrullinuria

Other options:

Option A: Arginase deficiency leads to hyperargininemia. Increased arginine levels are seen in blood and CSF.

Option C: Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency leads to hyperammonemia type II. Orotic aciduria occurs due to the redirection of carbamoyl phosphate into pyrimidine synthesis.

Option D: Carbamoyl phosphatase synthetase I deficiency leads to hyperammonemia type I. Presents with mental retardation.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: A physician prescribes colchicine to a patient diagnosed with an acute episode of gout. By what mechanism does this drug improve his condition?

choices.text: Reducing neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue

questions.solution:
Colchicine acts by reducing neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue and neutrophil adhesion. 

It arrests the cell division in G1 by interfering with microtubule and spindle formation. Colchicine can also alter neutrophil motility and decrease the secretion of chemotactic factors and superoxide anions by activated neutrophils. 

Colchicine is considered second-line therapy in acute gout because it has a narrow therapeutic window and a high rate of side effects, particularly at higher doses. Adverse effects mainly involve gastrointestinal symptoms like nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, and abdominal pain. Life-threatening toxicities are associated with the administration of concomitant therapy with P-glycoprotein or CYP3A4 inhibitors.

Other options:

Option A: Allopurinol and Febuxostat decrease uric acid production by inhibiting xanthine oxidase.

Option B: Probenecid and lesinurad increase uric acid excretion by inhibiting the reabsorption of uric acid by organic anion transporters.

Option C: Aspirin, an NSAID (Nonsteroidal Anti-inflammatory Drug), covalently acetylates the catalytic subunits of the COX-1 and COX-2 dimers, irreversibly inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzyme (COX) activity. Through this mechanism, the drug shows antipyretic, analgesic, and anti-inflammatory actions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, who is a known case of sickle-cell anemia, presented with a history of headache, 1 episode of generalized seizures, and confusion. On examination, she was found to have papilledema and focal neurological deficits. A  contrast-enhanced CT of the head shows the following finding. What could be the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The above-mentioned clinical scenario, in this patient with a history of sickle cell anemia, is suggestive of cerebral venous thrombosis. CECT image shows the empty delta sign, which is seen in cerebral venous thrombosis.

Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis is the occlusion of the lateral, sagittal sinuses or of small cortical veins (cortical venous thrombosis).

Symptoms and signs:

  • Headache - most common, with or without vomiting
  • Seizures
  • Intracranial hypertension and papilledema
  • Focal neurological deficits
  • Altered mental status
  • Coma

It is commonly seen in hypercoagulable states. Risk factors include the following:

  • Oral contraceptive pill use
  • Pregnancy and puerperium
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Dehydration
  • Intracranial infections
  • Thrombophilias like antiphospholipid syndrome; polycythemia; sickle cell anemia; protein C, S deficiency; factor V Leiden mutation; and antithrombin III deficiency

Investigations include:

  • MRI Brain with MR venography is the most sensitive investigation.
  • Non-contrast CT Brain may be normal, so CECT or MRI Brain is preferred.
  • Empty delta sign is a sign of dural venous sinus thrombosis of the superior sagittal sinus, where contrast outlines a triangular filling defect (clot) and is only described with a CECT-scan or MRI.

CECT image showing the empty delta sign in the superior sagittal sinus posteriorly, with a large infarct in the left hemisphere causing a midline shift to the right

Treatment of CVT:

  • Acute treatment: using IV Heparin or LMWH
    • IV heparin is the drug of choice in cerebral venous thrombosis. It prevents further thrombosis and reduces venous hypertension and ischemia.
  • Maintenance therapy:
    • Anticoagulation is often continued indefinitely if thrombophilia is diagnosed.
    • If there is no underlying hypercoagulable state, treatment with vitamin K antagonists like warfarin for 3–6 months may be initiated and then converted to aspirin, depending on the degree of resolution of the venous sinus thrombus. 
    • In pregnant women:
      • Anticoagulation with low-molecular-weight heparin throughout pregnancy and till 8 weeks postpartum

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient suffered a diaphyseal tibial fracture sustained in a road traffic accident and he was managed conservatively with casts. The follow-up radiograph after a few months is as shown below. What could be the probable cause of this finding?

choices.text: Due to loss of a fragment of bone

questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows hypertrophic nonunion of the Tibia. It is mostly due to inadequate stabilization.

Based on increasing biologic potential for fracture healing, non-union can be of the following types:

  • Atrophic nonunion: Poor healing response with no callus formation due to little or no active bone-forming cells at the fracture site. The blood supply is typically poor. On radiography, there is an absence of bone reaction. 
  • Oligotrophic nonunion: There is minimal callus formation, often due to inadequate approximation of fracture surfaces. On radiography, there is minimal bone healing reaction.
  • Hypertrophic nonunion: These fractures have adequate healing response and good vascularity. There is a lack of adequate stability for the union to occur. On radiography, there is usually abundant callus formation with an intervening dark area of fibrocartilage-lacking mineral. It can occur after initial nonoperative management or in some cases after initial operative management where there was inadequate stabilization.

questions.text: Which of the following is the SI unit for the measurement of the amount of light reflected from a surface?
questions.solution:
The amount of light reflected from a surface is known as brightness or luminance. The SI unit for the measurement of brightness is candela/square meter.

The following table shows different units used for the measurement of light as recommended by the International Organization for Standardization:

Description Quantity Measured SI Unit Other Units Used
Brightness of a point source Luminous intensity Candela Candle power
Flow of light Luminous flux Lumen -
Amount of light reaching a surface

Illumination

(Illuminance)

 Lux  Foot candle,  Lumen/cm²
Amount of light reflected from a surface Luminance Candela/square meter Foot lambert, Candle/cm2

questions.text: The following image shows the sequence of propulsion of a bolus in the gut by means of peristalsis. Which of the following substances is responsible for the configuration of the segment of the gut marked as '2'?
questions.solution:
The given configuration of the segment marked by '2' is due to the vasoactive intestinal peptide being responsible for a state of relaxation of this part of the gut. 

The above image shows peristalsis. It is a reflex response that is initiated when the gut wall is stretched by the contents of the lumen. The given segment of relaxation is an anterograde segment that moves from an oral to a caudal direction. 

Stretching of the gut wall releases serotonin and activates the cholinergic neurons present in the myenteric plexus. Cholinergic neurons passing in an anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus. Cholinergic neurons passing in a retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which cause contraction of a segment of the intestine behind the bolus.

The following image shows the events as described.

Note:

In achalasia cardia, there is a defective release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of peristalsis

questions.text: A patient newly diagnosed with chronic lymphocytic leukemia is started on fludarabine. A few days later, he develops vomiting, abdominal pain, and hematuria. His laboratory results reveal new-onset impaired kidney function, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, hyperuricemia, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase levels. Which of the following conditions has he developed?
questions.solution:
The patient has developed tumor lysis syndrome. The patient has been started on fludarabine, a cytotoxic drug to treat chronic lymphocytic leukemia. The cytotoxic drug causes lysis of tumor cells, leading to hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and hyperuricemia. The uric acid crystals and calcium phosphate precipitate in the tubules and cause damage to the epithelium, subsequently causing renal failure. 

Patients with impaired renal function, high tumor burden, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level are more likely to develop tumor lysis syndrome. 

Management: Aggressive hydration and administration of allopurinol at the same time as fludarabine are used to reduce the incidence of tumor lysis syndrome. Febuxostat, a non-selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor, can be used to treat hyperuricemia. It does not require dose calculations and can be used in patients with mildly decreased renal function. 

Rasburicase, a recombinant urate oxidase, may also be used in patients with renal failure. Hemodialysis can be done in severe cases not responding to treatment. 

Other options:

Option B - Chronic kidney disease would have a long-term history of impaired kidney function. This patient’s kidney dysfunction is of recent onset. In addition, his laboratory values are more suggestive of tumor lysis syndrome. 

Option C - Urate arthropathy (gouty arthritis) is not likely in this patient as he has no joint involvement. 

Option D - Nephrotoxic nephropathy is unlikely in this patient. Fludarabine is a purine nucleotide analog that causes myelosuppression, immunosuppression, fever, myalgia, and arthralgias.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who is a known case of familial hypercholesterolemia was prescribed alirocumab. It helps in lowering lipid by __________.
questions.solution:
Alirocumab helps in lowering lipids by PCSK-9 inhibition.

It is a monoclonal antibody that binds to proprotein convertase subtilisin Kexin type 9 (PCSK-9). PCSK-9 is a protease involved in the degradation of LDL receptors, which results in higher plasma LDL concentrations. Alirocumab binds to free PCSK-9, thereby interfering with its binding to the LDL receptor, leading to increased liver clearance of LDL from the circulation and lower serum LDL levels.

Alirocumab and evolocumab are 2 FDA-approved PCSK9 inhibitors. It is used as adjunctive therapy in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, in whom the maximum tolerated statin dose is not able to achieve target LDL reduction.

It is administered as subcutaneous injections every 2 weeks or once monthly depending on the indication.

questions.text: The audiogram given in the image below is seen in ______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows an upsloping/ ascending audiogram in which lower frequencies are affected first like in the early stages of Meniere's disease also known as endolymphatic hydrops. 

Meniere's disease (endolymphatic hydrops) is an inner ear disorder where the endolymph distends the endolymphatic system.

Meniere's disease is usually unilateral. It is characterized by episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sense of ear fullness.

Pure tone audiometry reveals a sensorineural type of hearing loss with lower frequencies affected first. It shows a rising type of curve. As the disease progresses, middle and higher frequencies get involved, and the audiogram becomes flat or downsloping type.

The illustration given below shows an audiogram seen in different stages of Meniere's disease.

Other options:

Option A: Ototoxicity causes bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Audiometry shows a downsloping audiogram, typically involving frequencies above 8,000 Hz and progresses to lower speech frequencies. Common drugs causing the same include aminoglycoside antibiotics; loop diuretics (not thiazides); antimalarials; cisplatin; and NSAIDs like ibuprofen, salicylates, and indomethacin.

Option B: Presbycusis is a physiological sensorineural hearing loss occurring in individuals above 65 years of age. Audiometry shows a downsloping graph.

Option C: In noise-induced hearing loss, audiometry shows a typical notch at 4000 Hz. As the duration of noise exposure increases, the notch becomes deeper and wider, involving lower and higher frequencies.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding thymoma?

choices.text: Invasive thymomas are cytologically malignant and locally invasive
Most tumors arise in anterior superior mediastinum
Associated with pure red cell aplasia
Typically contain benign immature T cells

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding thymoma is- Invasive thymomas are cytologically malignant and locally invasive.

Thymoma refers to the tumors of the thymic epithelial cells. Such tumors typically contain benign immature T cells. Most of the thymic tumors occur in the anterior superior mediastinum. But sometimes they occur in the neck, thyroid, and pulmonary hilus.

Histologically classified into following subtypes:

• Tumors that are cytologically benign and noninvasive- Noninvasive thymomas

• Tumors that are cytologically benign but invasive or metastatic- Invasive thymomas

• Tumors that are cytologically malignant- Thymic carcinoma

Clinical features can be chest pain, dyspnea, cough, or superior vena cava syndrome.

It is associated with paraneoplastic syndromes like myasthenia gravis, pure red cell aplasia, hypogammaglobulinemia, graves disease, pernicious anemia, dermatomyositis, polymyositis, and Cushing syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the King’s College selection criteria for liver transplantation in paracetamol-induced acute liver failure?
questions.solution:
pH >7.30 is not included in the King’s College selection criteria for liver transplantation in paracetamol-induced acute liver failure. Hence, option D is incorrect.

Given below are King's college criteria for liver transplantation:

Paracetamol-induced Acute Liver Failure:

  • pH <7.30 (irrespective of the grade of encephalopathy) 

        (OR)

  • All three of the following:
    • Prothrombin time >100 s (INR >6.5)
    • Serum creatinine level of >300 μmol/L
    • Grade 3 or 4 encephalopathy

Non-paracetamol-induced Acute Liver Failure (irrespective of encephalopathy):

  • PT >100 s (INR >6.5)

        (OR)

  • Any three of the following:
    • Age <10 years or >40 years
    • Etiology non-A, non-B hepatitis, halothane, or idiosyncratic drug reaction
    • Jaundice more than 7 days before the development of encephalopathy i.e., not hyperacute
    • PT >50 s (INR > 3.5)
    • Bilirubin >300 μmol/L.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with complaints of fever and abdominal pain for the past couple of weeks. His past history is significant for bloody stools with colicky abdominal pain and tenesmus several weeks ago. Examination reveals tenderness in the right upper quadrant. A CT scan of the abdomen is attached below. Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding the causative agent?

choices.text: Mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form
Causes flask shaped ulcer found in jejunum
Characteristic anchovy paste is produced in the abscess

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and upper abdominal CT scan revealing an abscess in the right liver lobe are suggestive of amebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. Flask-shaped ulcers occur in the colon.

Humans acquire infection by ingestion of food and water contaminated with mature quadrinucleate cyst in the feces. So, a mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form. The ameboid trophozoite is the only form present in tissues. The cytoplasm may contain red blood cells which is a pathognomonic feature.

It can manifest as acute intestinal amebiasis with symptoms of dysentery, lower abdominal discomfort, and flatulence. Low-grade symptoms such as occasional diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue are present in chronic amebiasis.

The amebic ulcer which is flask-shaped is the typical lesion seen in intestinal amebiasis. The ulcers are multiple and are confined to the colon. Sometimes, in secondary intestinal lesions, the ulcers are numerous in the cecum, followed by the sigmoido-rectal region. A granulomatous lesion called an ameboma may form in the cecal or rectosigmoid areas of the colon which can resemble an adenocarcinoma of the colon.

The most common extraintestinal manifestation is amebic hepatitis or liver abscess. The contents are necrotic and bacteriologically sterile, with active amebae confined to the walls. A characteristic anchovy paste is produced in the abscess and seen on surgical drainage.

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating both amebic colitis and amebic liver abscess.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with complaints of shortness of breath for 6 months. On examination, he has a hyperdynamic apical impulse with wide pulse pressure and a diastolic murmur in the second intercostal space on the left sternal border. The systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb by 24 mmHg. Which among the following is the above-mentioned sign?
questions.solution:
In this patient, shortness of breath along with examination findings of wide pulse pressure, hyperdynamic apical impulse, and diastolic murmur in the second intercostal space on the left sternal border points toward a diagnosis of aortic regurgitation. In aortic regurgitation (AR), if the systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb at least by 20 mmHg, the sign is called Hill's sign.

Normally, the systolic blood pressure in the lower limb is 10-20 mm higher than the upper limb pressure. The increased blood pressure is due to the summation of reflected pressure waves. In aortic regurgitation, the systolic blood pressure in the lower limb is more than 20 mmHg higher than the systolic blood pressure in the upper limb.  

Further, there are a number of other signs seen in aortic regurgitation.

Other peripheral signs seen in AR:

  • de Musset's sign is the head bobbing with each arterial pulsation
  • Corrigan's sign is the rapidly rising water hammer pulse, which collapses quickly as arterial pressure falls rapidly during late systole and diastole
  • Traube's sign is the booming pistol shot sound over femoral arteries.

The total stroke volume ejected by the left ventricle is increased in aortic regurgitation. It is the sum of the effective forward stroke volume and the volume of blood that regurgitates back into the left ventricle. This occurs due to valve leaflets or primary aortic root disease. AR results in left ventricular (LV) volume overload. This increase in LV end-diastolic volume causes dilatation and eccentric hypertrophy of the LV. Over time, these adaptive measures fail, which leads to a further rise in the end-diastolic volume, and the forward stroke volume and ejection fraction (EF) decline.

LV decompensation results in decreased compliance and increased LV end-diastolic volume and pressure. The increase in LV mass leads to increased myocardial oxygen requirements and reduced coronary perfusion pressure. This results in exertional chest pain.

A high-pitched, blowing, decrescendo diastolic murmur, heard best in the third intercostal space along the left sternal border can be auscultated in aortic regurgitation. It is best heard when the patient leans forward with breath held in forced expiration. The below image shows auscultatory findings in aortic regurgitation.

Related Pearl: Different signs in Aortic Regurgitation

Sign

Description

De Musset's sign

  Head nodding with each heartbeat

Collapsing/Water Hammer/Corrigan pulse

 It is a bounding pulse with rapid upstroke  and descent

Lighthouse sign

  Alternate flushing & blanching of the forehead

Landolfi’s sign

  Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Becker’s sign

  Retinal artery pulsations

Quincke’s pulse

 Alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
Rosenbach’s sign  Pulsation of liver
Gerhardt’s sign  Pulsation over the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly

Traube’s sign

 A pistol shot sound over femoral arteries

Durozeiz’s sign

 To-and-fro murmur over the femoral artery when lightly compressed with a stethoscope

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency is associated with nutritional melalgia?
questions.solution:
Pantothenic acid/ Vitamin B5 deficiency leads to burning feet syndrome, also known as nutritional melalgia or Gopalan's syndrome.

It acts as a functional part of CoA or acyl carrier protein. CoA plays a role in fatty acid oxidation, the citric acid cycle, acetylations, and cholesterol synthesis. ACP is involved in the fatty acid synthesis.

Deficiency leads to peripheral nerve damage leading to burning foot syndrome. It is mostly seen during a famine, in prison camps, in chronic alcoholics, and in renal dialysis patients.

 

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Deficiency State

Relatively unknown

questions.text: A paramedic in the ambulance is examining a G2P1 lady, who is in labor. Her vitals are stable, her uterus is term-sized, and the fetus is in cephalic presentation. However, the cord was found to be prolapsed outside the vulva. Which of the following first aid measures should not be done by the ambulance staff?

choices.text: Put her in exaggerated Sim's position
Adjust stretcher for reverse Trendelenburg position
Place 2 fingers in the vagina and elevate the presenting part

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests cord prolapse, and the patient should be put in a Trendelenburg position (not reverse Trendelenburg). This relieves cord compression by elevating the presenting part, till definitive management can be undertaken.

The definitive treatment for cord prolapse is delivery by cesarean section. Till then, the following first aid measures can be carried out:

  • IV fluids, oxygen by face mask, and continuous fetal monitoring
  • Stop oxytocin, if ongoing
  • Manual elevation of the fetal presenting part using two fingers or the whole hand through the vagina. (Option D)
  • Positioning of the patient in a steep Trendelenburg position, exaggerated Sim’s position (Option A), or knee-chest position
  • Vagos method (Option B): A Foley catheter is placed, and the bladder is filled with 500-750 mL of saline and then clamped. The patient’s enlarging bladder provides upward pressure on the fetus and alleviates the compression on the cord.
  • Funic reduction: Gentle replacement of the umbilical cord into the uterus. It is not preferred nowadays.
  • Tocolysis can be considered if there is a prolonged interval before delivery

Given below are the images of Trendelenburg's position, exaggerated Sim’s position, and knee-chest position, respectively:

questions.text: With respect to the Factories Act, which of the following pairs is incorrect?

choices.text: Per capita space - At least 500 cu.ft/person
Hours of work for adults - Should not be more than 9 hours a day
Age of employment - Should be at least 16 years of age to be employed
Leave with wages - Weekly holidays + 1 day for every 20 days of work for adults

questions.solution:
The Factories Act states that children of age <14 years (not 16 years) cannot be employed. Adolescents between 15–18 years can be employed only in certain industries and can work between 6 AM–7 PM. They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours per day.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: A farmer came to the outpatient clinic with a cauliflower-shaped mass on the foot, which developed after a minor injury. A histopathological image of the lesion is given. Identify the pathognomonic structure in the slide given below.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a cauliflower-shaped mass developing after a minor injury is suggestive of chromoblastomycosis. The histopathological image showing round, dark brown bodies is sclerotic bodies.

Chromoblastomycosis is more commonly seen in tropical areas among agricultural workers and woodcutters who walk barefoot. The fungus enters the skin by traumatic implantation. Patients present with warty cutaneous nodules on the feet and lower legs. Species of the fungal genus Fonsecaea are implicated as the causative agents.

Diagnosis is by demonstration of sclerotic bodies in tissue sections. Sclerotic bodies appear as round or irregular, dark brown bodies with septae. 

The condition can be managed with amphotericin B or thiabendazole. For small lesions, surgical excision is the therapy of choice.

questions.text: According to the TNM staging, a patient with lung cancer of size 8 cm with metastasis to the ipsilateral mediastinal lymph node but no distant metastasis is staged as which of the following?
questions.solution:
According to TNM staging, a patient with lung carcinoma of size 8 cm with metastasis to the ipsilateral mediastinal lymph node but no distant metastasis is staged as T4N2M0.

TNM staging system of Lung carcinoma

T: Primary tumor

Tx

Primary tumor cannot be assessed or tumor proven by the presence of malignant cells in sputum or bronchial washings but not visualized by imaging or bronchoscopy

T0

No evidence of primary tumor

Tis

Carcinoma in situ

T1

Tumour ≤3 cm in the greatest dimension surrounded by lung or visceral pleura without bronchoscopic evidence of invasion more proximal than the lobar bronchus (i.e. not in the main bronchus)

T1a(mi)

Minimally invasive adenocarcinoma

T1a

Tumour 1 cm in greatest dimension

T1b

Tumor >1 cm but ≤2 cm in greatest dimension

T1c

Tumor >2 cm but ≤3 cm in greatest dimension

T2

Tumor >3 cm but ≤5 cm or tumor with any of the following features:
– involves the main bronchus regardless of distance from the carina but without the involvement of the carina
– invades visceral pleura
– associated with atelectasis or obstructive pneumonitis that extends to the hilar region, involving part or all of the lung

T2a

Tumor>3 cm but ≤4 cm in greatest dimension

T2b

Tumor>4 cm but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension

T3

Tumor >5 cm but ≤7 cm in greatest dimension or associated with separate tumor nodule(s) in the same lobe as the primary tumor or directly invades any of the following structures: chest wall (including the parietal pleura and superior sulcus tumors), phrenic nerve, the parietal pericardium

T4

Tumor >7 cm in greatest dimension or associated with separate tumor nodule(s) in a different ipsilateral lobe than that of the primary tumor or invades any of the following structures: diaphragm, mediastinum, heart, great vessels, trachea, recurrent laryngeal nerve, esophagus, vertebral body, and carina

N: Lymph nodes involvement 

Nx

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis

N1

Metastasis in ipsilateral peribronchial and/or ipsilateral hilar lymph nodes and intrapulmonary nodes, including involvement by direct extension

N2

Metastasis in ipsilateral mediastinal and/or subcarinal lymph node(s)

N3

Metastasis in contralateral mediastinal, contralateral hilar, ipsilateral or contralateral scalene, or supraclavicular lymph node(s)

M: Distant metastasis

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis present

M1a

Separate tumor nodule(s) in a contralateral lobe; tumor with pleural or pericardial nodule(s) or malignant pleural or pericardial effusion

M1b

Single extrathoracic metastasis

M1c

Multiple extrathoracic metastases in one or more organs

Stage T1-3/N0-1/M0 are amenable to resection.

Related Pearl: Types of lung cancer

Features Adeno-carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Small cell carcinoma
Association with smoking Present, but most common type of lung cancer in non smokers Strong Strongest association
Common genetic alterations EGFR and TP53 TP53,  CDKN2A RB, TP53, MYC
Location Peripheral Central/hilar Anywhere
Precursor lesions Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia, Adeno-carcinoma in situ Squamous dysplasia, Carcinoma in situ None
Histology

Glandular differentiation, mucin production, Lepidic growth pattern

 Keratinization, squamous pearls, intercellular bridges Small cells, scant cytoplasm, salt and pepper chromatin, Azzopardi effect
IHC Mucin, TTF-1, Napsin-A p40, p63

Chromogranin, Synaptophysin, and CD56

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy sustained an injury to his left eye during a fight at school. On examination, there was a small subcutaneous ecchymosis in the left lower eyelid. An x-ray was performed, which showed a blowout fracture. What is the most common site of the fracture?
questions.solution:
The most common site of an orbital blowout fracture is the floor of the orbit. 

An isolated fracture of the orbital floor when a large blunt object strikes the globe is called a blowout fracture. The orbital contents herniate through the antrum into the maxillary sinus, which may lead to enophthalmos and entrapment of the inferior rectus muscle.

The floor is made of zygomatic, maxillary, and palatine bones. The posteromedial portion of the maxillary bone is relatively weak and may be involved in a blowout fracture.

Clinical signs: periocular swelling (early stage), enophthalmos, ecchymosis, and subconjunctival hemorrhage. Infraorbital hypoesthesia may be present because of entrapment of the infraorbital nerve.

Investigations:

  • X-ray (Water's view) shows a teardrop opacity in the maxillary sinus.
  • CT scan is used to confirm the site and size of the fracture and entrapment of muscle.

Initial treatment consists of observation, oral antibiotics, ice packs, and nasal decongestants.

Indications of surgery:

  • Enophthalmos greater than 2 mm
  • Persistent and progressive diplopia in the primary position
  • Entrapment of orbital contents
  • Large fracture involving at least half of the orbital floor

If any of these conditions are present, surgical correction is required within 2 weeks.

The image below shows the teardrop sign in the left eye due to orbital floor fracture.

questions.text: Which of the joints marked in the image is a saddle joint?
questions.solution:
The first carpometacarpal joint marked as 3 in the image is a saddle joint.

1 Interphalangeal joint Hinge
2 Metacarpophalangeal joint Ellipsoid
3 First carpometacarpal joint Saddle
4 Intercarpal joint Plane

All the above are different types of synovial joints.

Except for the first carpometacarpal joint, all the other carpometacarpal joints are plane synovial joints.

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the tape shown in the image below?

choices.text: Reading of 12.5 to 13.5 cm is considered severe acute malnutrition
Useful mainly for frontline field workers
Used for the measurement of mid-upper arm circumference

questions.solution:
The given image is used for the measurement of mid-upper arm circumference, and the false statement is option B-a reading of 12.5 to 13.5 cm is considered severe malnutrition. Reading below 11.5 cm is considered to be severe acute malnutrition (SAM).

It is used to assess severe acute malnutrition (SAM) and is useful mainly for frontline field workers for nutritional screening of malnourished children, aged 6-59 months. 

To locate the midpoint of the left arm, the arm is flexed at the right angle and the mid-point is marked halfway between the acromion and olecranon process. Colour coding is as follows:

  • Red is from 0 to 11.5 cm-Severe acute malnutrition
  • Yellow is from 11.5 to 12.5 cm-Moderate acute malnutrition
  • Green is from 12.5 to 26.5 cm-Normal

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came with complaints of headache, impaired memory, and visual disturbances. He has a history of genital ulcers from many years ago for which he did not seek appropriate treatment. Further evaluation reveals CSF analysis positive for VDRL screening. Which of the following findings is observed in the pupils in response to light?

choices.text: Pupils react but do not accommodate.
Pupils accommodate but do not react.

questions.solution:
Pupils accommodate but do not react to light.

The clinical features of the patient are suggestive of neurosyphilis. The type of pupillary response seen in reaction to light is known as the Argyll Robertson pupil.

Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP) is a feature of neurosyphilis that includes general paresis and tabes dorsalis. Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP) results from damage to the relay paths in the tectum between the afferent and efferent tracts that interrupt pupillary light reflex. But the ventral pathway of the pupillary near reflex is spared, resulting in an intact accommodation reflex. 

Clinical features in the eyes include an intact accommodation reflex, i.e eyes converge and constrict on seeing a near object. Light reflexes are absent, which means they do not constrict when exposed to bright light (i.e., they do not react to light). This is also known as light-near dissociation. These patients also have bilateral small irregular pupils. Optic atrophy is another common feature of tabes. 

Treatment of neurosyphilis is with aqueous crystalline penicillin G for 10–14 days or aqueous procaine penicillin G plus oral probenecid, both for 10–14 days. Patients who have penicillin allergy are desensitised and then treated with penicillin.

Related Pearl: Sympathetic and parasympathetic nerve supply to iris muscles

  • Dilator pupillae/radial muscle of iris: Sympathetic postganglionic nerves from cervical ganglion.
  • Constrictor pupillae/circular muscle of iris: Parasympathetic postganglionic nerves from ciliary ganglion (Edinger Westphal nucleus).

questions.text: The aim of the Kyoto protocol is ______.

choices.text: To promote clean water and sanitation
To promote proper bio-medical waste disposal

questions.solution:
The aim of the Kyoto protocol is to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions.

The Kyoto Protocol is associated with the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) regime. It covers the emission of the following six greenhouse gases:

  • Carbon dioxide (CO2)
  • Methane (CH4)
  • Nitrous oxide (N2O)
  • Hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs)
  • Perfluorocarbons (PFCs)
  • Sulphur hexafluoride (SF6)

Related Pearl: Greenhouse Effect

Greenhouse gases (GHGs) or radiatively active gases (RAGs) are gases in the atmosphere that absorb some of the upward-going, long-wave radiation after they have left the Earth’s surface. They then emit the radiation in all directions, some of it back towards the Earth’s surface. This raises the earth's temperature.

In this entire process, the earth acts as an effective insulator and the overall process is known as the greenhouse effect. The greenhouse effect has a role in global warming which is the average rise in global temperature leading to change in climate patterns.

The most important natural GHGs are:

  • Water vapor
  • Carbon dioxide
  • Methane
  • Tropospheric ozone (Stratospheric ozone is not harmful)
  • Nitrous oxide

Non-natural GHGs include chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs).

International protocols on climate change:

  • Kyoto Protocol:
    • Linked to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
    • Set internationally binding emission reduction targets for the concerned parties
    • Parties aimed to reduce GHGs by 18% from 2013-2020.
  • Paris Agreement:
    • Aims to strengthen the global response to climate change
    • Aims to maintain the global temperature rise in this century < 2°C above pre-industrial levels
    • Aims to pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase even further to 1.5°C.
    • It deals with greenhouse gas emissions mitigation, adaptation, and finance starting in the year 2020.
  • Montreal Protocol:
    • Related to the depletion of the atmospheric ozone layer, which is protective.

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant woman in her 24th week of gestation came for a regular antenatal check-up. On sonographic imaging, her amniotic fluid index was found to be much lower than normal levels. All of the following are possible causes, except _______.
questions.solution:
An amniotic fluid index (AFI) lower than normal suggests a diagnosis of oligohydramnios. All of the given options are causes of oligohydramnios, except esophageal atresia.

Esophageal atresia results in defective swallowing and impaired reabsorption of amniotic fluid by the fetus, which leads to polyhydramnios.

Oligohydramnios refers to a decreased volume of amniotic fluid and is clinically defined as an AFI <5 cm, deepest vertical pocket (DVP) <2 cm, or amniotic fluid volume < 200 ml. Conditions that lead to decreased urine production by the fetus, (such as sirenomelia and multicystic dysplastic kidneys), and bladder outlet obstruction such as urethral stenosis lead to oligohydramnios.

Findings that support a diagnosis of oligohydramnios include a fundal height much less than the corresponding gestational age, well-defined fetal parts on palpation, the uterus appearing full of the fetus, malpresentation of the fetus, and signs of intrauterine growth restriction.

Related Pearl: Causes of oligohydramnios and polyhydramnios

Causes

Oligohydramnios

Polyhydramnios

Maternal
  • Undiagnosed rupture of membrane (most common)
  • Spontaneous rupture of membranes
  • Post-dated pregnancy
  • Preeclampsia
  • NSAIDs
  • ACE inhibitors
  • Overt diabetes
  • Gestational diabetes
  • Cardiac disease
  • Renal disease
  • Liver failure

Fetal
  • Fetal anomalies
  • Renal agenesis
  • Urethral defects
    • Posterior valve
    • Obstructive uropathy

 
  • Multiple gestation
  • Neural tube defects
  • Abdominal wall defects
  • Cleft palate
  • Neck masses
  • Esophageal atresia
  • Aneuploidy
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • TTTS

Placental

Failure of secretion:- e.g. Amnion nodosum

Chorangioma of placenta

questions.text: A 46-year-old male patient presents with complaints of difficulty in swallowing, a feeling of food getting stuck below his throat, and a burning sensation in his chest over the past month. A barium swallow study is performed, and the findings are shown below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient presenting with food impaction and dysphagia and barium swallow showing the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus is suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis.

Eosinophilic esophagitis is diagnosed based on the combination of typical esophageal symptoms and esophageal mucosal biopsies demonstrating squamous epithelial eosinophil-predominant inflammation.

Symptoms:

  • Adults: Food impaction, dysphagia, vomiting, and GERD-like symptoms
  • Children: Feeding intolerance and GERD-like symptoms
  • Patients are usually atopic and may also have atopic dermatitis, allergic rhinitis, asthma, or modest peripheral eosinophilia.

Diagnosis:

The “feline” esophagus which resembles the appearance of stacked circular rings, strictures, and linear furrows on esophageal endoscopy is typical of eosinophilic esophagitis. Fluoroscopy/barium studies show a small-caliber esophagus, transient or fixed circular rings, or a benign stricture. The diagnosis requires a biopsy with a histologic finding of > 15–20 eosinophils per high-power field.

Treatment:

Patients typically undergo a trial of PPI therapy to exclude GERD. 30–50% of cases respond to PPI therapy.

Children have been effectively treated with allergy testing combining skin prick and atopy patch testing. Both adults and children responded to empiric elimination of common food allergies (milk, wheat, egg, soy, nuts, and seafood) followed by systematic reintroduction.

Swallowed, topical glucocorticoids like fluticasone propionate or budesonide are highly effective but have high rates of recurrence after discontinuing therapy. Systemic glucocorticoids are reserved for severely afflicted patients refractory to less morbid treatments.

Esophageal dilation is very effective at relieving dysphagia in patients with fibro stenosis but is approached conservatively because of the risk of deep, esophageal mural laceration or perforation in the stiff-walled esophagus.

The below image shows the feline esophagus seen on esophageal endoscopy.

Other options:

Options B - Diffuse esophageal spasm is a hypermotility disorder of the esophagus seen more commonly in women. Patients usually present with dysphagia and chest pain which is caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the oesophageal body. However, in between the contractions, peristalsis remains normal. Pathologically, there is marked hypertrophy of the circular muscles and barium swallow study shows corkscrew appearance.

Option C - Achalasia cardia is a primary esophageal motility disorder characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter in response to swallowing. It presents with the characteristic triad of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. On barium swallow, bird-beak appearance of the esophagus is seen in achalasia. Esophageal manometry is the "gold standard" investigation for achalasia.

Option D - Zenker's diverticulum is a pseudodiverticulum resulting from herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian triangle (or dehiscence of Killian). Killian triangle is an area of muscular weakness between the transverse fibers of the cricopharyngeus and the oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus. Barium swallow study is used for the diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect. 

Related Pearl: Barium Studies

Barium swallow: Used to assess the pharynx, esophagus, and stomach. (Barium paste is used)

The image below is a barium swallow showing eosinophilic esophagitis and associated stricture:

Barium meal: Used to assess stomach and duodenum. (95% BaSO4 is used)

Barium meal followthrough: Used to assess the small intestine (50% BaSO4 is used)

Barium enema: Used to assess the large intestine (25% BaSO4 is used)

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents with severe acute pain in the abdomen. She has an old ultrasonography report, which is shown below. Which among the following would be false in case of red degeneration?
questions.solution:
The ultrasound image shows a well-defined rounded tumor, which is suggestive of a fibroid in the uterus. If red degeneration occurs, the WBC count will be elevated and not normal.

Red degeneration is the most common complication of fibroids in pregnancy. It is due to the breakdown of the fibroid, resulting in ischemia and pain. It is an aseptic condition. Key clinical features of this condition:

  • Low-grade fever
  • Tender uterus on palpation
  • Elevated WBC count
  • Elevated ESR

The diagnosis is confirmed with an ultrasound. It is usually self-limiting and can be managed with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

Note: Torsion fibroid is a close differential of red degeneration of fibroid. The patient will similarly present with acute pain abdomen, but the WBC count will be normal.

 

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

Related Pearl: Complications of pregnancy due to fibroids

  • Increased risk of abortion or miscarriage
  • Preterm labor
  • Abnormal presentation
  • Accidental hemorrhage
  • Dystocic labor
  • Postpartum hemorrhage
  • Puerperal sepsis
  • Uterine inversion

questions.text: A 58-year-old chronic alcoholic woman presented to the dermatology outpatient department with the following lesion over the extensor aspect of the arm. All the following are the histopathological features seen in this condition, except _______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical image is indicative of psoriasis. All the following histopathological features are seen in this condition except suprapapillary thickening, instead suprapapillary thinning is seen.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin with systemic manifestations. The sustained inflammation leads to uncontrolled proliferation of the epidermal keratinocytes.

In a normal individual, it takes approximately 30 days for basal epidermal keratinocytes to proliferate, differentiate, and ascend through the layers of the epidermis. However, this process takes only 4-5 days in a patient with psoriasis. 

It can be caused due to drugs (lithium, antimalarials, interferon-α), seasons (winter), infections (streptococcal), alcohol abuse, and smoking. 

Histopathological features of psoriasis include:

  • Acanthosis- Irregular epidermal thickening 
  • Hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis
  • Suprapapillary thinning
  • Clubbing or elongation of rete ridges at the base
  • Kogoj spongiform pustules- collection of neutrophils in the malpighian layer (stratum basale and stratum spinosum referred together)
  • Munro microabscesses- collection of neutrophils in stratum corneum
  • Dilated, tortuous blood vessels in the dermis

Psoriasis patient presents with skin involved in the form of red/ salmon pink, scaly, and well-demarcated lesions. A peripheral clearing (ring of Woronoff) may be present. It is usually seen on the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

The appearance of a smooth, glossy red membrane with small bleeding points on the removal of the scales by gentle scraping is known as Auspitz sign, which is characteristic. It is associated with Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon.

Topical application of steroids, retinoids, vitamin D, and emollients is the mainstay of management

The following is an image of psoriasis. Its epidermis shows markedly elongated rete ridges, with bulbous thickening. Also, it shows thin suprapapillary epidermal plates, edema, and dilated vessels in the dermal papillae.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis

Type Drug of choice

Erythrodermic Psoriasis Methotrexate

2. Cyclosporine

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with progressive painless loss of vision presents to the ophthalmology OPD. The fundus image of the patient is given below. What could be the probable finding and the cause of it?

choices.text: Soft exudate, central retinal vein occlusion

questions.solution:
The given image shows small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with crenated margins that are suggestive of hard exudates, seen in diabetes mellitus.

In diabetic retinopathy, hard exudates occur due to chronic localized edema and are composed of leaked lipoproteins and lipid-filled macrophages.

Other common causes of hard exudates include hypertensive retinopathy, Coats’ disease, and circinate retinopathy.

 

Cotton wool spots (soft exudates) appear as whitish fluffy spots with indistinct margins that represent areas of infarcts in nerve fiber layer. Common causes are hypertensive retinopathy, toxemic retinopathy of pregnancy, diabetic retinopathy, anemias, and collagen disorders like discoid lupus erythematosus, polyarteritis nodosa, and scleroderma.

The image shows cotton wool spots

 

Flame-shaped hemorrhages are superficial retinal hemorrhages that occur due to disruption of the capillaries in the retinal nerve fiber layer. Common causes are diabetic retinopathy, non-ischemic central retinal vein occlusion, traumatic retinopathy, Eale's disease, hypertensive retinopathy, and anemic retinopathy.

 

Fundus examination of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) reveals massive engorgement, congestion, and tortuosity of retinal veins. Ischemic CRVO has massive retinal hemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance involving the whole fundus.

Related Pearl: Hypertensive retinopathy

Hypertensive retinopathy describes the fundus changes that occur in a patient with systemic hypertension. It is graded as follows:

  • Grade 1 - Mild generalized retinal arteriolar narrowing
  • Grade 2 - Focal arteriolar narrowing and deflection of veins at AV crossings (Salu's sign).
  • Grade 3 - Grade 2 changes with the following:
    • Copper-wiring of arterioles
    • Cotton wool spots, retinal hemorrhages (dot, blot, flame) or exudates (chronic retinal edema)
    • Bonnet’s sign: Banking of veins distal to arteriovenous crossings
    • Gunn’s sign: Tapering of veins on either side of the arteriovenous crossings 
      Macular star (Deposition of hard exudates around the fovea) may be present. 
  • Grade 4 - Severe grade 3 changes with optic disc swelling or papilledema (a marker of malignant hypertension) and silver-wiring of arterioles.

Related Pearl: Causes of loss of vision

Features Cause
Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Central retinal artery occlusion
  • Massive vitreous hemorrhage
  • Retinal detachment involving macula
  • Ischemic central retinal vein occlusion
Sudden painless onset of diminution of vision
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Optic neuritis
  • Methyl alcohol amblyopia
  • Non-ischemic central retinal vein occlusion
Sudden painful loss of vision
  • Acute congestive glaucoma
  • Acute iridocyclitis
  • Injury to eyeball
Gradual painless diminution of vision

  • Optic atrophy

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy accidentally ate the fruit shown in the image below. He presents with blurred vision, slurred speech, urinary retention, and confusion. On examination, the pupils are dilated, the mouth is dry, and the face appears flushed. What is the antidote of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image of a cherry-like, highly toxic fruit are suggestive of Atropa belladonna poisoning. It is a deliriant poison. The appropriate antidote of choice is physostigmine.

Atropa belladonna acts by inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine. All the parts of the plants are toxic. The active principle is 1-hyoscyamine.

The signs and symptoms, treatment, and postmortem appearances are similar to those associated with Datura poisoning. Clinical manifestations can be remembered with 9D's: dryness of mouth, dysarthria, dysphagia, dilation of cutaneous blood vessels, diplopia, dry hot skin, drunken gait, delirium, and drowsiness. On examination, dilation of the pupils, flushing of the face, and congestion of the cornea can be seen.

Note:

Deliriant poisons are poisons that produce a well-marked deliriant or confusional stage, like Datura, Belladonna, Hyoscyamus, Cannabis, and cocaine.

Other options

Options A and B- Atropine and pralidoxime are antidotes used in organophosphorus poisoning.

Option C- Sodium amytal is used as an antidote for strychnine which is a spinal poison.

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Digitalis purpurea 

Atropa belladonna

Calotropis gigantea

Related Pearl: Toxic manifestations of Datura

  • Mnemonic: "hot as a hare, blind as a bat, dry as a bone, red as a beet, and mad as a hatter"
  • Also, remember the D's of Datura
    • Dry hot skin (Temp rises upto 42 C, a scarlet rash may also be appreciated).
    • Dilatation of pupils along with loss of accommodation
    • Diplopia
    • Dryness of the mouth and throat, unquenchable thirst
    • Dysphagia
    • Dilatation of cutaneous blood vessels
    • Dysarthria (Difficulty in talking)
    • Drunken gait
    • Delirium
    • Drowsiness
    • Death due to respiratory or cardiac failure

questions.text: Which among the following is discarded in the bin shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a red bin. According to Biomedical Waste Management Rules, urine bags are discarded in the red bin. Red bins are used to discard contaminated waste that is recyclable.

Cotton swabs contaminated with blood and blood bags are discarded in the yellow bin. Ampules are discarded in blue puncture-proof containers.

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue and chronic diarrhea for 4 months. Endoscopy reveals several ulcers in the gastric antrum and the descending duodenum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of gastrinoma- Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. 

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is caused by gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumors. In 75% of patients, gastrinomas are sporadic, solitary lesions. The remaining 25% of patients with gastrinomas have multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1). Gastrinomas usually arise in the small intestine or pancreas. The most remarkable feature in the stomach is an increase in oxyntic mucosal thickness due to massive parietal cell hyperplasia.

Patients present with duodenal ulcers or chronic diarrhea. The acidic environment impairs the function of digestive enzymes (pancreatic enzymes), leading to the malabsorption of nutrients. This malabsorption results in an osmotic gradient, drawing water into the intestinal lumen, which contributes to diarrhea. 

Treatment of individuals with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome includes blockade of acid hypersecretion, typically with proton pump inhibitors. 

Other options:

Option A: VIPoma is characterized by watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria (WDHA syndrome). It is caused by the release of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) from the tumor.

Option C: Glucagonomas, α-cell tumors are associated with increased serum levels of glucagon. The patient presents with mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia. They occur most frequently in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women and are characterized by extremely high plasma glucagon levels.

Option D: Insulinomas, β-cell tumors are the most common pancreatic endocrine neoplasms. These are usually benign and often cause symptomatic hypoglycemia. Hypoglycemic symptoms appear when blood glucose levels fall below 50 mg/dL. The symptoms usually develop after fasting or exertion and improve after glucose intake.

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Clinical features

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text: A  man suffering from ulcerative colitis for the past several years presents with jaundice and pruritus. Investigations show elevated serum alkaline phosphatase levels, and MRCP shows beading in the bile ducts. Biopsy reveals fibrosis of the bile ducts, as shown below. Which of the following is true about the disorder that has caused jaundice?

choices.text: Antimitochondrial antibodies present in most patients
Strictures and dilatations are restricted to intra-hepatic ducts
p-ANCA is positive in most of the patients

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) in a patient with a past history of ulcerative colitis. p-ANCA is positive in this condition.

Primary sclerosing cholangitis is a progressive inflammatory disorder characterized by obliterative fibrosis of both intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts (Option C). It is strongly associated with ulcerative colitis.

Clinical features comprise right upper quadrant abdominal pain, pruritus, obstructive jaundice, fatigue, steatorrhea, and fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies. It can progress to biliary cirrhosis, portal hypertension, cholangiocarcinoma, and liver failure. (Option A)

Laboratory findings are a two-fold or greater increase in alkaline phosphatase levels, elevated aminotransferase levels, and prolonged prothrombin time. p-ANCA is positive in 65% of the patients with PSC.

The imaging test of choice is magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP). Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) can also be performed to further localize areas of dominant strictures. The cholangiography findings include multifocal strictures with intervening dilated or normal bile duct segments producing a classic beaded appearance. Liver biopsy reveals periductal fibrosis and onion skinning.

Glucocorticoids are used to treat initially. Azathioprine may be added if there is inadequate response or relapse. Endoscopic dilatation of the strictures may help to improve symptoms. Definitive management is only with liver transplantation. PSC is one of the risk factors for the development of colon cancer in patients with ulcerative colitis.

The image below shows a cholangiogram of primary sclerosing cholangitis. There are diffuse strictures of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts with dilatation of the areas in between:

Other options-

Option B: Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are seen in most patients with primary biliary cholangitis, and not in PSC.

Related Pearl: Differences between primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)

Antimitochondrial antibodies positive in most patients

Antinuclear antibodies positive

Antimitochondrial antibodies /AMA typically negative

p-ANCA-positive
Age group 40–60 years 30-45 years
Gender predominance Females Males
Site Intrahepatic bile ducts only Intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts
 Associated with

Sjogren syndrome

CREST syndrome

Rheumatoid arthritis

Celiac disease
