questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient who works with animal hides presents with a lesion covered by a black eschar on his arm. Microscopy of the pus sample revealed bacilli, as shown in the image below. Which of the following proteins is not associated with the toxin produced by this pathogen?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image showing gram-positive bacilli with a characteristic bamboo stick appearance suggest Bacillus anthracis. Serum opacity factor is not a protein associated with anthrax toxin.

Serum opacity factor is a lipoproteinase produced by some M types of Streptococcus pyogenes. It causes opacity when applied to agar gel containing horse or swine serum. It is used to determine the virulence of the organism. 

Bacillus anthracis is a large, gram-positive bacillus. It causes zoonotic infections in humans. It is non-motile and capsulated with a characteristic polypeptide capsule made of d(-)glutamic acid.

Virulence factors of B. anthracis include

  • A polypeptide capsule that inhibits phagocytosis
  • Anthrax toxins, which are made of three proteins

    1. Edema factor/Factor I An adenylate cyclase that causes tissue edema
    2. Protective antigen/Factor II Binds to specific cell receptors and mediates entry of edema factor and lethal factor into the cell
    3. Lethal factor/Factor III Causes tissue death
     

Clinical presentation of anthrax:

  • Cutaneous anthrax: It is seen in dock workers carrying loads of hides and skin of infected animals. Hence, it is also called hide porter's disease. At the site of entry of organism or spores, a papule develops in about 1–3 days. This develops into a vesicle that later breaks down into an ulcer with a black, central, necrotic eschar surrounded by edematous skin. The lesion is also called a malignant pustule. The majority of the patients recover spontaneously, but a few may succumb to septicemia or meningitis.
  • Pulmonary anthrax: It is caused by inhaling spores. It is seen in wool sorters. The infection from the lung spreads to the mediastinal lymph nodes and causes hemorrhagic pneumonitis. 
  • Intestinal anthrax: It is rare and is caused due to ingestion of infected animals. 
  • Anthrax meningitis or meningoencephalitis: This is a fatal infection that occurs when the infection spreads to the CNS hematogenously. 

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between anthrax and anthracoid bacilli.

The following are the Differentiating features between anthrax and anthracoid bacilli.

S.N. Characteristics Anthrax Bacilli Anthracoid Bacilli
1. Motility Non-Motile Generally Motile
2. Capsule Capsulated Non-Capsulated
3. Shape Grow in long chains Grow in short chains
4. Medusa Head Colony Present Not Present
5. Growth in Penicillin Agar (10 units/ml) No Growth Grow Usually
6. Hemolysis Hemolysis absent or weak. Usually well marked
7. Gelatin Liquefaction Slow Gelatin Liquefaction Rapid Gelatin Liquefaction
8. Turbidity No Turbidity in broth Turbidity usually
9. Salicin Fermentation Negative Usually Positive
10. Growth at 45°C No Growth Grows usually
11. Chloral Hydrate Growth inhibited by  Chloral Hydrate Not Inhibited
12. Gamma Phage Susceptible to gamma phage Not susceptible
13. Pathogenesis Pathogenic to laboratory animals Not pathogenic

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is a neprilysin inhibitor approved for the treatment of heart failure?
questions.solution:
Sacubitril is a neprilysin inhibitor approved for the treatment of heart failure.

Sacubitril is a prodrug that is activated to sacubitrilat. It can inhibit the enzyme neprilysin (neutral endopeptidase), which is responsible for the degradation of atrial and brain natriuretic peptides. Thus, it increases the levels of natriuretic peptides and causes vascular relaxation, diuresis, and lowering of aldosterone levels.

Sacubitril is approved in combination with valsartan (angiotensin receptor blocker) for the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

Other options:

Option A: Bosentan is an endothelin receptor antagonist which is used to treat pulmonary arterial hypertension.

Option C: Icatibant is a bradykinin B2 receptor antagonist that is used to reduce the swelling caused by hereditary angioedema. 

Option D: Ivabradine selectively blocks the cardiac sino-atrial 'f' channels, also called funny cation channels involved in the generation of automaticity in the SA node. It reduces heart rate and thereby oxygen demand. It does not have any effect on cardiac contractility. It is an FDA-approved drug for the treatment of heart failure. It is also used for treating stable angina.

questions.text: A drunk father was playing with his baby and fell asleep as shown in the image, resulting in the death of the baby. What type of suffocation is seen here?
questions.solution:
The type of suffocation seen in this scenario is overlaying.

Overlaying is a type of suffocation resulting from compression of the nose, mouth, and chest, preventing breathing. It occurs in cases when a parent, under the influence of alcohol shares the bed with an infant. The guardian accidentally rolls over the child during sleep, leading to accidental occlusion of the air passages. There will be limited movements of the thoracic cavity, resulting in the reduction or absence of respiratory movements. 

Postmortem findings: The face, nose, and chest of the child appear compressed and pale. The nostrils may be filled with blood-stained froth. The usual findings of asphyxia like intrathoracic petechiae may be found. Death occurs as a result of neurogenic cardiac arrest.

Medicolegal importance: It can be purely accidental. It may also be a case of infanticide. 

Other options:

Option A: Traumatic asphyxia is a type of suffocation resulting from respiratory arrest due to mechanical fixation of the chest that prevents the normal movement of the chest.

Option B: Burking is a type of homicidal asphyxial death comprising of smothering and traumatic asphyxia. In burking, the assaulter kneels or sits on the chest of the victim, preventing chest movements, and then covers the nose and mouth of the victim with his hands. 

Below is the image showing burking.

Option C: Smothering is a type of suffocation resulting from blockage of the external respiratory orifices either by hand or any other means such as introducing a foreign object (paper, cloth).

Below is the image showing smothering:

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a history of gallstones presented with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back for the past 1 day. Laboratory investigations reveal an elevated lipase level.  Which of the following is not part of the calculation for Ranson's score at admission?

choices.text: White blood cell count of >16,000 cells/mm3
Serum aspartate aminotransferase level  of >250 IU/L

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a patient having characteristic abdominal pain radiating to the back and with elevated lipase level is suggestive of acute gallstone pancreatitis. A decrease in hematocrit by >10% is not a parameter for the calculation of Ranson's score at admission. It is however part of the Ranson score within 48 hours of admission. 

The Ranson and Glasgow scoring systems are specific for acute pancreatitis. 

Related Pearl: Ranson Prognostic Criteria for Acute Pancreatitis

Ranson's prognostic criteria at presentation
Parameter Non-gallstone pancreatitis Gallstone pancreatitis
Age >55 years >70 years
Blood glucose level >200 mg/dL >220 mg/dL
White blood cell count >16,000 cells/mm3 >18,000 cells/mm3
Serum LDH level >350 IU/L  >400 IU/L
Serum Aspartate aminotransferase level  >250 IU/L  >250 IU/L

 

Ranson's prognostic criteria after 48 hours of admission
Parameter Non-gallstone pancreatitis Gallstone pancreatitis 
Hematocrit fall
 >10% >10%
Serum calcium level <8 mg/dL <8 mg/dL
Base deficit >4 mEq/L >5 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen level increase 

≥5 mg/dL despite IV fluid hydration

 ≥2 mg/dL despite IV fluid hydration
Fluid sequestration
  >6 L  >4 L
PaO2  <60 mm Hg  Not available

Ranson score ≥3 defines severe pancreatitis.

Score Interpretation

  • 0 to 2 points: 0% to 3% mortality
  • 3 to 4 points: 15% mortality
  • 5 to 6 points: 40% mortality
  • 7 to 11: nearly 100% mortality

 

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Acute Pancreatitis

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign (A): Bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign (B): Bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Fox sign: Discolouration below the inguinal ligament
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): Dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

Related Pearl: Laboratory Findings in Acute Pancreatitis

  • Elevated serum amylase and serum lipase
    • Serum amylase level rises immediately and peaks in few hours and returns to normal in 3–5 days
    • Serum amylase level lacks specificity
    • Serum amylase levels do not correlate with the severity of pancreatitis.
    • Serum lipase is more specific, and it is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours later
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia, hypoalbuminemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Elevated serum levels of hepatic enzymes like alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
  • Azotemia, due to prerenal acute renal failure in case of severe fluid loss

questions.text: A college student has repeated episodes of intense fear and a sense of impending doom every semester before his exams. He suffers from palpitations, dyspnea, and sweating during these episodes. Which of these is the drug of choice for the long-term management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient suffering from repeated episodes of intense fear, and sense of impending doom accompanied by palpitations, sweating, and dyspnea is suggestive of panic disorder. The drug of choice for long-term management of panic disorder is paroxetine, which is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI).

A panic attack is an abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort lasting from minutes to hours. Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks, at least one of which is associated with 1 month of either persistent concern or worry about additional attacks, or a change in behavior related to the attacks.

An attack often begins with 10 minutes of rapid worsening of symptoms. This includes an extreme fear and a sense of impending doom and death along with tachycardia, palpitations, dyspnea, and sweating. The attack generally lasts for up to half an hour but in some cases may last for more than an hour. Between attacks, the patient may suffer from anticipatory anxiety about the next attack. 

DSM-5 criteria for panic disorder:

A. Recurrent unexpected panic attacks which include ≥4 of the following 

  • Palpitations
  • Trembling
  • Sweating
  • Dyspnea
  • Choking
  • Chest pain
  • Nausea, abdominal distress
  • Chills, heat sensation
  • Dizziness, light-headedness
  • Paresthesias
  • Derealization or depersonalization
  • Fear of losing control
  • Fear of death

2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following for >1 month:

  • Anticipatory anxiety - Continuous concern about additional panic attacks
  • Changes in behavior related to attacks (e.g. avoidance of unfamiliar situations)

3. The attack is not attributable to substance abuse or any other medical condition.

4. The attack cannot be explained by any other mental disorder. 

Treatment

Presently, SSRIs are considered the first-line drugs for the treatment of panic disorder. Paroxetine is preferred due to its sedative effects which calm down patients immediately leading to better compliance. Citalopram or sertraline are viable alternatives as well. However, for an acute episode with severe symptoms, benzodiazepines like alprazolam should be started concurrently with SSRIs and slowly tapered off. This is because benzodiazepines have the most rapid onset of action. Pharmacotherapy should generally continue for 8-12 months when it is found to be effective.

Other than pharmacotherapy, cognitive and behavior therapies are also very effective treatments for panic disorder. These work especially well when used in combination with pharmacotherapy. These help in producing long-lasting remissions of symptoms.

Option B - Alprazolam is a benzodiazepine with a high risk of psychological and physical dependence if used in the long term. Therefore it is used as an adjunct to SSRIs or psychotherapy and not used as a primary treatment.

Option C - Phenelzine is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor. MAOIs may require certain dietary restrictions and hence are used less often.

Option D - Imipramine is a tricyclic anti-depressant that can be used for panic disorder as a second-line drug. TCAs are used less often than SSRIs because they are associated with more adverse effects at the dosages required for the treatment of panic disorder. 

 

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

Disorder 
Feature
Panic disorder
1. Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:
  • Dyspnea
  • Tachypnea
  • Palpitations
  • Sweating
  • Dizziness
  • Chest pain
  • Tightness
  • Paresthesias
  • Emotional and cognitive
    symptoms
  • Feeling that something catastrophic is
    about to happen.

2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following > 1 month:

  • Worry about an additional panic attack or consequences
  • Changes in behaviour related to attacks (ex: avoidance)

3. Panic attack not attributable to substance abuse or another medical condition.

4. Panic attack not explained by another mental disorder.

Treatment of Panic disorder:

Immediate: Benzodiazepines
Long term: SSRI/ SNRI and or cognitive behavioural therapy
Phobias
Exaggerated anxiety responses that occur
during exposure to relatively innocuous stimuli or situations.
Specific phobias entail phobic responses to
particular stimuli or situations.
Social
anxiety disorder (Social phobia)
Phobic responses to specific social situations.
Generalized anxiety disorder
Excessive worry about
a variety of topics (job, health, finances, etc.) > 6 months.
 
3 or more of the following symptoms:
  • Restlessness
  • Fatigue
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability
  • Muscle tension
  • Sleep disturbance

Treatment:

First line: CBT, SSRIs or SNRIs

Second-line: Benzodiazepines, Buspirone

questions.text: During the attempted intubation of a patient, the senior resident complains that the glottis is too anterior and asks the junior resident to perform a maneuver so that the senior resident would be able to visualize the glottis better as shown below. Identify the correct sequence of steps that the junior resident would have performed for obtaining such a result.
questions.solution:
The maneuver that the junior resident would have performed is the BURP maneuver, where a Backwards->Upwards->Rightwards pressure is applied externally so as to move an anteriorly positioned glottis posterior for getting better visualization.

You can visualize the step-by-step result of the maneuver in the video below.

Note:

BURP maneuver should not be confused with Sellick's maneuver (cricoid pressure), which involves the application of pressure to the cricoid cartilage, thus occluding the esophagus. This technique is used in rapid-sequence induction to reduce the risk of aspiration.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant with abdominal distension, fever, and jaundice was brought to the pediatric outpatient department. Urine examination revealed a boiled cabbage odor. What is the likely disorder?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the boiled cabbage odor on urine examination is hepatorenal tyrosinemia. 

There are three types of tyrosinemias:

  • Type 1 tyrosinemia also known as hepatorenal tyrosinemia is an autosomal recessive condition. The defective enzyme is fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase. Clinical features are liver failure, hypoglycemia, boiled cabbage odor in the urine, and mental retardation. 
  • Type 2 is known as oculocutaneous tyrosinemia or Richner-Hanhart syndrome. The defective enzyme is tyrosine transaminase. Clinical features are palmoplantar keratosis, painful corneal erosions, photophobia, and mental retardation.
  • Type 3 is known as neonatal tyrosinemia. It is due to the deficiency of 4-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate hydroxylase. Clinical features include normal liver function, developmental delay, seizures, and intermittent ataxia.

Hawkinsinuria is an autosomal dominant condition. It is due to the dysfunction of 4-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate oxidase. Clinical features are failure to thrive and metabolic acidosis in infancy.

Note: Boiled cabbage odor can also be found in cases of hypermethioninemia.

questions.text: What is the principle behind plethysmography?

choices.text: Measures changes in the volume of blood flow
Detects the changes in the elasticity of a tissue

questions.solution:
Plethysmography is a semiquantitative method that measures changes in the volume of blood flow and velocity in the vascular systems.

There are different types of plethysmographs:

  1. Impedance plethysmograph: Enables detection of deep vein thrombosis or venous insufficiencies
  2. Air plethysmograph: Assesses calf pump function and venous reflux in the lower limb
  3. Photoplethysmograph: Evaluates venous function using infrared light
  4. Water plethysmograph: Measures limb volume in lymphedema

Other options: 

Option B: Thromboelastography (TEG) is a non-invasive test that quantifies the ability of whole blood to form a clot. It is useful in intraoperative coagulation status assessment. The dynamic changes in the viscoelastic properties of a blood sample during the clotting can be detected and quantified by thromboelastography.

Option C: Electrocardiography is a record of the electrical activity of the heart in a graph. 

Option D: Elastography is a newer imaging modality, which detects the changes in the elasticity of tissues. It is based on the concept that the pathological process alters the elastic properties of tissue. It is useful in differentiating malignant and benign breast neoplasms, identifying traumatic changes in the muscles and tendons, helping to decide the biopsy site accurately, and assessing liver fibrosis and steatosis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents with respiratory insufficiency. A decision is made to perform a procedure using the instrument shown below. Which of the following is not a function of this procedure?
questions.solution:
The image shows a tracheostomy tube. Tracheostomy does not increase dead space by 30-50%. It decreases dead space and reduces airway resistance. 

Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. 

Functions: 

  1. Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction
  2. Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space by 30-50% and reducing airway resistance
  3. Uses a cuff to protect the airways from secretions and blood
  4. Allows suction of secretions in the setting of the impaired cough reflex
  5. Allows positive pressure respiration
  6. Allows administration of anesthesia

Indications: 

  1. Respiratory obstruction due to 
    1. Infections (laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis, epiglottitis, diphtheria)
    2. Trauma due to external injury, mandibular or maxillofacial fractures
    3. Neoplasms
    4. Foreign bodies or edema
    5. Bilateral abductor paralysis
    6. Congenital anomalies
  2. Retained secretions
    1. Inability to cough due to coma, spasm, or paralysis of respiratory muscles
    2. Aspiration of pharyngeal secretions
    3. Painful cough
  3. Respiratory insufficiency due to emphysema, chronic bronchitis

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.text: A middle-aged patient presented to the outpatient clinic with frontal bossing, a large tongue, spade-shaped hands, and a protruding lower jaw as shown in the image. The physician prescribed pegvisomant for his condition. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this drug?

choices.text: It is a  growth hormone receptor antagonist
It activates JAK-STAT signaling pathway and stimulates IGF-1 secretion
Liver function tests should be monitored in all patients

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding pegvisomant is, it activates the JAK-STAT signaling pathway and stimulates IGF-1 (insulin-like growth factor 1) secretion.

The image of a middle-aged man with frontal bossing, a large tongue, a protruding lower jaw, and spade-shaped hands, are highly suggestive of acromegaly. Acromegaly is a clinical syndrome that results from the excessive secretion of growth hormones.

Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist. It is indicated for the treatment of acromegaly. Pegvisomant binds to the GHR but does not activate JAK-STAT signaling and does not stimulate IGF-1 secretion.

Insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) levels are used to screen for acromegaly. The diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating that GH concentration is >1 ng/mL after 2 hours of an oral glucose load (75 g). The drug Pegvisomant is administered subcutaneously (a 40 mg loading dose, followed by administration of 10 mg/day). Liver function tests should be monitored in all patients because of the risk of elevation of hepatic transaminases. Lipohypertrophy can also occur at injection sites.

Related Pearl: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

questions.text:
An ultrasound scan of a 35-year-old woman revealed a unilocular cyst of 5 cm in her ovary. She is asymptomatic. She does not have a family history of breast, ovarian, or colon cancer. She has not received treatment for infertility in the past. CA-125 levels are < 35 U/mL. What is the next best step in her treatment plan?

OCPs - oral contraceptive pills
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a functional cyst in the ovary. Among the given options, the next best step in her treatment plan is to follow up after 1-2 cycles of OCPs. 

A functional cyst is usually asymptomatic, unilocular, and contains clear fluid unless a hemorrhage occurs. In the childbearing period, around 70% of ovarian tumors are functional. They usually regress spontaneously within a few months. It is usually between 3-7 cm in size.

A simple, unilocular cyst of less than 7 cm should be observed. It usually regresses within 4-6 months. Oral contraceptive pills can be prescribed for 3-4 months to women of child-bearing age to hasten its regression. 

A follow-up ultrasound can pick up a persistent cyst. On ultrasound, if any cyst persists for longer than 3 months or its size increases to more than 7 cm, the possibility of malignancy should be investigated. 

Before opting for surgical management, it is important to be certain that the tumor is benign and the other ovary healthy by frozen-section biopsy.

Laparotomy is advised for tumors more than 7 cm to prevent complications or malignant transformation.

In a young woman, in order to conserve the healthy ovary, the ovarian cyst should be enucleated (cystectomy). If this is not possible, ovariotomy should be done. 

Laparoscopic cystectomy–ovariotomy is a minimally invasive surgery done for small ovarian cysts. The other options of treatment are laparoscopy/ ultrasound-guided aspiration and removal of the cyst.

Hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy are recommended in peri-menopausal women, even in the case of benign and unilocular cysts.

questions.text: Among the following, which is the earliest sensation to be lost in leprosy?
questions.solution:
The earliest sensation to be lost in leprosy is hot temperature.

The sensations are lost in the following order:

  • Temperature (inability to distinguish hot and cold)
  • Light touch
  • Pain
  • Deep touch

Leprosy (Hansen disease) is a chronic infective granulomatous disease caused by the bacillus Mycobacterium leprae.

Leprosy is clinically characterized by one or more of the following features :

  • Numbness
  • Hypopigmented patches
  • Erythematous macules over cheeks, upper arms, thighs, and buttocks may be present.
  • Partial or total loss of cutaneous sensation in the affected areas 
  • Presence of thickened nerves
  • Presence of acid-fast bacilli in the skin or nasal smears.

Classification systems of leprosy:

  • Ridley-Jopling classification:
    • Tuberculoid (TT)
    • Borderline tubercular (BT)
    • Borderline (BB)
    • Borderline lepromatous (BL)
    • Lepromatous (LL)
  • Madrid classification:
    • Lepromatous (LL)
    • Tuberculoid (TT)
    • Borderline/dimorphous
    • Indeterminate (early unstable type)
  • Indian classification - includes categories under Madrid classification + pure neuritic type

    The spectrum of leprosy in India in decreasing order of prevalence: 

    1. Borderline tuberculoid 
    2. Borderline lepromatous
    3. Lepromatous leprosy
    4. Pure neuritic type
    5. Borderline-borderline
    6. Indeterminate type
    7. Histoid type 
  • WHO classification:
 

Paucibacillary Leprosy

 Multibacillary Leprosy

Number of skin lesions 

up to 5 

6 or more

Nerve involvement 

0-1 

2 or more 
Slit skin smear  Negative on all sites

Positive at any site
Ridley-Jopling  TT, BT

BB, LL, BL 

As per the NLEP guidelines, a patient with paucibacillary leprosy is treated with rifampicin and dapsone for 6 months. The dose of rifampicin is 600 mg, and it is given monthly under supervision. The dose of dapsone is 100 mg and has to be taken by the patient every day.

A patient with multibacillary leprosy is treated with rifampicin, clofazimine, and dapsone for 12 months. Rifampicin 600 mg and clofazimine 300 mg are given every month under supervision. Dapsone 100 mg and clofazimine 50 mg should be taken by the patient every day.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a gunstock deformity of his hand which developed after he sustained a fracture. On examination, you notice that he was unable to perform the following sign and there were no associated sensory symptoms. This is suggestive of:

choices.text: Injury to the deep branch of ulnar nerve
Injury to the superficial branch of ulnar nerve
Injury to the posterior interosseous nerve
Injury to the anterior interosseous nerve

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of gun stock deformity following a fracture indicates a history of supracondylar fracture of the humerus. The sign shown in the above image is the 'OK sign' and the inability to perform this sign is suggestive of injury to the anterior interosseous nerve, a purely motor branch of the median nerve. 

In the case of supracondylar fracture, the most common nerve injuries: Anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve

The patient is asked to perform the OK sign by touching the tips of the index finger and the thumb. Normally, the patient is able to flex the distal phalanges, producing an O-shape. 

In anterior interosseous nerve injury (AIN), the flexor digitorum profundus and flexor pollicis longus are weak. The patient is unable to perform the OK sign. The fingers get pinched, and instead of the tips, the volar surfaces of the thumb and index finger make contact. 

The image below shows a normal OK sign on the right side and an abnormal sign on the left side because of AIN injury:

SCC- Squamous cell carcinoma

choices.text: This method is preferred to treat BCC lesions near eyes
Sentinel lymph node biopsy is always done before this procedure
This method should not be used in recurrent BCC
This technique is contraindicated in SCC with invasive lesions

questions.solution:
The given procedure is microscopically oriented histographic surgery (MOHS). The correct statement is option A.  

Mohs micrographic surgery involves sequential horizontal excision of the tumor with immediate pathologic margin assessment. It is used most often for skin malignancies such as basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell cancer, and in situ lesions of melanoma.

Mohs micrographic surgery is the treatment of choice for morphea form and other basal cell carcinomas with the following features:

  • High-risk tumors
  • Poorly differentiated lesions
  • Recurrent tumors (option C)
  • Cosmetically sensitive areas, especially in the midface and eyes, where tissue preservation is important

Other options:

Option B - Sentinel lymph node biopsy is not always required before the procedure. In the case of BCC, it is only locally invasive (no lymphatic or blood-borne spread). It is usually done in cases of malignant melanomas. 

Option D - Mohs microsurgical excision is indicated for squamous cell carcinoma in cases with the following features: positive margins, recurrent tumors, sites where cosmesis or function preservation is critical, poorly differentiated tumors, invasive lesions, and verrucous tumors.

questions.text: A female patient presents to the physician with sudden-onset fever, rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise, and headache. On further evaluation, she tested positive for the Zika virus. She has an increased risk of developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The patient who tested positive for the Zika virus has an increased risk of developing Guillan-Barre syndrome.

Zika virus is a flavivirus acquired mainly through the bite of an infected female Aedes aegypti mosquito. However, transmission can also occur perinatally through sexual contact with an infected individual, breastfeeding, and blood transfusion. 

Congenital transmission of the Zika virus leads to fetal microcephaly. Zika virus infection during pregnancy may also lead to other malformations, including limb contractures, high muscle tone, eye abnormalities, and hearing loss, known as congenital Zika syndrome.

Zika virus infection is characterized by influenza-like clinical signs, including fever, headache, and malaise. An itchy, maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, myalgia, and arthralgia usually accompany or follow those manifestations.

The complications of the Zika virus infection include Guillan-Barre syndrome, encephalitis, meningoencephalitis, peripheral neuropathies, and neurological birth defects. Other complications of pregnancy include preterm birth and miscarriage.

Other Options:

Option B: Glomerulonephritis is seen 1-4 weeks after the acute infection of Streptococcus pyogenes. 

Option C: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare delayed sequel to infection with the measles virus. It is seen in young adolescents and is characterized by progressive deterioration of mental and motor functions.

Option D: Thyroiditis is not a known complication of Zika virus infection. Some viruses like mumps and influenza can cause subacute thyroiditis.

questions.text: Which of the following fibers are carried by the structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the posterior limb of the internal capsule and it carries the cortico-spinal motor fibers from the thalamus.

The internal capsule is a component of the white matter of the brain. They contain projection fibres. It can be divided into the following parts:

  • anterior limb
  • genu
  • posterior limb
  • retrolenticular/ retrolentiform portion
  • sublenticular/ sublentiform portion

The anterior limb of the internal capsule carries the fronto-pontine fibers, while the genu carries the corticonuclear tract. 

The posterior limb of the internal capsule carries cortico-spinal motor fibers in the anterior part. The posterior part of the posterior limb of the internal capsule carries sensory fibers.

The retrolenticular part contains the parietopontine, occipitopontine and occipitotectal fibres and the sublenticular part contains temporopontine and some parietopontine fibres.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition shown in the image below?

choices.text: Treatment of larger defects requires skin grafts.
Treacher Collins syndrome is associated with coloboma of eyelid.
It usually occurs near the temporal side

questions.solution:
The given image shows a coloboma of the upper eyelid. Option D is the false statement as it usually occurs near the nasal side and not the temporal side.

Coloboma of the eyelid is a partial or full-thickness eyelid defect. It more frequently involves the upper lid (Option B) than the lower lid and usually occurs on the nasal side. It occurs when eyelid development is incomplete, due to failure of migration of lid ectoderm to fuse with the lid folds.

Upper-lid colobomas occur at the junction of the middle and inner thirds and have a relatively strong association with cryptophthalmos, facial abnormalities, and Goldenhar syndrome. (Cryptophthalmos is a congenital anomaly in which the eyelids are absent, replaced by a continuous layer of skin). Lower lid colobomas occur at the junction of the middle and outer thirds and are frequently associated with systemic conditions. 

Treacher Collins syndrome is characterized by malformations in the derivatives of first and second branchial arches, primarily mandibular and ear anomalies. Lower eyelid coloboma (Option C) is a feature of this syndrome along with slanted palpebral apertures, cataracts, microphthalmos, and lacrimal atresia. 

Small defects can be managed by primary closure, while large defects require skin grafts (Option A) and rotation flaps.

questions.text: A female patient is diagnosed with Huntington's chorea. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the disorder?

choices.text: There are abnormal repeats of CUG
It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder
Abnormality is seen due to mutation in chromosome 4
There is a gain of function type of mutation

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding the disorder is option A. 

Huntington's chorea is a prototypic polyglutamine trinucleotide repeat disorder.

It is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder. It is caused by CAG trinucleotide repeats (>40). It occurs due to a gain-of-function (expansion) mutation in the huntingtin gene on chromosome 4p. 

The disease shows genetic anticipation. It refers to an early onset of the disease in the next generation if inherited from the father as repeat expansions occur during spermatogenesis.

This condition is characterized by rapid, nonpatterned, semi-purposeful, involuntary choreiform movements. Other features include dysarthria, gait disturbance, oculomotor abnormalities, behavioral disturbance, and cognitive impairment with dementia.

The disease affects components of the dorsal striatum. Atrophy of the caudate and putamen with ex vacuo ventriculomegaly is also seen. The loss of striatal neurons results in increased motor output which is manifested as choreoathetosis. The cognitive changes associated with the disease are related to neuronal loss in the cerebral cortex.

questions.text: During your labor room postings, a vaginal examination of a primigravida female revealed the anterior cervix having soft consistency and showing 3 cm dilatation and a cervical length of 3 cm. You would assign a Bishop score of 1 to which of these cervical parameters in this patient?
questions.solution:
Among the given parameters, cervical length of 3 cm is given a score of 1 whereas a score of 2 is given for all the other parameters.

The Bishop score is a scoring system used to assess labor induction outcomes. It is based on the station of the head, dilation, effacement (or length), position, and consistency of the cervix noted by doing a vaginal examination.

Note: In the modified Bishop score (1991), the effacement is replaced by the cervical length in cm.

From the data given in the question:

  • Length of the cervix is 3 cm, hence score = 1
  • Position of the cervix is Anterior, hence score = 2
  • Cervical dilatation is 3 cm, hence score = 2
  • Consistency of cervix is soft, hence score = 2

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text:
According to NPCBVI, blindness is defined as ______.

NPCBVI: National Program for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment

choices.text: Visual acuity <6/12 – 6/18 in the better eye with correction
Visual acuity <3/60 in the better eye with available correction
Visual acuity <6/60 – 3/60 in the better eye with correction
Visual acuity <6/18 – 6/60 in the better eye with correction

questions.solution:
As per the NPCBVI guidelines, blindness is defined as visual acuity of <3/60 or its equivalent in the better eye with available correction.

Refractive error is the main cause of visual impairment in ages 0-49 years, followed by cataracts, amblyopia, and corneal opacity. However, in the age group >50 years, cataract is the major cause, followed by refractive errors and surgical complications of cataract. 

Definitions of blindness and visual impairment as per NPCBVI: 

Blindness Presenting visual acuity <3/60 in the better eye with available correction
Mild visual impairment  Presenting visual acuity <6/12 – 6/18 in the better eye with available correction
Moderate visual impairment (MVI) Presenting visual acuity <6/18 – 6/60 in the better eye with available correction
Severe visual impairment (SVI) Presenting visual acuity <6/60 – 3/60 in the better eye with available correction

questions.text: A patient with nephrotic syndrome has severe proteinuria and low levels of serum albumin. What would be the most likely change in the anion gap of this patient?
questions.solution:
Serum albumin is an unmeasured anion. Therefore, proteinuria in nephrotic syndrome leads to a decrease in unmeasured anions.

Albumin is negatively charged at physiological pH and responsible for approximately 75% of the unmeasured anions of the normal anion gap. A drop in albumin therefore will cause the anion gap to fall. Nephrotic syndrome causes hypoalbuminemia and thus patients have a reduced anion gap.

Decreased anion gap (<6 mEq/L) is seen when there is

  • An increase in unmeasured cations
  • An addition of abnormal cations to the blood, such as
    • Lithium (lithium intoxication)
    • Cationic immunoglobulins (plasma cell dyscrasias)
  • A reduction in the plasma anion albumin concentration (nephrotic syndrome, liver disease, or malabsorption)

questions.text: The major neurotransmitter and the neuroanatomical area concerned with delirium are:
questions.solution:
The major neurotransmitter to be involved in delirium is acetylcholine, and the major neuroanatomical area is reticular formation.

The reticular formation of the brainstem is the principal area for the regulation of attention and arousal. The major pathway implicated in delirium is the dorsal tegmental pathway - projecting from the mesencephalic reticular formation to the tectum and thalamus.

The correlation between several delirium-inducing factors and decreased acetylcholine activity in the brain has been well-established by studies. Iatrogenic delirium can result from multiple anticholinergic drugs being prescribed simultaneously.

Another proposed mechanism, mainly for the delirium associated with alcohol withdrawal, is the hyperactivity of the locus ceruleus and its noradrenergic neurons. Other neurotransmitters that have been implicated are serotonin and glutamate.

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with a chronic history of pain in the small joints of her hands with stiffness of joints in the early hours of the day. The image of the patient’s hands is given below. What is the preferred management in limiting joint destruction and disability for her?
questions.solution:
The history and image are typical of rheumatoid arthritis. Methotrexate with anti-TNF is preferred in limiting joint destruction and disability.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease of unknown etiology characterized by symmetric polyarthritis. A variation in the HLA-DRB1 gene is known to cause RA. Cigarette smoking is known to increase the risk.

Histopathological features include synovial cell hyperplasia and proliferation with inflammatory infiltrates and rheumatoid nodules. These are necrotizing granulomas surrounded by fibrinoid necrosis. 

Clinically, patients present with early morning joint pain and stiffness that is relieved with activity. It mainly involves the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. Other hallmark features include flexor tendon tenosynovitis, swan neck deformity, boutonniere deformity, Z-line deformity, and trigger finger. RA is a systemic disease and leads to a variety of extra-articular manifestations, including fatigue, subcutaneous nodules, interstitial lung disease, etc. 

Patients may have elevated ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate) and C-reactive protein (CRP). Rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP (cyclic citrullinated peptide) antibodies are helpful in prognosis.

Management comprises non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs for pain relief, along with disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs (DMARD). Methotrexate is the DMARD of choice. Hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) is given as an adjuvant in combination with other DMARDs. Biological agents such as TNF-α inhibitors, anakinra, and rituximab are known to reduce the signs and symptoms of RA, slow the radiographic progression of joint damage, and improve physical function and quality of life.

Combination therapy:

  • Methotrexate, sulfasalazine, and hydroxychloroquine (Oral triple therapy).
  • Methotrexate and leflunomide.
  • Methotrexate and a biological such as anti-TNF

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text:
Which of the following features are suggestive of an artificial bruise?

1. Location at a site accessible to the patient
2. Location at a site not accessible to the patient
3. Presence of blisters
4. Absence of blisters
5. Presence of itching
questions.solution:
Location at a site that is accessible to the patient, the presence of blisters, and itching are features suggestive of an artificial bruise. 

Artificial bruises are caused by the application of certain irritant substances such as the juice of marking nut and roots or twigs of Plumbago rosea to simulate true bruises. However, the following features can be used to distinguish between the two entities.

Trait Artificial bruise True bruise
Site Accessible to the patient Anywhere
Color Dark brown Typical color progression over time
Shape Irregular Regular
Margins Well defined and regular Ill-defined and irregular
Vesicles/Blisters Present Absent
Redness/Inflammation Present in the surrounding skin Present over bruise
Itching Present Absent
Ecchymosis Absent Present
Chemical tests Positive Negative

Bruises cannot be produced after 2 minutes of death. However, small bruises can be developed by violent forces even up to 3 hours after death. Antemortem bruises can be differentiated from postmortem bruises by the following features:

Features Antemortem bruise Postmortem bruise
Swelling Present Absent
Damage to epithelium Present Absent
Extravastion of blood Present Absent
Inflammation in tissues Present Absent

questions.text: Which of the following antiarrhythmics has the property of blocking sodium and potassium channels?
questions.solution:
Procainamide belongs to the class IA of antiarrhythmics. It has the property of blocking sodium and potassium channels.

Class 1A drugs have an intermediate rate of recovery with sodium and potassium channel-blocking properties. These include procainamide, quinidine, and disopyramide. Procainamide is used in the treatment of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome with atrial fibrillation. Procainamide is used in the acute and chronic management of atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation.

Other options:

Option B: Verapamil and diltiazem are calcium channel blockers that belong to class IV antiarrhythmics. It is used in the management of supraventricular arrhythmias and rate control in atrial fibrillation. These agents can be used in the termination and prevention of such arrhythmias.

Option C: Propranolol is a beta-blocker belonging to class II antiarrhythmics agents. It is used for rate control in atrial fibrillation. 

Option D: IV Ibutilide is administered as a rapid infusion for the immediate conversion of atrial fibrillation or flutter to sinus rhythm. It is a class III antiarrhythmic drug that is a potassium channel blocker and restores sinus rhythm by prolonging the action potential duration and effective refractory period. Ibutilide carries a significant risk of Torsades de Pointes. Hence is not preferred in a patient with prolonged QT interval.

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient admitted to the intensive medical care unit with suspected meningoencephalitis is undergoing the procedure shown below. All the following structures are pierced during this procedure, except ________.
questions.solution:
The patient is undergoing a procedure of lumbar puncture as shown in the image. All the given structures are pierced during lumbar puncture, except the posterior longitudinal ligament.

Lumbar puncture is a diagnostic procedure done to obtain a sample of cerebrospinal fluid from the subarachnoid space. The following structures are pierced during lumbar puncture, in that order:

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous tissue
  • Supraspinous ligament
  • Interspinous ligament
  • Ligamentum flavum
  • Epidural space
  • Dura
  • Arachnoid
  • Subarachnoid space 

Indications:

  • Diagnosis of suspected meningitis and subarachnoid hemorrhage 
  • Spinal anesthesia and intrathecal administration of antibiotics/ chemotherapy
  • Therapeutic relief of pseudomotor cerebri, less frequently

Contraindications for lumbar puncture include:

  • Absolute- Infection over the site 
  • Relative-
    • Coagulopathy
    • Raised intracranial pressure
    • Spinal epidural abscess

Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) is a common post-procedure symptom. It occurs due to loss of CSF through the dura which causes traction on the pain-sensitive intracranial structures. The headache in PDPH is typically frontal or occipital. It is aggravated with the upright or sitting posture and is relieved by lying supine. 

Other complications include infections, bleeding, cerebral herniation, and radicular pain.

The image given below shows the types of needles used for lumbar puncture.

The below image shows lumbar puncture being performed in the lying as well as the sitting position.

  • Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

  • IV fluids
  • Caffeine and analgesia

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with hypertension, diabetes, and ischemic heart disease undergoes percutaneous coronary intervention with the placement of a drug-eluting stent in order to reduce restenosis. Which of the following is involved in the further care of this patient?

choices.text: Daily aspirin for 6 months then daily clopidogrel for 6 months
Daily aspirin indefinitely and clopidogrel for at least 1 year
Daily aspirin for 1 year and clopidogrel for 6 months

questions.solution:
Clopidogrel, a P2Y12 receptor blocker, along with aspirin is called dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT). DAPT should be continued for at least 1 year following stent placement to prevent stent thrombosis, with aspirin being continued indefinitely. 

Drug-eluting stents (DES) are coronary stents that locally release antiproliferative agents that can reduce restenosis. However, the delayed endothelial healing in the region of the stent can increase the acute risk of thrombosis during the period after placement. This increased risk calls for the use of dual antiplatelet therapy for at least a year. The commonly used antiproliferative drugs in DES are everolimus, tacrolimus, sirolimus, paclitaxel, etc.

questions.text: A 26-year-old nursing mother presents with pain in her left breast. On examination of the breast, a tender, non-fluctuant swelling was present. The overlying skin is red, hot, and flushed as shown in the image below. Her WBC count is 13000/mm3. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a nursing mother presenting with a tender, non-fluctuant swelling in the breast, along with elevated total leukocyte count, and the image shown above are suggestive of acute mastitis. The drug of choice for acute mastitis is dicloxacillin.

Dicloxaciilin is a penicillinase resistant penicillin. 500 mg is administered every 6 hours for 7 days. For patients who are allergic to penicillin, erythromycin can be used.

Acute mastitis is caused by infection with Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis, and Streptococci viridans commonly. The source of organisms is the infant’s nose and throat. It usually occurs during the first 2–4 weeks postpartum. Poor nursing, maternal fatigue, and crackled nipple are some of the risk factors.

Clinical features of acute mastitis include generalized malaise, nausea, vomiting, headache, high fever with chills, severe pain, and tender swelling in the breast. On examination, the skin overlying the swelling will be red, hot, and flushed, and will feel tense. 

Microscopic examination of breast milk will show a leukocyte count of more than 106/mL and a bacterial count of more than 103/mL. An abscess can form if there is variable destruction of breast tissues.

Other steps in management include:

  • Breast support
  • Plenty of oral fluids
  • Breastfeeding is continued with good attachment
  • Nursing initiated on the unaffected side
  • The infected site is emptied manually with each feed
  • Analgesics like Ibuprofen
  • Maintained milk flow by breastfeeding

The incidence of acute mastitis can be reduced by washing hands before breastfeeding and cleaning the nipples before and after each feed to keep them dry.

questions.text: You are about to administer neostigmine to a patient for reversal of neuromuscular blockade. Your senior asks you to add atropine to it. This is because atropine _______.

choices.text: Facilitates earlier recovery from neuromuscular blockade

questions.solution:
Atropine, a tertiary amine, is an anticholinergic drug that is used along with anticholinesterases like neostigmine in order to minimize the muscarinic adverse effects of anticholinesterases. It has no effect on the reversal of neuromuscular blockade produced by the nicotinic effect of anticholinesterases.

Atropine counteracts the cardiovascular effects of anticholinesterases like bradycardia and other bradyarrhythmias.

Glycopyrrolate, a quaternary amine, is another anticholinergic that can be used with anticholinesterases. It has a slower onset than atropine but does not cause central effects as it does not cross the blood-brain barrier, unlike atropine.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a patient with paronychia of the index finger on the right hand, as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts paronychia associated with a reddish erythematous streak-like lesion on the hand suggestive of paronychia associated with lymphangitis. The treatment of choice for this patient is amoxiclav. 

Acute paronychia is an acute infection of the nail beds and folds. It is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It presents as a tender, erythematous swelling around the nail.

Treatment of pyogenic paronychia: 

  • Protection against trauma
  • Keep affected fingernails dry.
  • Abscesses - Incision and drainage. (abscess is often opened by pushing the nail fold away from the nail plate)
  • Antibiotics- A penicillin in combination with a β-lactamase inhibitor, e.g. amoxicillin with clavulanic acid (Amoxiclav)

Chronic paronychia is usually due to infection with Candida albicans and responds to topical antifungal therapy.

Lymphangitis:

Lymphangitis represents acute inflammation elicited by the spread of bacterial infections into lymphatics, with group A β-hemolytic streptococci being the most common causative agent. It is manifested by red, painful subcutaneous streaks (the inflamed lymphatics) and painful enlargement of the draining lymph nodes (lymphadenitis). It is managed by elevating the affected extremity and broad-spectrum antibiotics.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was prescribed a diuretic by a doctor for the management of hypertension. The drug acts on the site 'A' in the given image. All the following are adverse effects of the drug, except ______.
questions.solution:
The site 'A' in the given image represents a distal convoluted tubule. Thiazides act on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). The adverse effects are hypokalemia, hyperuricemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypercalcemia.

They block the Na+/Cl- co-transporter in the DCT leading to an increase in Na+ and Cl- excretion. Thiazides are the diuretic of choice for uncomplicated hypertension. They are also used for the treatment of edema associated with congestive heart failure, hepatic cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome, chronic renal failure, and acute glomerulonephritis.

The advantages of thiazide as an antihypertensive are:

  • It can be given as once a day dose and has a flat dose-response curve
  • Decreased incidence of postural hypotension and relative freedom from CNS side effects
  • No tolerance
  • No fluid retention
  • Decreased risk of osteoporotic fractures due to its hypocalciuric action
  • Low cost

The adverse effects include extracellular volume depletion, hypotension, hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hypochloremia, metabolic alkalosis, hypomagnesemia, hypercalcemia, and hyperuricemia.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever, rash and swelling of her hands and feet since the past 5 days. There is desquamative skin rash, edema of hands and feet, erythema of palms and soles, oral erythema, and cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Kawasaki disease or mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.

Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It is commonly seen in infants and children <4 years of age. There is a dense transmural inflammatory infiltrate of medium to the large-sized vessel.

Clinical features include:

  • Fever
  • Conjunctival and oral erythema
  • Blistering, edema of hands and feet
  • Erythema of palms and soles
  • Desquamative rash
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy

The disease is usually self-limiting. In some cases, the disease may involve the coronary artery leading to thrombosis and acute myocardial infarction. Intravenous immunoglobulin and aspirin may be given to reduce the risk of coronary artery disease.

Other options:

Option B: Measles is an acute, highly infectious disease. It is characterized by fever, respiratory symptoms, and a maculopapular rash.

Option C: Scarlet fever is associated with pharyngitis caused by S. pyogenes. It manifests by a punctate erythematous rash that is most prominent over the trunk and inner aspects of the arms and legs. Circumoral pallor is observed. The skin usually becomes hyperkeratotic and scaly during defervescence.

Option D: Henoch-Schönlein purpura is a subtype of acute leukocytoclastic vasculitis that is seen more commonly in children and adolescents following an upper respiratory infection. The patient may present with purpura, colicky abdominal pain, polyarthralgia, and acute glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant was brought to you with complaints of projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeding. On examination, you were able to palpate a firm ovoid mass in the right upper abdominal quadrant. You suspect Infantile Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis and barium contrast studies were performed. The barium study can demonstrate all the following signs, except ______.
questions.solution:
Cervix sign is a USG finding seen in a patient with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis and not a finding of barium study.

The investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis is ultrasound which shows hypoechoic, thickened pyloric muscle and an elongated pyloric canal. The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is referred to as the cervix sign and the double-layered, hypertrophic mucosa protruding into the stomach is called the nipple sign.

If ultrasound is inconclusive, contrast studies (barium) are performed, which may demonstrate:

  • An elongated pyloric channel (string sign),
  • A bulge of the pyloric muscle into the antrum (shoulder sign)
  • Parallel streaks of barium are seen in the narrowed channel, producing a “double tract sign.”

The ultrasound image shows the cervix sign.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented to the emergency with bleeding from the nose. On evaluation, the bleeding site was localized on the lateral wall of the nose. Which of the following arteries is least likely to be involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
The superior labial artery supplies the nasal septum and not the lateral wall of the nose.
 
Blood supply of lateral wall of the nose:
 
Internal carotid system (branches of the ophthalmic artery)
  1. Anterior ethmoidal
  2. Posterior ethmoidal
External carotid system
  1. Posterior lateral nasal branches from the sphenopalatine artery
  2. Greater palatine and lesser palatine arteries from the maxillary artery
  3. Nasal branch of the anterior superior dental from an infraorbital branch of the maxillary artery
  4. Branches of the facial artery to the nasal vestibule

The illustration given below shows the blood supply of the lateral wall of the nose.

Blood supply of nasal septum:
 
Internal carotid system (branches of the ophthalmic artery)
  1. Anterior ethmoidal artery
  2. Posterior ethmoidal artery
External carotid system
  1. The sphenopalatine artery (branch of the maxillary artery) gives nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.
  2. Septal branch of the greater palatine artery (branch of the maxillary artery).
  3. Septal branch of the superior labial artery (branch of a facial artery).

The illustration given below shows the blood supply of the nasal septum.

Related Pearl: Nasal Septum

Septum proper is an osseocartilaginous framework made up of:

  • Septal or quadrilateral cartilage
  • Perpendicular plate of ethmoid
  • Vomer
  • Others – crest of nasal bones, nasal spine of frontal bone, rostrum of sphenoid, crest of palatine bones and the crest maxilla, and the anterior nasal spine of maxilla

questions.text: A 27-year-old female patient comes to the clinic to follow up on managing her obesity. Her body mass index (BMI) is 41. She has increased her physical activity for the last few months and has reduced her caloric intake. She is still unable to lose weight. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Increase intensity of physical exercise regimen

questions.solution:
The best next step in the management of this patient is a referral for bariatric surgery because she has a body mass index-BMI of 41 kg/m2 and has failed to lose weight with conservative methods.

Bariatric surgery should be considered in patients with

  • severe obesity - BMI ≥40, or
  • moderate obesity - BMI ≥35 with severe obesity-related medical conditions 

Bariatric surgery can be classified into restrictive, restrictive-malabsorptive, and malabsorptive. These affect eating behaviors, reduction of appetite, satiety, energy intake, and possibly physical activity.

Surgeries like laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding (LAGB) and laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy restrict the capacity of the stomach and slow emptying.

Surgeries such as roux-en-y gastric bypass, biliopancreatic diversion (BPD), and BPD with a duodenal switch combine the features of restrictive and malabsorptive surgeries, which reduce the surface area and subsequently reduce the absorption of nutrients. 

Bariatric surgery can produce an average of 30-35% weight loss that is maintained up to 5 years after the surgery. It is also successful in reducing comorbid conditions related to obesity like type 2 diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, and hypertension. 

Other options:

Increasing the intensity of the physical exercise regimens (Option A) and increasing caloric deficit (Option D) can be attempted in those with mild to moderate obesity. This patient has already attempted diet and exercise, and it has not been effective. 

Option C - Starting anti-obesity medications should be considered in patients with a BMI of ≥30 or those with a BMI of ≥27 with obesity-related diseases. This patient has better chances of weight loss with surgery than medical therapy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was diagnosed with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and was started on levothyroxine 2 weeks ago. She now presents to your clinic with abdominal pain and dizziness. The left and right images below show her current appearance and her appearance last month, respectively. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image showing skin hyperpigmentation in a patient with severe dizziness and a history of autoimmune thyroiditis points to a diagnosis of Addison’s disease. Hyperglycemia is not a feature of this condition. Hypocortisolism leads to hypoglycemia in these patients.

Addison’s disease is primary adrenal insufficiency characterized by the disruption of glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and androgen secretion. Primary adrenal insufficiency is most commonly caused by autoimmune adrenalitis and coincident autoimmune disease occurring in these patients most frequently includes thyroid autoimmune disease, vitiligo, and premature ovarian failure.

Clinical features of Addison’s disease:

Hormone

Clinical features
Hypoaldosteronism

Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, salt craving
Dizziness, postural hypotension
AKI due to volume depletion
Hyponatremia
Hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis
Hypocortisolism Anorexia, weight loss, fatigue, myalgia, arthralgia
Fever (increased IL-1)
Depression
Postural hypotension
Hypoglycemia
Hyponatremia (loss of feedback inhibition of ADH)
Slightly increased TSH (loss of feedback inhibition)
Hypoandrogenism Loss of libido
  Loss of pubic and axillary hair
Elevated ACTH Hyperpigmentation

Levothyroxine can precipitate adrenal insufficiency or crisis in undiagnosed patients. In patients with concurrent adrenal insufficiency and hypothyroidism, a course of steroids must be given before giving thyroid replacement.

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding the marked structure in the given image of the axilla.

choices.text: It enters the forearm between the 2 heads of supinator
It lies medial to the third part of axillary artery in the axilla
It provides sensory innervation to lateral one and half fingers
It enters the forearm between the 2 heads of pronator teres

questions.solution:
The marked structure is the median nerve and the true statement regarding median nerve is D i.e., it enters the forearm between the 2 heads of the pronator teres.

The median nerve is formed by joining of lateral root (C5, C6, C7) from the lateral cord and medial root (C8, T1) from the medial cord. It lies lateral to the third part of the axillary artery in the axilla and runs down to the arm. It shifts from lateral to medial side and stays medial to brachial artery in the cubital fossa.

It enters the forearm between the 2 heads of the pronator teres. It lies lateral to the ulnar artery and descends through the forearm posterior and is adherent to the flexor digitorum superficialis and anterior flexor digitorum profundus. Just before the wrist, it lies between the tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis and flexor carpi radialis. It then passes deep to the flexor retinaculum into the palm.

The median nerve does not give any branches in the axilla and the arm.

Branches in the forearm:

  • Nerve to pronator teres
  • Nerve to palmaris longus, flexor carpi radialis and flexor digitorum superficialis
  • Anterior interosseous nerve supplying flexor pollicis longus, lateral part of flexor digitorum profundus, and pronator quadratus
  • Palmar cutaneous branch supplying the thenar skin

Branches in the hand:

  • Digital cutaneous branch supplying the lateral three and a half fingers
  • Muscular branches to thenar muscles (except adductor pollicis), 1st and 2nd lumbricals

Other options:

Option A- Posterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the radial nerve passes between the 2 heads of the supinator.

Option B- Ulnar nerve lies medial to the third part of the axillary artery in the axilla.

Option C- Median nerve provides sensory innervation to the lateral three and a half fingers.

Related Pearl: Brachial Plexus

Brachial Plexus

  • C5 to T1
  • Roots (from spinal cord) > Trunks (in the neck)> Divisions (passing behind clavicle) > Cords and Branches (in the axilla).
  • Covered by prevertebral fascia extension called "axillary sheath"

Trunks:

  • Upper trunk: C5 and C6
  • Middle trunk: C7.
  • Lower trunk: C8 and T1

Divisions:

  • Anterior divisions - Forms lateral and medial cords supplying mainly flexors 
  • Posterior divisions - Forms posterior cord which suppy mainly extensors 

Cords:

  • Lateral cord: Formed by anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunks.
  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions 
  • Medial cord: Formed by anterior division of the lower trunk.

Branches: 

 Parts 

Branches

Nerve to Subclavius (C5, C6).

Musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7)

Lateral root of median nerve (C5-C7)
Medial cord (UM4)

Medial pectoral (C8,T1)

Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm (C8,T1)

Medial cutaneous nerve of arm (C8,T1)

Ulnar nerve (C8,T1)

Note : However Ulnar Nerve near its origin, often receives a communicating branch from the lateral root of the median nerve originating from the lateral cord and carrying fibers from C7.

Related Pearl: Compression neuropathies

questions.text: A child with attention deficit hyperactive disorder was prescribed amphetamine in order to increase the attention span and improve behavioral performance. This drug belongs to which category?
questions.solution:
Amphetamine is a CNS stimulant and belongs to schedule X drugs requiring a special license for manufacturing and sales. They have high abuse liability and are to be sold with a valid prescription only.

The Drugs and Cosmetics Rules, 1945 are the set of rules under The Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940 which contains provisions for the classification of drugs under given schedules and there are guidelines for the storage, sale, display, and prescription of each schedule.

Any stereoisomeric form of the substance, any salt of the substance, or the preparations containing the substances specified in this schedule is covered by schedule X.

These drugs include

  • Amobarbital
  • Glutethimide
  • Pentobarbital
  • Ketamine hydrochloride
  • Amphetamine
  • Meprobamate
  • Phencyclidine
  • Barbital
  • Methamphetamine
  • Phenmetrazine
  • Cyclobarbital
  • Dexamphetamine
  • Methylphenidate
  • Secobarbital
  • Ethclorvynol
  • Methylphenobarbital

Related Pearl: Drug regulatory schedules 1940: (2016 update)

Schedule Details
Schedule C Biological and other special products e.g. Toxins, Insulin, Sera & Antibiotics.
Schedule D List of drugs exempted from the provision of import of drugs.
Schedule F

Blood and blood products

F I - Production of Bacterial vaccines, Anti- Sera

F II - Specification of standards for Surgical dressing

FF- Specification of standard Ophthalmic preparation
Schedule G With a label of Caution, dangerous to use except under medical supervision.
Schedule H Prescription drugs.
Schedule J List of diseases that a drug may not prevent or cure. Eg - HIV & Atherosclerosis
Schedule M Regulations regarding good manufacturing practices
Schedule P Regulations regarding the life period and storage of various drugs.
Schedule W Drugs marketed under generic names.
Schedule X Drugs having abuse and dependence liability.
Schedule Y Requirement and guidelines for import/ manufacture or Clinical trials in India

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was admitted to the ICU after major surgery for bowel cancer. Identify the false statement with respect to the test performed on this patient, which is shown below.

choices.text: This test is positive in deep vein thrombosis
The test is positive if there is calf pain on dorsiflexion of foot
It is highly sensitive and specific

questions.solution:
The image shows the method of eliciting Homan’s sign, that is calf pain on forced ankle dorsiflexion seen in deep venous thrombosis (DVT). It is neither sensitive nor specific.

Endothelial injury, hypercoagulability, and stasis of blood are the 3 components of Virchow's triad, which explains the formation of DVT. Postoperative thrombosis is the most common cause.

It presents with pain and swelling of the affected limb. Pitting edema, dilated veins, and low-grade fever are also present. Moses sign—tenderness on gently squeezing the calf—can be elicited. Embolization to the lungs can present as cyanosis, dyspnea, and dilated neck veins.

Duplex ultrasound is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of DVT, which shows filling defects and lack of compressibility.

The patient should be started on anticoagulants like heparin/low-molecular-weight heparin or fondaparinux.

Related Pearl: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1

Three-level score probability:

Well's criteria Score
Low <2
Moderate 2-6
High >6

Two-level score probability:

Modified Well's criteria Score
Pulmonary embolism unlikely ≤4
Pulmonary embolism likely >4 

 

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Venous Thromboembolism

The risk factors for venous thromboembolism (pulmonary embolism and DVT) are as follows:

  • Major trauma like spinal cord injury or fracture of lower limb
  • Surgery like hip or knee replacement
  • Hospitalization for heart failure or atrial fibrillation/flutter within last 3 months
  • Myocardial infarction within last 3 months
  • Previous venous thromboembolism
  • Infections and inflammatory bowel disease
  • Autoimmune diseases:
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA)
    • SLE
  • Inherited thrombophilias:
    • Factor V leiden mutation
    • Deficiency of antithrombin III
    • Deficiency of protein C or protein S
  • Hypercoagulable states:
    • Pregnancy and postpartum period
    • COPD
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Malignancies
  • Iatrogenic:
    • OCPs
    • Hormone replacement therapy
    • Chemotherapeutic drugs
    • Insertion of central venous lines
  • Varicose veins
  • Prolonged car or air travel.

questions.text: A bodybuilder who does strenuous exercises went to the doctor with complaints of muscle cramps. Muscle cramps are due to the accumulation of lactic acid. Which of the following cycles is responsible for preventing lactate accumulation in the muscle?
questions.solution:
Cori's cycle is responsible for preventing lactate accumulation in the muscle.

The process of reconversion of lactate formed in the muscles, back to glucose inside the liver is called Cori's cycle. Lactic acid is a metabolic byproduct formed after anaerobic glycolysis in tissues such as the skeletal muscles and erythrocytes. The lactate so formed is transported into the liver and kidney. Here, it gets reconverted back into pyruvate which can be converted to glucose. This entire process is called Cori’s cycle or the glucose–lactate cycle.

Lactic acid which accumulates in the muscle after strenuous muscle exercises enter Cori's cycle. This process prevents the accumulation of lactate thereby preventing muscle cramps.

Other options

Option A- Cahill cycle is also called as glucose–alanine cycle. In the fasting state, there is a significant output of alanine from muscle as it is the major substrate for gluconeogenesis. Alanine is derived from the transamination of pyruvate obtained from glycolysis. Alanine is then exported to the liver where it undergoes transamination again back to pyruvate and enters gluconeogenesis.

Option C- Krebs cycle, also known as the citric acid cycle, is the final common oxidative pathway that oxidizes acetyl CoA to CO2. It is the source of reduced co-enzymes that provide the substrate for the respiratory chain. It also acts as the link between catabolic and anabolic pathways (amphibolic role).

Option D- The Krebs-Henseleit cycle (urea cycle) is also known as the ornithine cycle. It forms urea by detoxifying ammonia in the liver. The overall reaction may be summarized as NH3 + CO2 + Aspartate → Urea + Fumarate.

Related Pearl: Transport of ammonia in blood (Cahill and Cori cycle)

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with fever and chills for the last 7 days. A peripheral blood smear showed the following feature. Which of the following is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of fever and chills with the image showing band forms in the erythrocyte suggest that P. malariae is the causative agent.

The older trophozoites of P.malariae are sometimes seen stretched across the erythrocyte as a broad band. These band forms are a unique feature of P. malariae. Numerous large pigment granules are also seen. Fine stippling called, Ziemann's stippling may be seen with special stains. P.malariae preferentially infects older erythrocytes and the degree of parasitization is found to be low.

Other options:

Option A: Merozoites of P. vivax preferentially infect reticulocytes and young erythrocytes. Erythrocytes are enlarged and show Schuffner's dots which are red granules. The erythrocytes become irregular in shape, lose their red color, and have a pale appearance.

Option C: Erythrocytes in P. falciparum initially will show a marginal ring form known as accole. Binucleate rings (double chromatin) resembling stereo headphones are commonly seen. The infected erythrocyte is normal in size and shows a few brick-red dots known as Maurer's cleft. Basophilic stippling also can be noted. 

The blood smear in P. falciparum will show multiple ring forms in the erythrocytes as shown below.

Option D: In P.ovale, the trophozoites resemble those in vivax malaria but they are usually more compact with less ameboid appearance. Schuffner's dots appear earlier and are more abundant and prominent than in vivax infection. The infected erythrocytes are enlarged and oval-shaped with fimbriated margins. The schizonts resemble those of P. malariae, except that the erythrocyte is usually oval, with prominent Schuffner's dots and the pigment is darker. 

Related Pearl: Difference between plasmodium species

Feature P.vivax P.ovale P.falciparum P.malaria
Discovered by Grassi & Feletti Stephens Welch Laveran
Erythrocyte preference Reticulocytes Reticulocytes All stages Old erythrocytes
Stages found in peripheral blood Trophozoite, schizonts, gametocytes As in vivax Ring form, accole form, gametocytes Band forms
Infected erythrocyte Enlarged pale with Schuffner’s dots Pear-shaped, fimbriated, Schuffner’s dots (Jame’s dots) Normal size, Maurer’s cleft Normal size, Ziemann’s stippling
Gametocyte Spherical, fills the cell Similar to but smaller than vivax Crescent, Banana shaped Similar to but smaller than vivax
Color of pigment Yellowish-brown Yellowish-brown Black Dark brown
Hypnozoites Present Present Absent Absent
Relapse Yes Yes No No
Average IP(days) 14 14 12 (shortest) 30 (longest)
Duration of erythrocyte cycle(hours) 48 (Benign tertian) 48 (ovale tertian) 48 (malignant tertian) 72(Quartan malaria)
