questions.text: A 35-year-old woman who is a known diabetic with a body mass index of 32 presents to the outpatient department with a skin condition around the neck, as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: It does not regress and is irreversible
It is more common in patients with darker skin.
The most common association is obesity.

questions.solution:
The given image of a obese, diabetic woman with a skin lesion around the neck shows acanthosis nigricans (AN). The false statement regarding this condition is that it does not regress and is irreversible.

The skin condition is characterized by a symmetrical darkening and thickening of the skin with a vel­vety texture. More common in the intertriginous areas, mainly the axillae, groins, submammary folds, and neck. Obesity and insulin resistance is the most common association with AN, and it can regress with weight loss. It is more common in patients with darker skins. 

Other conditions associated with AN:

  • Acromegaly and gigantism
  • Diabetes
  • HAIR-AN syndrome
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome
  • Gastric cancer
  • Gynecological cancer

Familial AN is rare and transmitted as an autosomal dominant trait.

Histology shows hyperkeratosis and finger‐like upward projections of der­mal papillae called papillomatosis. Pigmentation is due to hyperkeratosis and there is no increase in melanocyte numbers or in melanin production. 

Treatment of the underlying condition is the mainstay. AN associated with obesity responds to dietary restriction and weight loss. The cosmetic appear­ance of the condition can be treated with: 

  • First line: Topical retinoids act by reducing hyperkeratosis.
  • Second line: Topical keratolytics like salicylic acid are used.
  • Third line: Oral isotretinoin is used for extensive cases.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient is brought with ataxia. He recalls an episode of diarrhea last week. On examination, the patient has the eye findings shown below and absent knee jerk reflexes. Which of the following is true about this patient's condition?

choices.text: Antibodies against a ganglioside component will be present
The preceding diarrhea is unrelated to the condition
Electrodiagnostic study will reveal increased sensory response

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of ataxia, absent knee jerk, fixed and dilated pupil, and a history of diarrhea is likely to have Miller-Fisher syndrome (MFS). MFS is a variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). In MFS, antibodies are seen against GQ1b, which is a ganglioside component of the nerve.

GBS is progressive, symmetric muscle weakness with absent or reduced deep tendon reflexes of variable severity. It is typically an ascending paralysis that may lead to severe respiratory muscle weakness.

In MFS, like GBS, symptoms may be preceded by a viral illness (upper respiratory tract infections or diarrhea). It classically presents as a triad of

  • Ataxia
  • Areflexia
  • Ophthalmoplegia.

The condition is usually not associated with weakness, and even if present, is very mild. It is strongly associated with antibodies to ganglioside. The prognosis for Miller-Fisher syndrome is usually good. Recovery occurs in 8-12 weeks. Some individuals are left with residual deficits. 

Electrodiagnostic studies will reveal reduced or absent sensory responses without slowing the conduction velocity. Motor nerve conduction abnormalities may be present if there is associated weakness. 

Treatment for Miller-Fisher syndrome is identical to treatment for Guillain-Barré syndrome: intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis and supportive care.

Related Pearl: Antibodies seen in Guillian Barre syndrome

Type Antibody
AIDP Anti GM1
AMAN Anti GD1a
AMSAN Anti GD1a
Miller Fisher syndrome Anti GQ1b
  • AIDP-Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy 
  • AMAN-Acute motor axonal neuropathy 
  • AMSAN-Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy

questions.text: In the given dose-response curve, which drug has the maximum potency?
questions.solution:
In the given dose-response curve (DRC), drug B has the maximum potency.

Potency

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response.
  • The more the curve is on the left side, the more its potency.
  • Hence in the given DRC drug B is the most potent and drug D is the least potent.

Efficacy

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug and is determined by the peak of the curve.
  • Hence in the given DRC, drug B has the least efficacy, and drugs A, C & D are equally efficacious.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man presents with sudden-onset loose stools, vomiting, and muscular cramps. Stools were colorless, like rice water, and had an inoffensive sweetish odor. Identify the false statement regarding the causative agent.

TCBS - Thiosulfate citrate bile salt sucrose

choices.text: Cary-Blair medium is used as a transport media
The toxin acts on GM2 ganglioside receptor
The organism has a polar flagellum

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of sudden onset colorless rice watery, stools having an inoffensive sweetish odor is indicative of cholera and the causative agent is Vibrio cholerae. The toxin produced binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells, not GM2 receptors.

They are gram-negative and typically comma-shaped. They show darting motility with a single-sheathed polar flagellum. They are facultative anaerobes and produce large yellow convex colonies on the thiosulphate citrate bile salt sucrose (TCBS) medium.

Following are the special media used for V. cholera:

1. Holding or transporting media:

  • Venkatraman Ramakrishnan (VR) medium
  • Cary-Blair medium- It is a suitable transport medium for vibrios, Salmonella, and Shigella.
  • Autoclaved seawater

2. Enrichment media like Monsur's taurocholate tellurite peptone water 

3. Plating media

  • Alkaline bile salt agar
  • Monsur's gelatin taurocholate trypticase tellurite agar (GTTA)
  • Thiosulphate citrate bile salt sucrose agar (colonies shown in the image below)

Vibrio colonies may be identified by the 'string test,' where a loopful of the growth is mixed with a drop of 0.5% sodium deoxycholate in saline on a slide. The suspension loses its turbidity, becomes mucoid, and forms a 'string' when the loop is drawn away slowly in a positive test.

Vibrios multiply in the intestinal epithelium and produce an enterotoxin called cholera toxin (CT), which is very similar to the heat-labile toxin (LT) of Escherichia coli, although CT is far more potent than LT in biological activity. The toxin molecule consists of 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B (binding) units attach to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. The A (active) subunit causes prolonged activation of cellular adenylate cyclase and accumulation of cAMP, leading to the outpouring of large quantities of water and electrolytes into the small intestinal lumen and the consequent watery diarrhea.

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

Bacillus cereus Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Meat, vegetables, dried beans, cereals
>16 hrs incubation period

Salmonella species Inflammatory diarrhea Beef, poultry, eggs

Enterohemorrhagic E. coli Bloody diarrhea Raw milk, raw vegetables, apple juice

  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: A child developed a fever, headache, and a diffuse rash, as shown below. The rash is most prominent on the face and chest. He says the rash is very itchy bothering his everyday life. Considering the rash infectivity, until when would you advise him to stay isolated?

choices.text: 4 days after the appearance of lesions
10 days after the appearance of lesions
14 days after the appearance of lesions
After crust formation has occurred over lesions

questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of chickenpox caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV). You would advise the boy to stay isolated until after crust formation has occurred over lesions. People with chickenpox are contagious 24-48 hours before the rash is evident and until the vesicles have crusted, which is usually 3-7 days after the onset of the rash.

Aerosolization of the virus present in cutaneous lesions leads to the spread of VZV. The spread of the virus via oropharyngeal secretions occurs to a much lesser extent. Susceptible persons thus acquire varicella after close, direct contact with adults or children who have herpes zoster. For this reason, isolation is recommended during the period of infectivity until after crust formation has occurred over lesions.

Varicella lesions often appear on the scalp, face, or trunk first. The initial exanthems are intensely pruritic erythematous macules that evolve through the papular stage to form clear, fluid-filled vesicles. The distribution of the rash is predominantly central or centripetal. Clouding and umbilication of the lesions begin in 24-48 hr. New crops form on the trunk and then the extremities while the initial lesions are crusting. This simultaneous presence of lesions in various stages of evolution is characteristic of varicella.

Disease

Until all lesions are crusted – usually about 6 days after onset of rash.

From the onset of symptoms (catarrhal stage) to 5 days after the appearance of the rash

Until 3 days of tetracycline therapy.

Diphtheria 

Until 48 hours of antibiotics.

Shigellosis and salmonellosis

Until 3 consecutive negative stool cultures.

Hepatitis A

3 weeks.

Influenza

3 days after onset.

Polio

2 weeks in adult; 6 weeks in children.

Tuberculosis (sputum +)

Until 3 weeks of effective chemotherapy.

6 days after onset of rash.

Until the swelling subsides.

4 weeks or until paroxysms cease.

questions.text: A middle-aged man is found to have elevated liver transaminases. His liver biopsy image is given below. These inclusions are periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant. Which of the following condition is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The presence of PAS-positive and diastase-resistant inclusion bodies in the hepatocytes is suggestive of α1 antitrypsin deficiency. This condition is associated with panacinar type of emphysema.

α1-antitrypsin (α1AT) deficiency is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding that results in impaired secretion of α1 antitrypsin (α1AT) into the serum. It causes liver disease due to the abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes. In neonates, it rapidly progresses to cirrhosis and in adults, it presents with chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis, or hepatocellular carcinoma. Liver biopsy shows round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes that are strongly periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant. Liver transplantation is curative in liver disease, but it won’t help in treating panacinar emphysema.

Deficiency of α1AT protein results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase causing panacinar emphysema. In this type, the acini from the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli are uniformly enlarged.

Other options:

Option A: Bronchial asthma is characterized by chronic airway inflammation and variable expiratory airflow obstruction. The patient presents with symptoms such as wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and cough, which vary over time and in intensity.

Option B: Cryptogenic Organizing Pneumonia is associated with viral and bacterial pneumonia, inhaled toxins, drugs, connective tissue disease, and graft-versus-host disease in hematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients. The patient presents with a cough and dyspnea. Histologically, it is characterized by polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue (Masson bodies) within alveolar ducts, alveoli, and often bronchioles.

 Option D: Centriacinar emphysema occurs predominantly in heavy smokers with COPD. In this type of emphysema, the central or proximal parts of the acini, formed by respiratory bronchioles, are affected, whereas distal alveoli are spared.

Related Pearl: Types of emphysema

Emphysema is classified according to its anatomic distribution within the lobule.

Type Area involved Other features

Centriacinar (most common)
  • Central part of acinus (respiratory bronchiole)
  • Upper lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in smokers
Panacinar
  • Entire acinus (respiratory bronchiole + alveoli)
  • Lower lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in young non-smokers
  • Associated with α-1 antitrypsin deficiency
Paraseptal
  • Distal part of acinus (alveoli)
  • Subpleural region
  • Commonly seen in young adults 
  • Increased risk for spontaneous pneumothorax 
Irregular
  • Focal and irregular involvement of acinus
  • Areas of the lung near scar tissue 
  • Not usually seen in COPD

questions.text: A young girl presented to the OPD for examination. She is tall and thin with slender fingers, and dislocated lenses. Workup revealed cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency. Which amino acid supplement is required in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a tall and thin young girl with slender fingers, dislocated lenses, and cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency is suggestive of classic homocystinuria. The amino acid supplement required in this scenario is cysteine.

Classic homocystinuria is a metabolic disorder of methionine metabolism, due to cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency. It is an autosomal recessive condition.

Cystathionine beta-synthase is a pyridoxal phosphate-dependent enzyme that condenses homocysteine with serine to form cystathionine. The absence of this enzyme will cause cysteine deficiency, hence cysteine needs to be supplemented in the diet.

Clinical features:

  • Affected children are initially asymptomatic. 
  • Ectopia lentis (subluxation of the lens) is seen first, after 3 years of age.
  • Intellectual disability and psychiatric and behavioral disorders.
  • Thromboembolic episodes.
  • Skeletal abnormalities resembling those of Marfan syndrome: They are tall and thin with elongated limbs and arachnodactyly (slender fingers).

Elevations of both methionine and homocysteine in body fluids are the diagnostic laboratory findings. The diagnosis is established by molecular analysis of cystathionine β-synthase (CBS) or by assay of the enzyme in cultured fibroblasts, phytohemagglutinin-stimulated lymphocytes, or liver biopsy specimens. Treatment includes restriction of methionine intake and supplementation with cysteine, betaine, vitamins B6, B12, and folate.

 

The image below shows arachnodactyly. 

 Methionine supplementation is required in non-classical homocystinuria. It is due to impaired re-methylation of homocysteine to methionine. This can be caused by defective methionine synthase or reduced availability of two essential cofactors, 5-methyltetrahydrofolate, and methylcobalamin.

Elevated homocysteine levels with low levels of methionine will be seen. Treatment includes methionine supplementation and administration of methyl folate, hydroxocobalamin, and betaine.

Related Pearl: Homocystinuria

The concept for treatment:

  • Since homocysteine is produced from methionine, decreased dietary intake of methionine decreases the formation of homocysteine.
  • As the end product of this cycle is cysteine, increased dietary intake of cysteine will decrease the conversion of methionine to homocysteine through negative feedback.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe burning with urination for the past 3 days. He has also had a clear urethral discharge. He is sexually active but uses condoms inconsistently. Gram stain of a urethral swab shows neutrophils but no organisms. The organism was isolated on cell culture and a Giemsa stain was done as shown below. Which among the following statements is incorrect regarding the causative organism?

choices.text: It is a facultative intracellular organism.
The elementary body is the infectious form.
McCoy cell line is used to isolate chlamydia.
Infection with this organism can be treated with azithromycin.

questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is indicative of urethritis due to Chlamydia trachomatis. Therefore, the incorrect statement is option A. Chlamydia trachomatis is an obligate intracellular organism.  

Chlamydia is coccobacilli that lack the enzymes for ATP synthesis and are hence dependent entirely on the host cell, making them obligate intracellular organisms (not facultatively intracellular). As they are dependent on host cells for ATP synthesis, they can be grown in McCoy cells. McCoy cells are treated with cycloheximide to isolate chlamydia.  

They can exist in two states-

  • Extracellular form called the elementary body. The elementary body is the infectious form.
  • Intracellular form called the reticulate body. These reticulate bodies are found inside a membrane-bound compartment called the "inclusion body" which can be visualized within infected epithelial cells. The given image shows Giemsa stained urethral discharge smear revealing the cytoplasmic inclusion bodies of Chlamydia.

Different serovars cause a variety of diseases, of which D to K cause genital tract diseases. Biovars A, B, and C cause trachoma while L1, L2, and L3 cause lymphogranuloma venereum.

The investigation of choice is the nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT). 

Treatment includes antibiotic therapy with azithromycin or doxycycline. Sexual partners should also be treated.

questions.text: FIGLU (Formiminoglutamic acid) excretion test is used in the assessment of the deficiency of which of the following vitamins?
questions.solution:
FIGLU excretion test is used in the assessment of deficiency of Vitamin B9 (Folic acid).

FIGLU is converted to L-glutamate by the enzyme glutamate formimino transferase. This enzyme uses folate (vitamin B9). In Vitamin B9 deficiency, FIGLU accumulates in the body and is excreted in the urine.

Folic acid is a water-soluble vitamin, and its active form is tetrahydrofolate (THFA). It acts as a carrier of one-carbon groups. These one-carbon groups are attached either to the 5th, 10th, or both 5th and 10th nitrogen atoms of THFA.

The methyl group in N5-methyl THFA is used for the synthesis of active methionine. This takes part in transmethylation reactions required for the synthesis of choline, epinephrine, creatine, etc.

Folate deficiency results in

  • Reduced synthesis of DNA
  • Macrocytic anemia
  • Hyperhomocysteinemia
  • Neural tube defects in the fetus like spina bifida

questions.text: Identify the muscle marked by the red arrow and its nerve supply.

choices.text: Mylohyoid; posterior division of mandibular nerve
Medial pterygoid; trunk of mandibular nerve
Lateral pterygoid; anterior division of mandibular nerve
Masseter; anterior division of mandibular nerve

questions.solution:
The marked muscle is the medial pterygoid muscle. It is innervated by the trunk of the mandibular nerve, which is a branch of the trigeminal nerve.

The medial pterygoid is a part of muscles of mastication. The muscle is identified by the lingual nerve, which runs on the surface of the medial pterygoid. The motor innervation for the muscles of mastication arises from the special visceral efferent column in the pons. 

The mandibular nerve is the largest branch of the trigeminal nerve and is a mixed nerve. It gives sensory innervation to the teeth and gums of the mandible, skin in the temporal region, part of the auricle, lower lip, the lower part of the face, anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and the oral cavity. The motor innervation is given to the muscles of mastication, tensor veli palatini, tensor tympani, mylohyoid and anterior belly of digastric.

The mandibular nerve, after supplying the medial pterygoid, divides into anterior and posterior divisions. 

Muscles of mastication

Medial pterygoid:

It has two heads. The deep head arises from the medial surface of the lateral pterygoid plate of the sphenoid bone and the superficial head arises from the maxillary tuberosity and the pyramidal process of the palatine bone. It is inserted into the posteroinferior part of the medial surface of the ramus and the angle of the mandible.

Its main actions are elevation of the mandible/ closing of the mouth, jaw protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the mandible. It is innervated by the trunk of the mandibular nerve.

 

Lateral pterygoid:

It has two heads. The upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and the infratemporal crest of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, capsule, and the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint.

Its main actions are depression of the mandible/ opening of the mouth, jaw protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the mandible. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

 

Temporalis:

It arises from the temporal fossa up to the inferior temporal line and temporal fascia. It is inserted into the coronoid process and the anterior border of the mandibular ramus. It causes elevation of mandible/ closing of the mouth, jaw retraction, and side-to-side movement of the mandible. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

 

Masseter:

It arises from the zygomatic arch and from a thick aponeurosis from the maxillary process of the zygomatic bone. It is inserted into the angle and lower posterior half of the lateral surface of the mandibular ramus. Its main actions are elevation of the mandible/ closing of the mouth and jaw protrusion. It is innervated by the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is diagnosed with gastric carcinoma and is planned for a D1 gastrectomy. Which of the following group of lymph nodes are resected in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Lymph nodes around the gastroepiploic artery are the lymph nodes around the greater curvature and are routinely resected in D1 gastrectomy.

Gastric cancer surgery involves removing the primary tumor and lymph nodes.

Depending on the extent of lymph node stations removed, the surgery may be either  D1 or D2 gastrectomy. A D1 resection involves the removal of the perigastric nodes and a D2 resection involves the clearance of the major arterial trunks. 

The lymph node stations are

  1. Right paracardiac
  2. Left paracardiac
  3. Lesser curvature
  4. Greater curvature
    • Short gastric
    • Left gastroepiploic
    • Right gastroepiploic
  5. Suprapyloric
  6. Infrapyloric
  7. Left gastric artery
  8. Anterior hepatic artery
  9. Coeliac axis
  10. Splenic hilum
  11. Splenic artery

The D1 gastrectomy involves the removal of lymph node stations 1-6. The D2 gastrectomy involves the removal of lymph node stations 1-11.

questions.text: Maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for a country is best given as:
questions.solution:
The maternal mortality ratio is the number of maternal deaths in a given period per 100,000 live births during the same period.

Maternal death is defined as

  • Death of a woman while pregnant.
  • Death during delivery or within 42 days (6 weeks) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of duration or site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

MMR = (No. of maternal deaths in a given year/Total no. of live births in the same year) x 100,000

In a developing country like India, maternal mortality is a huge public health issue. The most common causes are postpartum hemorrhage and infections, which mainly occur when women do not give birth at hospitals or health centers.

The main contributor to a decline in maternal mortality is the rise in institutional deliveries.

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

The main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor, and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia-related complications, etc.

In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

questions.text: A child is brought to your clinic with complaints of diarrhea and abdominal pain. The stool microscopy image is given below. Eggs were non-bile stained and floated in the saturated salt solution. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the organism?

choices.text: It hatches in the small intestine.
Praziquantel is the drug of choice for infection with this organism.

questions.solution:
The given clinical history along with the given image implicates the most likely organism to be Hymenolepis nana. The incorrect statement is option C.

Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) is the smallest tapeworm. Humans are the definitive host. It has no intermediate host. It occurs more commonly in children and the patient acquires this infection by ingesting food or water contaminated with its eggs. The egg attaches to the intestine and develops into the larva and adult worm. The adult worm resides in the small intestine.  

Patients are usually asymptomatic. But in heavy infections, they present with nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and irritability. Pruritus may also be present due to an allergic response.

It can also cause autoinfection. Internal autoinfection occurs when the eggs are released in the intestine and hatch there. External autoinfection occurs through the ingestion of the eggs by the fecal-oral route. They hatch in the small intestine to release the hexacanth embryo which penetrates the intestinal villus resulting in autoinfection.

The image given below shows the egg of Hymenolepis nana.

The eggs are non-bile stained and float in the saturated salt solution. They have a thin colorless outer membrane and thread-like polar filaments on stool microscopy. They have a hexacanth embryo. 

Praziquantel is the drug of choice for infection with H. nana. 

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

Related Pearl: Parasites with bile-stained eggs

The following are the parasites with bile-stained eggs. (mnemonic: FaT CAT)

  • Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke)
  • Fasciolopsis buski (giant intestinal fluke)
  • Trichuris trichiura (whipworm)
  • Clonorchis sinensis (chinese liver fluke, oriental liver fluke)
  • Ascaris lumbricoides (round worm)
  • Taenia solium (pork tapeworm)
  • Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm)

Related Pearl: Helminth eggs that float in saturated salt solution

The following are the helminths whose eggs float in a saturated salt solution. (mnemonic: THE FAN)

  • Trichuris trichiura
  • Hymenolepis nana
  • Enterobius vermicularis
  • Fertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides
  • Ancylostoma duodenale
  • Necator americanus.

questions.text: Oral digoxin is being given to a 65-year-old male patient with congestive heart failure as a maintenance dose to gradually digitalize him. A target plasma concentration of 0.70 ng/mL is decided upon. The digoxin clearance for this particular individual is calculated as 60 mL/min. Knowing that the oral bioavailability of digoxin is 70%, what is the dosing rate in this patient?
questions.solution:
The dosing rate in this patient is 60 ng/min.

The oral bioavailability of digoxin is 70% (F = 0.7) and the required target plasma concentration (Cp) is 0.70 ng/mL. CL is the clearance of digoxin which is 60 mL/min.

Hence, the appropriate dose rate for this patient can be calculated as:

Dosing rate = Target Cp x CL/F

= [0.70 ng/mL × 60 mL/min] ÷ [0.7]

= 60 ng/min

questions.text: A female patient presents with fever, odynophagia, and trismus. Her oral cavity examination appears as shown in the image given below. She was diagnosed with a peritonsillar abscess. Where does the pus usually get collected in this condition?

choices.text: Between the alar fascia and the prevertebral fascia
Between the capsule of tonsil and the superior constrictor muscle
Between the alar fascia and the superior constrictor muscle
Between the capsule of tonsil and the inferior constrictor muscle

questions.solution:
The site of collection of pus in quinsy/ peritonsillar abscess is between the capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscle.

Peritonsillar abscess or quinsy is a collection of pus in the peritonsillar space which lies between the capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscle. It usually follows an episode of acute tonsillitis when the crypta magna gets infected and gets sealed off. An intratonsillar abscess then forms which then bursts through the capsule to reach the peritonsillar space.

The illustration given below shows structures forming a tonsillar bed.

It presents with marked odynophagia such that the patient cannot even swallow his saliva which dribbles from the angle of his mouth. The patient is usually dehydrated. Other features include a muffled and thick speech, often called a hot potato voice, sore throat, ipsilateral otalgia, torticollis, and fever.

On examination, the tonsil, pillars, and soft palate are congested and enlarged. The uvula is congested and edematous and pushed to the opposite side. Mucopus covering the tonsil is seen. Jugulodigastric lymph nodes are enlarged and tender.

CECT, submandibular ultrasonography, and MRI are better suited for visualizing the abscess and its extent. Submandibular ultrasonography is also helpful for incision and drainage.

Management of peritonsillar abscess:

  • Hospitalization
  • Intravenous fluids to address dehydration
  • High-dose intravenous antibiotics to cover aerobes and anaerobes
  • Analgesics for pain relief
  • Drainage by needle aspiration or incision and drainage
  • Tonsillectomy when there is airway obstruction or recurrence.

Incision and drainage of the abscess at the point of the maximum bulge above the upper pole of the tonsil or just lateral to the point of junction of the anterior pillar with a line drawn through the base of the uvula.

The image given below shows the site of the incision in the peritonsillar abscess.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was brought to the emergency in an unconscious state. He had a fever for the past two days and is a known case of severe COPD. His ECG is given below. What is the mechanism behind this condition?

choices.text: Automaticity of multiple foci in the atrium
Macro re-entry circuit in the right atrium

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of chronic pulmonary disease and the ECG showing different P wave morphologies are suggestive of multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT). The mechanism triggering multifocal atrial tachycardia is the automaticity of multiple atrial foci.

The given ECG shows narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals; hence, it can be atrial fibrillation or multifocal atrial tachycardia. The next step is to look at the p waves. Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is characterized by at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies (shown by arrows in the image). However, in atrial fibrillation, there would be no distinct p waves seen.

 

Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) occurs due to impulses arising from multiple abnormal foci in the atria. This leads to supraventricular tachycardia with p waves and QRS complexes of different morphologies. It is usually encountered in patients with chronic pulmonary disease and acute illness.  

Identifying features in ECG:

  • Heart rate > 100, typically between 100 and 150 beats/min
  • Irregular rhythm
  • Narrow QRS complex
  • Discrete P waves with more than 3 different morphologies 
  • Variable PR interval

Therapy for MAT is directed at treating the underlying disease and correcting any metabolic abnormalities. The calcium channel blockers verapamil or diltiazem are useful in slowing the atrial and ventricular rates. Radiofrequency ablation of the AV node is another treatment modality. Cardioversion is ineffective. 

Other options:

Option A - Increased atrial automaticity is seen in atrial tachycardia, which is a narrow-complex tachycardia in which abnormal P-wave morphology is observed. It can lead to an AV block if the rate is too rapid.

Option C - Atrial flutter is characterized by a macro re-entry circuit in the right atrium, which is usually encircling the tricuspid annulus. ECG shows characteristic saw-tooth flutter waves.

Option D - Abnormal bands of conductive tissue between the atria and ventricles are seen in atrioventricular re-entrant tachycardia. ECG shows a characteristic delta wave in the presence of these accessory pathways.

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: Which among the following options does not depict the type of inhibition shown in the graph?

choices.text: BAL as an antidote for heavy metal poisoning

questions.solution:
The given image shows a Lineweaver-Burk plot of non-competitive inhibition. Among the given options, all are examples of non-competitive inhibition, except methotrexate on folate reductase enzyme, which is an example of competitive inhibition.

Noncompetitive inhibitors bind to enzymes in locations remote from the active site. So, the degree of inhibition is based upon the concentration of the inhibitor, and increasing the substrate concentrations does not compete with or change the inhibition. Therefore, in noncompetitive inhibition, Vmax decreases while Km usually remains the same. Noncompetitive inhibition is usually irreversible.

Competitive inhibition is when the active site or catalytic site of an enzyme is occupied by a substance other than the substrate of that enzyme, and its activity is inhibited. Competitive inhibition is reversible, and the inhibition is abolished by increasing the substrate concentration. In Competitive inhibition, Vmax remains constant but Km increases.

The Graph showing the changes in Vmax and Km in competitive and noncompetitive inhibition is given below.

Related Pearl: Difference between Reversible and Irreversible Inhibitors

Reversible Inhibitors

Irreversible Inhibitors

Binds via non-covalent interaction

Binds via covalent interactions

No chemical change

Inhibitor binds to the substrate & prevent catalytic activity of enzymes

Can be reversed, as there is no bonding between the inhibitor & substrate

Irreversibility due to strong covalent bonding

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with a fever and swelling of his hands after playing football. He has a history of similar episodes of dactylitis in the past and also frequently complains of fatigue. On imaging, his spleen was found to be shrunken. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the peripheral smear showing sickle-shaped cells is suggestive of sickle cell disease.

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to the point mutation in the β-globin gene, which results in the replacement of glutamate residue with valine. This causes the production of sickle-shaped red blood cells due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS).

Factors that predispose to sickling are infection, dehydration, and acidosis.

The clinical features of sickle cell disease are due to the tendency of HbS molecules to stack into polymers when deoxygenated.

Clinical features:

  • Moderately severe hemolytic anemia with jaundice
  • Painful bone crisis - hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis of the bones of hands and feet.
  • Acute chest syndrome - Typically presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates.
  • Hyposthenuria- inability to concentrate urine.
  • The aplastic crisis stems from the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Spleen
    • In children- splenic sequestration crises occur which results in splenomegaly due to red pulp congestion.
    •         Adolescence or early adulthood- autosplenectomy occurs due to splenic infarction, fibrosis, and progressive shrinkage.
    • Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococcal, meningococcal, and Haemophilus influenzae septicemia, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.
  • Other clinical features- priapism, leg ulcers, stroke, retinopathy, pigment gallstones, and growth retardation.

The diagnosis is suggested by the clinical findings, the presence of irreversibly sickled red cells on the peripheral smear, and hemoglobin electrophoresis showing increased HbA2 and HbF and S spike. The changes in the skull resemble a crewcut in radiographic studies as a result of compensatory erythroid hyperplasia.

The image given below shows the sickling of RBCs in sickle cell disease.

The image given below shows Howell-Jolly bodies seen in asplenia.

Note: The sickle cell trait protects against falciparum malaria in certain African populations.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with fungal infection of the sinuses and periorbital region, with significant visual impairment, as shown below. Vascular involvement and thrombosis are seen in the biopsy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The description of the patient typically resembles the presentation of invasive mucormycosis in the form of orbital cellulitis.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection in diabetes mellitus, leukemia, and lymphoma patients. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus oryza.

The agents of zygomycosis are angioinvasive. The major clinical form is rhinocerebral mucormycosis. It results from the germination of the sporangiospores in the nasal passages of patients with reduced host defense. From there, they enter the blood vessels and proliferate in the walls of blood vessels. This causes thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. The disease progress to invade the paranasal sinuses, eyes, cranial bone, and brain. It damages blood vessels and nerves, thereby developing edema of the involved facial area, a bloody nasal exudate, and orbital cellulitis.

A culture of nasal discharge, tissue, or sputum will show broad hyphae with uneven thickness, irregular branching, and sparse septations.

Treatment includes aggressive surgical debridement, rapid administration of amphotericin B, and control of the underlying disease.

Other options:

Option A: Coccidioidomycosis primarily includes pulmonary infection. It is caused by Coccidioides immitis. A self-limited influenza-like fever may occur in some individuals. Disseminated disease is seen in less than 1% of the people

Option B: Histoplasmosis is caused by Histoplasma capsulatum. It presents as a pulmonary disease that resembles tuberculosis. Disseminated histoplasmosis involves infection of the reticuloendothelial system which manifests as lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and anemia.

Option D: Aspergillosis is a spectrum of diseases that are caused by a number of Aspergillus species. It can either present as allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, aspergilloma, or invasive aspergillosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with acute bleeding following delivery in the ambulance. On examination, a perineal tear was observed involving the anal sphincter and anal mucosa. The bleeding has been controlled. When is the ideal time to perform sphincter reconstructive surgery?
questions.solution:
As the patient was delivered in the ambulance on the way to the hospital, she has presented immediately (within 24 hours) with a complete perineal tear. Sphincter reconstructive surgery must be performed immediately.

A tear of the perineal body involving the sphincter ani externus with or without the involvement of anorectal mucosa is termed a complete perineal tear. Complete perineal tears (3rd or 4th-degree tears) that were not repaired in the first 24 hours should be operated on between 3-6 months after delivery.

In 3 months, local infection would subside with improvement in the general condition of the patient and baby can also be kept at home. Beyond 6 months, due to excessive fibrosis at the margin, it becomes inconvenient for the patient.

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Second-degree

Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male patient presented with episodic wheezing, breathlessness, and cough. He was diagnosed with mild asthma with intermittent symptoms. According to GINA 2022 guidelines, what is the initial recommendation for treating this patient?

GINA - Global Initiative for Asthma
questions.solution:
According to GINA 2022 guidelines, beclomethasone with formoterol is preferred for mild asthma with intermittent symptoms.

Asthma is a respiratory condition characterized by reversible airflow obstruction. GINA recommends the treatment of asthma with low-dose inhaled corticosteroids with formoterol. Short-acting beta-agonists are associated with increased exacerbations.  

Low-dose inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) are found to have reduced hospitalizations, death, and exercise-induced bronchoconstriction and can improve lung function. 

Thus, adults or adolescents with asthma should be started on low-dose ICS with formoterol as needed. If there are multiple episodes during the week or the patient is waking up with asthma more than once a week, then maintenance therapy with the same can be started. 

Other options: 

Option B - Albuterol is a bronchodilator that is a short-acting beta 2 agonist (SABA). It is no longer recommended for treatment for asthma as regular use increases allergic responses, airway inflammation, and reduces the bronchodilator response during exacerbations. 

Option C - Beclomethasone alone is generally not prescribed as it is a combination of low-dose ICS with formoterol. 

Option D - Beclomethasone (ICS) and albuterol (SABA) can be given as an alternative in the form of regular low-dose ICS with as-needed SABA when the preferred treatment is not possible. However, the current guidelines prefer formoterol.

Related Pearl: Treatment of Asthma based on severity of symptoms (GINA-2022)

Asthma management - GINA 2022

questions.text: A 60-year-old man came to you with a white growth over the cornea, as shown in the image. Which of the following features can be seen associated with it?
questions.solution:
The given image shows pterygium. Stocker's line can be seen associated with a pterygium. It is a linear deposition of iron seen in the corneal epithelium, anterior to the head of a pterygium.

Pterygium is a wing-shaped, triangular fibrovascular ingrowth of degenerative conjunctival tissue that can encroach onto the cornea. It occurs as a response to prolonged exposure to ultraviolet rays, dry heat, etc.

It has 3 parts, a head (apical part on the cornea), a body (the part between the limbus and canthus), and a cap (semilunar white infiltrate in front of the head).

Patients may complain of irritation and grittiness due to localized drying effects. If the pterygium encroaches onto the pupillary area, it may interfere with vision and also induce astigmatism.

This condition can be treated symptomatically with tear substitutes for dry eye symptoms, and patients are advised to avoid ultraviolet rays. Surgical excision with free conjunctival limbal autograft is the preferred treatment to avoid recurrence. 

Other options:

Option B: Concretions are tiny cysts containing deposits of epithelial debris and may occur due to old age or in association with trachoma. 

Option C: Arcus senilis is an annular lipid infiltration in the peripheral cornea. It is an age age-related change that usually occurs bilaterally.

Option D: Busacca nodules are iris nodules seen in anterior uveitis.

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the labor room at 40 weeks of gestation with lower abdominal pain. She has been in labor for 3 hours. Which of the following will determine if she is in active labor?

choices.text: Fetal head 5/5ths palpable on abdominal examination
More than 3 cm cervical dilatation with incomplete effacement
Contractions lasting for 45 seconds in a minute

questions.solution:
This patient will have presented in active labor if she had contractions lasting for 45 seconds in a minute.

The first symptom to appear in labor is intermittent painful uterine contractions, followed by the expulsion of blood-stained mucus (show) per vagina. As labor progresses from latent to active, the contractions last 30-90 seconds and the intervals in-between decrease. In the late first stage, the contraction comes at intervals of 3–5 minutes and lasts 45 seconds. 

≥12 contractions per hour without ruptured membranes may signify active labor.

Partograph is charted every half an hour recording the number of contractions in 10 minutes and the duration of each contraction in seconds. Contractions can be classified as mild (< 20 seconds), moderate (20–40 seconds), and strong (>40 seconds). 

The first stage of labor is characterized by dilatation and effacement of the cervix and can be divided into latent phase and active labor. The onset of latent labor is the point at which the mother perceives regular contractions. Cervical dilatation of ≥5 cm in the presence of uterine contractions can be taken to reliably represent the threshold for active labor.

The second stage of labor begins with complete cervical dilatation and ends with fetal delivery.

The third stage of labor is characterized by the delivery of the placenta.

The fourth stage is a stage of observation for at least an hour after the full expulsion of the placenta.

Other options:

Option A: Fetal head palpable 5/5ths on abdominal examination signifies the degree of descent in relation to the pelvic inlet and denotes the head is floating above the brim.

Option D: Rupture of membranes at or near term signifies that labor is likely to begin soon.

 

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: During rounds in the postnatal ward, you notice a patient's case sheet mentioning she had uterine tachysystole following labor induction. What is the criteria for this diagnosis?

choices.text: More than  5 contractions in a 5-min period
More than 5 contractions in a 10-min period
More than 10 contractions in a 5-min period
More than 10 contractions in a 10-min period

questions.solution:
Uterine tachysystole is defined as >5 contractions in a 10 min period and may occur in spontaneous or stimulated labor. It should always be qualified by the presence or absence of fetal heart rate abnormalities. Tachysystole interrupts maternal blood flow to the placenta during contractions and may lead to a reduction in fetal oxygenation. It is also associated with placental abruption.

It is caused by pharmacological agents used for cervical ripening and induction such as misoprostol (both oral and vaginal) and dinoprostone. Management includes stopping oxytocin infusion and terbutaline 0.25 mg SC.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child complains of mild painful swelling over the scalp with pus discharge for 3 months, as shown in the image below. On examination, a thick-crusted inflammatory mass with pus discharge is seen. What is the diagnosis of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the condition based on the image and examination findings is kerion. It is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis. 

Tinea capitis is a dermatophyte infection primarily occurring in children involving the hair shafts.

 Clinical variants of tinea capitis:

  • Endothrix - It is a non-inflammatory type in which multiple black dots are present within the areas of alopecia. It is most commonly caused by Trichophyton tonsurans and Trichophyton violaceum.
  • Ectothrix - It is a mild inflammatory type in which single or multiple scaly patches with hair loss are seen. Microsporum audouinii, Microsporum canis, Microsporum equinnum, and Microsporum ferrugineum cause ectothrix infection.
  • Kerion - It is a severe inflammatory type that presents with a mass with pus and sinus formation. Thick crusting and matting of hair are seen. It is commonly caused by Trichophyton verrucosum and Trichophyton mentagrophytes.
  • Favus - It is characterized by the presence of yellowish, cup‐shaped crusts known as scutula that develop around hair follicles. It is caused by Trichophyton schoenleinii.

Topical therapy has little role in the treatment. Oral itraconazole and terbinafine are used in children.

Below is an image of the endothrix variant 

 Other options:

(Option-A) Furuncle/ boil is caused by Staphylococcus. It is painful and usually situated on the neck area. It is pustular and later becomes necrotic and forms a scar. 

(Option-B) Epidermoid cyst/ sebaceous cyst results from squamous metaplasia in a damaged sebaceous gland. it is due to inflammation around a pilosebaceous follicle. The most common site of a sebaceous cyst is postauricular sulcus or below and behind the ear lobule. They are fixed to the skin and usually have a central punctum. When inflamed or infected, they should be incised and drained initially followed by total surgical excision.

(Option D): Folliculitis  is an infection of the follicular ostium. It is caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It presents as small, follicular papules or pinhead pustules.

Related Pearl: Characteristic features of macroconidia and microconidia of dermatophytes

Dermatophyte  

Macroconidia

Thin-walled, pencil-shaped

Small unicellular

Microsporum

Multicellular, spindle-shaped

Scanty

Absent

Epidermophyton

Related Pearl: Causes of scarring and non-scarring alopecia- Mnemonic

Alopecia or hair loss can be classified as :

  1. Non-Scarring/Non-Cicatricial alopecia
  2. Scarring/Cicatricial alopecia 

Mnemonic for causes of non-scarring alopecia: THATS STD!

  • Tinea capitis(Non-Inflammatory Type  - grey patch and black dot types )
  • Hormonal - Hypothyroidism, Androgenetic alopecia
  • Anagen effluvium, Alopecia areata
  • Trichotillomania
  • Secondary syphilis (moth-eaten alopecia)
  • SLE(predominantly causes non-scarring alopecia but also can cause scarring alopecia)
  • Telogen effluvium
  • Deficiency of Zinc, Iron 

Mnemonic for causes of scarring alopecia: SF2L3

  • Scleroderma - Linear scalp morphea (en coup de sabre)
  • Favus and Kerion (Inflammatory Type of Tinea capitis)
  • Folliculitis decalvans
  • Lichen planopilaris
  • Lupus vulgaris
  • Lupus erythematosis - discoid (DLE)
  • Pseudopelade of Brocq

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with intermittent fever, lower abdominal pain, and increased urinary frequency. Urine appears pale and opalescent with the presence of red blood cells and pus cells. Routine urine culture shows no growth. A CT scan was done as shown. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the management of this patient?

choices.text: Medical therapy successfully eradicates bacteria and prevents complications
Presence of acid-fast bacilli in urine is confirmatory
Medical therapy in this condition is as same as that of pulmonary TB
CT urography is the most sensitive imaging modility

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the CT scan are suggestive of renal tuberculosis. The incorrect statement is Option A.

Genitourinary TB is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream and is thus always a secondary TB. There is either reinfection or reactivation of old TB.

Genitourinary TB is a cause of sterile pyuria. Diagnosis is confirmed with a tuberculin test, or at least 3 consecutive early-morning specimens of urine, are examined for acid-fast bacilli. They are stained with a Ziehl–Neelsen stain and subsequently cultured.

The most sensitive imaging modality in renal tuberculosis is CT urography/pyelography. NCCT is the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications. Manifestations of renal TB as seen on CT are as follows:

  • Early: Papillary necrosis
  • Progressive:
    • Multifocal strictures
    • Generalized or focal hydronephrosis
    • Mural thickening and enhancement
    • Poorly enhancing renal parenchyma
  • End-stage:
    • Progressive hydronephrosis
    • Amorphous dystrophic calcification that involves the entire kidney- putty kidney (shown below) 

 

Treatment- 

  • Chemotherapy- Treatment involves anti-tubercular therapy that's similar to that of treatment of pulmonary tuberculosis. Drugs such as pyrazinamide, isoniazid, and rifampicin are used.
  • Surgical management- In renal tuberculosis, medical therapy successfully eradicates the bacteria but the complications of infection remain. It involves partial or total nephrectomy, reconstructive surgery (e.g. for ureteric strictures), and surgery for the bladder such as augmentation cystoplasty.

questions.text: The logo of a national health program is given below. According to this program, which of the following criteria is used to classify a state into the pre-elimination phase?

choices.text: States/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1
States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥1
States/UTs with API >1 but some districts reporting API <1

questions.solution:
The given logo represents National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP). 

NVBDCP is the nodal agency for the prevention of control of the following vector-borne diseases:

  • Kala-azar (also called visceral leishmaniasis)
  • Malaria
  • Dengue
  • Filariasis
  • Japanese encephalitis
  • Chikungunya

Annual parasite index (API) is defined as the number of confirmed cases per 1000 population in a year. According to this program, states/UTs with API of <1 but with some of their districts reporting API ≥ 1 belong to the pre-elimination phase.

Related Pearl: Malaria in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016-2030)

  • Goals: To eliminate malaria and maintain malaria-free status.
  • Objectives:
    • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases.
    • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to <1 case per 1000 population.
    • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

Classification of states/UTs according to the Annual Parasite Index (API):

 

Category  Criteria  Major measures:
Category 0  States/UTs with zero indigenous cases  Detect re-introduced cases and notify and maintain malaria-free status. 
Category 1  Elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  Interruption of local transmission.
Category 2  Pre-elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥1. 

Screening. 

Setting up one-stop mobile centres/clinics. 

 
Category 3  Intensified control phase – States/UTs with API ≥1.   Same as category 2

 

  • The National Strategic Plan (NSP) for Malaria Elimination (2017-22) was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare under NVBDCP, which is based on the National Framework for Malaria Elimination (2016 – 2030).
  • The NSP focuses mainly on the districts which function as the operational units.

Accordingly, all the districts are classified into the following four categories:

Category of districts Definition
Category 0: Prevention of re-establishment phase  Includes all districts in which no incidence of malaria was reported in the last 3 years.
Category 1: Elimination phase  Districts with API <1 per 1000 population.
Category 2: Pre elimination phase  Districts with API in between 1-2 per 1000 population.
Category 3: Intensified control phase  Districts with API >2 per 1000 population.

The above classification is more operational than the classification mentioned in the NFME which is state focussed.

The goal of NSP strategy is the phased elimination of malaria in India. The National Framework for Malaria Elimination (NFME) in India has set 2030 as the goal for eliminating malaria, and the goals of NSP in consonance with overall goals.

The goals of NSP 2017 – 2022 are:

  • Eliminate malaria in category 1 (API < 1) districts by 2020, and category 2 (API 1-2) districts by 2022.
  • Reduce transmission in category 3 districts to stabilize API at <1 by 2022.

questions.text: An 8-month-old child was brought for evaluation after an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures lasting for 5 minutes. The examination is positive for a fever of 103°F and otitis media. Neurological findings are normal.  Which of the following factors increases the risk of recurrence of this condition?

choices.text: High serum sodium at the time of presentation

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an 8-month-old child presenting with generalized tonic-clonic seizures lasting for 5 minutes along with high-grade fever and otitis media in a neurologically healthy state suggests febrile seizure. The age of the child less than 1 year increases its risk of recurrence. 

Febrile seizures occur in children of the age of 6-60 months with a high-grade fever of 38°C (100.4 F) or higher without underlying CNS infections, metabolic abnormality, or prior afebrile seizures.

Risk factors for febrile seizures:

Major Minor
Age < 1 year Family history of epilepsy or febrile seizures
Duration of fever < 24 hours Complex febrile seizure (Option A)
Fever range: 38-39°C (100.4-102.2°F) Male gender (Option B)
  Lower serum sodium levels at the time of presentation (Option D)

Lumbar puncture should be performed in the first episode of seizures with fever, for all infants <6 months of age to exclude meningitis. Electroencephalogram and neuroimaging are advised for children with suspected epilepsy or neurological abnormalities.

Acute treatment of febrile seizures includes lorazepam and midazolam for seizures lasting more than 5 minutes. Rectal diazepam is prescribed to use at home as rescue medication if febrile seizures last more than 5 minutes. The use of antipyretics can decrease the discomfort of the child but does not reduce the risk of having a recurrent febrile seizure.
